**The Imperial Commentary** (御疏) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人), hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人).
**"Thus"** (是以) is **to elucidate the lower with the higher** (引下以明上).
Though the **Sage’s heart is concentrated and still** (圣人心虽凝寂),
**teaching flows freely** (教则流通),
thus **constantly employing the Five Virtues** (常用五善) to **save beings** (救人),
**so that all may be liberated and enlightened** (令必释然而达解),
**with great compassion and equality** (大慈平等),
**without partiality or exclusion** (无所偏隔).
**All beings are universally guided with virtue** (凡是於人，尽皆善诱),
hence it is said: **"The Sage constantly saves beings, hence there is no abandonment of beings"** (故云常善救人，故无弃人).

**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物), hence **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (故无弃物).
**"Phenomena"** (物) **encompass both sentient and insentient beings** (通有识无识).
**Saving beings through virtuous teaching** (救人善教), hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故不弃人).
**Saving phenomena through a virtuous heart** (救物善心), **there is also no abandonment of phenomena** (亦无弃物),
**allowing all movement and growth to flourish** (使令动植咸遂),
**without any harm or injury** (无残伤者),
hence it is said: **"The Sage constantly saves phenomena, hence there is no abandonment of phenomena"** (故云常善救物，故无弃物).

**Master He Shang Gong** (河上公) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人),
**the Sage’s teaching of loyalty and rectitude** (圣人所以教人忠正者),
is **to save the lives of beings** (欲以救人之性命).
Hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人),
**allowing the noble and base to each attain their place** (使贵贱各得其所).

**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物),
**the Sage’s teaching to follow the Four Seasons** (圣人所以教民顺四时),
is **to save all phenomena from harm and injury** (以救万物之残伤).
Hence **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (故无弃物),
**the Sage does not demean stone while esteeming jade** (圣人不贱石而贵玉),
**viewing them as one** (视之如一).

**Rong** (荣) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人),
**yet there is no abandonment of beings** (而无弃人).
**If one thing loses its place** (一物失所), **it is mourned and taken into consideration** (虑轸纳隍),
**viewing beings as one’s children** (视人如子),
**how could there be abandonment**? (宁有弃乎).
The **True Sage expounds scriptures** (真圣阐经) **to open enlightenment** (以开化),
**responding to their karmic resonance** (赴感),
**to guide the common** (以遵凡),
**using the Dao/Way to deliver them** (以道济之),
**never omitting or abandoning any** (曾无遗弃).

**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物),
**yet there is no abandonment of phenomena** (而无弃物).
**Beginning and end, the Sage employs the Dao/Way** (始终用道),
hence it is said: **"constantly"** (故言常).
**Grace extends to all directions** (惠及万方),
hence it is said: **"virtuous"** (故言善).
**Virtue can broadly deliver** (德能广济),
hence it is said: **"salvation"** (故言救).
**"Phenomena"** (物) **speaks universally of all things** (通言一切),
hence it is said: **"phenomena"** (故言物).

**The Imperial Commentary** (成疏) **says:**
Thus, the **Sage constantly saves beings** (是以圣人常善救人), hence **there is no abandonment of beings** (故无弃人).
The **Sage** (圣人) is **the same as the prior one** (即是前三业清净六根解脱之人也),
**able to take the great vow** (为能发弘誓愿),
**and save all beings** (救度众生),
thus **constantly remaining in the world** (故常在世间),
**responding to all karmic resonances** (有感斯应),
**with compassion and virtue, equal and unceasing** (慈善平等),
**never omitting or abandoning any** (终不遗弃).
**The Sage constantly saves phenomena** (常善救物), yet **there is no abandonment of phenomena** (而无弃物).
**First mentioning beings** (先举人者) **demonstrates the恩 being extended to sentient beings** (恩被有情),
**then mentioning phenomena** (后举物者) **shows the virtue permeating insentient beings** (示仁覃无识).」

**Text:**
「亦言救人，直据黔首，救物爰及四生也。是谓袭明。」

**Translation:**
It also speaks of saving beings—
**directly** (直) **governing the common folk** (据黔首),
**and saving phenomena** (物) **extending to the fourfold life** (爰及四生).
This is called **inheriting the luminous** (袭明).

---

**御注:**
密用日袭，五善之行在於忘遣，忘遣则无迹，故云密用。
密用则悟了，故谓之明也。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Gloss (御注) says:**
*"Clad in secrecy"* (密用) is called *inheriting* (袭).
The five virtuous deeds lie in **forgetting and abandoning** (忘遣),
forgetting and abandoning leaves **no trace** (无迹), hence it is called *secret use* (密用).
When secretly used, **enlightenment is attained** (悟了), hence it is called *luminous* (明).

---

**御疏:**
袭，密用也。明，了悟也。
善行救人，在於忘遗，若滞教矜有，辙迹必存，故虽常善救人，终使慧心无滞，如此密用，则能悟了。
故云是谓袭明。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Commentary (御疏) says:**
*Inheriting* (袭) is *secret use* (密用).
*Luminous* (明) is *enlightenment* (了悟).
Virtuous deeds in saving beings lie in **forgetting and abandoning** (忘遗).
If one clings to teachings or boasts of possession, **traces will remain** (辙迹必存).
Thus, though one constantly performs virtuous deeds in saving beings, **the wise mind remains unobstructed** (慧心无滞).
Such *secret use* (密用) then attains enlightenment (悟了).
Hence it is called *inheriting the luminous* (袭明).

---

**河上公曰:**
圣人善救人物，是谓袭明天道。

**Translation:**
**Master He Shang (河上公) says:**
The **Sage** (圣人) **virtuously saves beings and phenomena** (善救人物),
this is called *inheriting the luminous Dao of Heaven* (袭明天道).

---

**荣曰:**
善行五者，人物兼济，承道而用，是谓袭明。

**Translation:**
**Master Rong (荣) says:**
The five virtuous deeds—
**saving beings and phenomena** (人物兼济),
**inheriting and applying the Dao** (承道而用)—
this is called *inheriting the luminous* (袭明).

---

**成疏:**
袭，承也，用也。
此即结叹常善圣人，利物无弃，可谓承用圣明之道也。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) says:**
*Inheriting* (袭) means **inheriting** (承) **and applying** (用).
This concludes the praise of the **constantly virtuous Sage** (常善圣人),
whose benefit extends to all without abandonment—
truly **inheriting and applying the luminous Dao of the Sage** (承用圣明之道).

---

**第四示师资之道，修学之妙。**
故善人不善人之师，不善人善人之资。

**Translation:**
**Fourth, it illustrates the Dao of teacher and disciple, the subtlety of cultivation.**
Thus, **the virtuous are teachers to the unvirtuous** (善人不善人之师),
and **the unvirtuous are resources for the virtuous** (不善人善人之资).

---

**御注:**
师，法。资，取。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Gloss (御注) says:**
*Teacher* (师) is *law/teaching* (法).
*Resource* (资) is *to take/employ* (取).

---

**御疏:**
师，法也。
夫善人者，离诸爱染，则心清净，於法无滞，则教圆通。
取喻於水，物来斯鉴，所鉴者则形而有象，能鉴者见象而无心。
善人正慧若斯，故可为不善人之师法也。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Commentary (御疏) says:**
*Teacher* (师) is *law/teaching* (法).
The **virtuous person** (善人), having **separated from all attachments and defilements** (离诸爱染),
has a **pure mind** (心清净) and **no obstruction in the teachings** (於法无滞),
thus their instruction is **perfectly fluid** (教圆通).
Take the analogy of water—
when objects approach, they are reflected.
The reflected objects have **form and appearance** (形而有象),
but the water itself **sees the appearance without clinging** (见象而无心).
The **right wisdom of the virtuous** (善人正慧) is thus,
hence they can serve as **teachings for the unvirtuous** (不善人之师法).

---

**不善人之资，资，取也。**
夫火有其炎，寒者附之。
闻道动行，必资宗匠，既说先生之善，须伏弟子之劳，
则不善之人，善人可取以役使尔。

**Translation:**
*The unvirtuous as resources* (不善人之资), *resource* (资) is *to take/employ* (取).
Fire has its **flame** (炎), and the cold cling to it.
When one **hears the Dao and acts**, they must **employ masters** (资宗匠).
Having **explained the virtues of the master** (说先生之善),
one must **submit to the labor of the disciple** (伏弟子之劳).
Thus, the **unvirtuous** (不善之人) can be **taken and employed by the virtuous** (善人可取以役使).

---

**河上公曰:**
故善人不善人之师，人之行善者，圣人即以为人师也。
不善人善人之资，资，用也。
人行不善者，圣人犹教道使为善，得以给用之。

**Translation:**
**Master He Shang (河上公) says:**
Thus, **the virtuous are teachers to the unvirtuous** (善人不善人之师)—
those who **practice virtue** (行善者), the **Sage** (圣人) **makes them teachers for others** (以为人师).
*The unvirtuous as resources* (不善人善人之资), *resource* (资) is *to employ* (用).
Even those who **practice unvirtue** (行不善者),
the **Sage** (圣人) **still teaches them the Dao to become virtuous** (教道使为善),
thus they can be **employed for use** (得以给用).

---

**荣曰:**
行与道合，德能利物，善人也。
人之仪表，物之楷模，师也。
暗者求明，明者不求於暗，爱之以作役，具之以束修，资也。

**Translation:**
**Master Rong (荣) says:**
**Practice aligning with the Dao** (行与道合), **virtue able to benefit beings** (德能利物)—this is the **virtuous** (善人).
**Human models, exemplars for phenomena** (人之仪表，物之楷模)—this is the *teacher* (师).
The **obscure seek the luminous** (暗者求明),
the **luminous do not seek the obscure** (明者不求於暗),
**loving them to serve as laborers** (爱之以作役),
**providing them with offerings** (具之以束修)—this is *resource* (资).

---

**成疏:**
善人不善人之师，善人即向袭明之人也，
言此人恒怀大心，先物后己，引导众生，允当宗匠。
不善人善人之资，资，用也，亦是助益之义。
言善人恒在有中化导群品，即用不善之类而为福田，
以彼众生益成我德故也。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) says:**
*The virtuous as teachers to the unvirtuous* (善人不善人之师)—
the **virtuous** (善人) are those who **inherit the luminous** (向袭明之人).
It speaks of such a person **constantly harboring a great heart** (恒怀大心),
**prioritizing beings over self** (先物后己),
**guiding all beings** (引导众生), truly **worthy as masters** (允当宗匠).
*The unvirtuous as resources for the virtuous* (不善人善人之资), *resource* (资) is *employment* (用), also meaning *assistance and benefit* (助益之义).
It speaks of the **virtuous constantly transforming and guiding all classes within existence** (恒在有中化导群品),
thus **employing the unvirtuous as fields of merit** (用不善之类而为福田),
for the sake of **using those beings to perfect their own virtue** (以彼众生益成我德).

---

**不贵其师，不爱其资，虽知大迷，是谓要妙。**

**Translation:**
**Not honoring the teacher, not cherishing the resource** (不贵其师，不爱其资),
even if **known as great delusion** (虽知大迷),
this is called *the ultimate subtlety* (是谓要妙).

---

**御注:**
此章深旨，教以兼忘，若存师资，未为极致。
今明所以贵师为存学相，学相既空，自无所贵，
所以爱资为存教相，於教忘教，故不爱资。
贵爱两忘，而道自化也。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Gloss (御注) says:**
This passage contains **profound meaning** (深旨),
teaching **simultaneous forgetting** (兼忘).
If one **retains attachment to teacher and resource** (存师资), it is not the ultimate.
Now it clarifies:
**Honoring the teacher** (贵师) is **retaining the form of learning** (存学相).
When the **form of learning is emptied** (学相既空), there is **nothing to honor** (自无所贵).
**Cherishing the resource** (爱资) is **retaining the form of teaching** (存教相).
In **teaching, one forgets teaching** (於教忘教), hence **no cherishing of the resource** (故不爱资).
**Forgetting both honor and cherishing** (贵爱两忘),
the **Dao transforms of itself** (而道自化).

---

**御疏:**
虽知大迷，是谓要妙。
夫物初第进修，两存学相，未能忘教，故贵爱师资。
若能体了行门，学无所学，师资之名既去，贵爱之目不存。
然此章大宗，教之忘遣，语以渐顿，不无阶级，
论其造极，是法都空，故前举为师为资，示进修之路，
后云不贵不爱，将导悟证之空。
则明所以贵师为存学相，学相既空，自无所贵。
所以爱资为存教相，於教兼忘，故不爱资，
鱼相忘於江湖，自无濡沬。
乍闻斯旨，凡俗不悟，执学滞教，则必以为大迷，
故老君格量云，虽知凡俗以此为大迷，
於道而论，是谓要妙。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Commentary (御疏) says:**
Even if **known as great delusion** (虽知大迷),
this is called *the ultimate subtlety* (是谓要妙).
Initially, beings **begin cultivation** (初第进修),
**retaining both forms of learning** (两存学相),
**unable to forget teaching** (未能忘教),
hence they **honor and cherish teacher and resource** (故贵爱师资).
If one **fully realizes the path of practice** (能体了行门),
**learning becomes non-learning** (学无所学),
the **names of teacher and resource vanish** (师资之名既去),
and the **objects of honor and cherishing do not remain** (贵爱之目不存).
Yet this passage **primarily expounds** (大宗),
the **forgetting and abandoning of teaching** (教之忘遣),
speaking in **gradual and sudden stages** (语以渐顿), not without **progressive levels** (不无阶级).
When **attaining the ultimate** (论其造极),
the **Dharma is entirely empty** (是法都空).
Thus, **earlier it speaks of teacher and resource** (前举为师为资),
**showing the path of cultivation** (示进修之路),
and **later speaks of not honoring or cherishing** (后云不贵不爱),
**guiding toward the emptiness of enlightenment and realization** (将导悟证之空).
It clarifies:
**Honoring the teacher** (贵师) is **retaining the form of learning** (存学相).
When the **form of learning is emptied** (学相既空), there is **nothing to honor** (自无所贵).
**Cherishing the resource** (爱资) is **retaining the form of teaching** (存教相).
In **teaching, one forgets teaching** (於教兼忘), hence **no cherishing of the resource** (故不爱资),
**like fish forgetting each other in rivers and lakes** (鱼相忘於江湖),
**naturally without wetting or staining** (自无濡沬).
**Hearing this meaning abruptly** (乍闻斯旨),
the **common and vulgar do not awaken** (凡俗不悟),
**clinging to learning and obstructed by teaching** (执学滞教),
they will surely **deem it great delusion** (必以为大迷).
Thus, the **Venerable Master Laozi** (老君) **measured the response** (格量云),
though the **common and vulgar consider this great delusion** (虽知凡俗以此为大迷),
**from the perspective of the Dao, it is the ultimate subtlety** (於道而论，是谓要妙).

---

**河上公曰:**
不贵其师，独无辅也。
不爱其资，无所使也。
故曰不贵其师，不爱其资，虽知大迷，此谓要妙。

**Translation:**
**Master He Shang (河上公) says:**
**Not honoring the teacher** (不贵其师) means **lacking support** (独无辅).
**Not cherishing the resource** (不爱其资) means **having nothing to employ** (无所使).
Thus it is said:
**Not honoring the teacher, not cherishing the resource** (不贵其师，不爱其资),
even if **known as great delusion** (虽知大迷),
this is called *the ultimate subtlety* (此谓要妙).

---

**荣曰:**
尊师重道，贵也。
仁惠善诱，爱也。
师资之义，当贵爱也。
若师不爱於资，壅玄流而不润，资不贵於师，失慧路而难反，
悟之者要妙，昏之者大迷也。

**Translation:**
**Master Rong (荣) says:**
**Respecting the teacher and valuing the Dao** (尊师重道) is *honor* (贵).
**Kindness, benevolence, and skillful guidance** (仁惠善诱) is *cherishing* (爱).
The **meaning of teacher and resource** (师资之义) should be **honored and cherished** (当贵爱).
If the **teacher does not cherish the resource** (师不爱於资),
the **mystic flow is blocked and not nourished** (壅玄流而不润),
and if the **resource is not honored by the teacher** (资不贵於师),
the **path to wisdom is lost and difficult to return from** (失慧路而难反).
The **enlightened recognize the subtlety** (悟之者要妙),
while the **obscure remain in great delusion** (昏之者大迷).

---

**成疏:**
不贵其师，无能化也。
不爱其资，无所化也。
前以圣道凡，劝令修学，今明凡圣平等，故遣师资，
斯则从浅之深，渐阶众妙。
虽知大迷，是谓要妙。

**Translation:**
**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) says:**
**Not honoring the teacher** (不贵其师) means **lacking the power to transform** (无能化).
**Not cher

**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) continues:**
**To grasp this subtlety** (是谓要妙), **is to know the profound and mysterious Dao/Way** (能通此意，是谓知微妙要道也).
**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) says:**
**Not honoring the teacher** (师资两忘) **and not cherishing the resource** (圣凡一揆) **is the way of the enlightened**; the **common folk cling to distinctions** (俗知分别), yet though they **seem to be in great delusion** (虽似大迷), **by reason they attain the profound subtlety** (据理而言，实成要妙).

**Chapter Twenty-Eight: Knowing the Heroic (知雄章)**
This chapter follows the previous one because the previous chapter **illuminated the virtuous** (善行之士) who **constantly rescue others**; yet their **method of saving all things** (救物之方) **remains yet to be revealed**, so this chapter **briefly outlines its essence** (故次此章略示其要).

Within this chapter, **four distinctions are expounded** (文开四别):
1. **To discard rigidity and embrace softness** (去刚取柔) is the **essential path for the practitioner** (是修行人要径);
2. **To urge the abandonment of clarity for the sake of hearing** (遣明归闻) is the **model for learning the Dao/Way** (为学道楷模);
3. **To endure humiliation and forget glory** (守辱忘荣) is to **return to the root and reflect upon the origin** (归根反本);
4. **To craft the skilled and embrace the common** (匠成庶品) is to **benefit others and forget one’s own merit** (利物忘功).

**First: To discard rigidity and embrace softness, is the essential path for the practitioner.**
The **rigid and strong are perilous** (夫刚健者凶), **the Daoists warn**; the **heroic and mighty are humbled** (雄壮者屈), **the ancient sages’ adage holds**. Thus, **strong armies do not conquer in the forefront** (故兵强不胜於前), **weak waters break through what is firm in the rear** (水弱破坚於后). **Zhang Hua said:**
*"Do not boast of your glory,
For the Dao/Way abhors excess;
Do not cling to your honor,
For the towering shall fall,
As the wise and noble observe."* (无矜尔荣，天道恶盈，无侍尔贵，隆隆者坠，贤达所作，诚不虚言).

**Knowing the cycle of the four seasons** (是知四时去来), **the shift of cold and heat** (寒暑易准), **the interplay of yin and yang** (二仪回薄), **the waxing and waning of the sun and moon** (日月亏全), **how much more so for those who merge with the Dao/Way** (何况体道融明), **who know to embrace the white while abiding in the black** (知白守黑), **whose wondrous forms radiate in perfect harmony** (妙象圆照), **who discard the heroic and return to the receptive** (去雄归雌)! **To endure through countless kalpas** (历万劫而不为), **to observe the singular heart ever abiding** (观一心而常住), **is to be the valley to which all things flow** (为溪为谷，天下归焉).

**To know the heroic while guarding the receptive, is to be the valley of the world.**
**To be the valley of the world** (为天下溪), **one’s constant virtue/power never departs** (常德不离), **and returns once more to the state of the infant** (复归於婴儿).

**The Imperial Commentary (御注) says:**
**The heroic** (雄) **suffers from the flaw of overuse** (患於用壮), so **to know the heroic is to guard the receptive in stillness** (故知其雄，则当守其雌静), **embracing humility to draw all things** (谦德物归), **thus becoming the valley of the world** (是为天下溪谷). **Then the constant virtue/power never leaves** (则真常之德不离其身), **holding the Dao/Way and nurturing harmony** (抱道含和), **and returning once more to the conduct of the infant** (复归婴儿之行矣).

**The Imperial Commentary (御疏) says:**
**Knowing** (知) **is to discern** (辨识也).
**Heroic** (雄) **is rigid and impulsive** (刚躁也).
**Receptive** (雌) **is soft and tranquil** (柔静也).

**All things value completeness and harmony** (夫物贵全和), **the law seeks the middle path** (法求中道). The **heroic is excessive** (雄则过当), the **receptive is too weak** (雌则卑弱); **both fail to align with virtuous conduct** (俱未适中於善行). **One must take the green cord as the standard** (必当绿督以为经), so **to know the heroic’s rigidity and impulsiveness** (知其雄躁), **one must guard the receptive’s softness and tranquility** (则当守其雌静).

**To guard the receptive’s softness and tranquility** (守其雌静), **one must also know the heroic’s rigidity and impulsiveness** (亦当知其雄躁).
**To know the heroic and guard the receptive** (知雄守雌) **is proper**, **but to know the receptive and guard the heroic is ruinous** (知雌守雄则败). **Ruined, it obstructs practice** (败则妨行), hence the special warning to **guard the receptive alone** (故特戒守雌).

**To guard the receptive’s softness is to embody humility** (能守雌柔，是为谦德), **to which all things are drawn** (物所归往), **as waters flow into valleys** (如水归溪矣).
**The *Er Ya* (尔雅) says:**
*"Water flowing into a river is called a valley."* (水注川日溪).

**To be the valley of the world** (经为天下溪), **one’s constant virtue/power never departs** (常德不离), **and returns once more to the infant** (复归於婴儿). **Knowing the heroic and guarding the receptive** (知雄守雌), **this is called virtuous conduct** (是名善行), **to which all things are drawn** (物所归往), **making one the valley of the world** (为天下溪). **To do so is to never scatter the constant virtue/power** (能如此则真常之德曾不离散).

**The constant virtue/power never scatters** (常德不散), **for this is to embody completeness and harmony** (即是全和). **Those of full harmony** (全和之人) **think little and desire little** (少思寡欲), **serene and unassuming** (泊然未兆), **like the infant** (乃如婴儿), hence the saying: *"Return once more to the infant."* (故云复归於婴儿也).

**River Master (河上公) says:**
*"To know the heroic and guard the receptive is to be the valley of the world* (知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪). **The heroic is likened to exaltation** (雄以喻尊), **the receptive to humility** (雌以喻卑). **Though one knows their own exaltation and display** (人虽自知其尊显), **one must still guard it with humility** (当复守之以卑微). **To abandon the heroic’s strength and embrace the receptive’s softness** (去雄之强梁，就雌之柔和), **then all things shall return to it** (如是则天下归之), **as waters flow into deep valleys."* (如水之流入深溪也).

**To be the valley of the world** (为天下溪), **one’s constant virtue/power never departs** (常德不离), **for those who humble themselves like deep valleys** (人能谦下如深溪), **their virtue/power is ever-present** (则德常在), **never leaving themselves** (不离己也).

**Yan (严) says:**
*"To return to the infant is to return to one’s true intent* (於婴儿复归於志), **to the infant’s brother is to be foolishly unaware* (於婴兄蠢然而无所知也)."

**Rong (荣) says:**
*"To know the heroic and guard the receptive is to be the valley of the world* (知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪), **neither arrogant nor haughty** (不馅不骄), **for this is the middle path** (在於中平), **the conduct of the virtuous.* (君子之行也).
**Neither stagnant nor restless** (不静不躁), **dwelling in the middle harmony** (处於中和), **is the foundation of entering the Dao/Way** (入道之基也).

Thus, **those who harbor the heroic’s fierce heart** (故知怀雄猛之心者), **cannot yet attain full truth** (未可全真).
**Those who embrace the receptive’s soft nature** (抱雌柔之性者), **cannot forget the Dao/Way** (不能忘道).

**To know the heroic nature while guarding the receptive** (令知性雄而守雌), **is to neither be restless nor hasty** (则不躁不速), **and to know the receptive nature while guarding the heroic** (亦知性雌而守雄), **is to neither be stagnant nor delayed** (则不静不迟). **To avoid entrapment in either extreme** (不滞两边), **is to naturally align with the middle path** (自合中道).

**Yet many practice the heroic’s fierceness** (然行雄猛者众), **while few guard the receptive’s softness** (守雌柔者少), hence the analogy: **the enlightened are likened to deep valleys** (故喻明溪壑处下), **to which all currents flow** (众流归之), **and the humble are likened to the Dao/Way’s return** (人士谦退，道德归之).

**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) says:**
*"To know the heroic and guard the receptive is to be the valley of the world* (知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪). **A valley is a path** (溪，径也), **the heroic is yang** (雄，阳也), **the name of rigidity and fierceness** (是刚躁之名), **the receptive is yin** (雌，阴也), **the essence of softness and tranquility** (是柔静之义).

**To know the rigidity and fierceness of the heroic** (知雄躁刚猛), **is to return to death and annihilation** (适归死灭), **while to guard the softness and tranquility of the receptive** (雌柔静退), **is to attain longevity** (必致长生). Thus, **to abandon the heroic and guard the receptive** (故弃雄而守雌), **is to become the essential path for the world** (可为天下之要径).

**The constant virtue/power never departs** (常德不离), **and returns once more to the infant** (复归於婴儿). **To depart** (离) **is to scatter** (散也), **the infant is an analogy for undivided wisdom** (婴儿譬无分别智也). **It says that if one constantly guards tranquility** (言人常能守静), **their virtue/power will not scatter** (则其德不散), **thus returning to their original nature** (故能复於本性), **and embracing undivided wisdom** (归无分别智).

**Second: To urge the abandonment of clarity for the sake of hearing, is the model for learning the Dao/Way.**
**To know the white and guard the black, is to be the pattern of the world.**
**To be the pattern of the world** (为天下式), **one’s constant virtue/power does not err** (常德不武), **and returns once more to the boundless** (复归於无极).

**The Imperial Commentary (御注) says:**
**To guard the receptive’s tranquility** (能守雌静), **one’s constant virtue/power never departs** (常德不离). **Though their virtue/power is clear and bright** (德虽明白), **they must be like darkness** (当如暗昧), **thus becoming the pattern of the world** (如此则为天下法式). **Their constant virtue/power applies without deviation** (常德应用), **never differing** (曾不差违), **and their virtue/power is inexhaustible** (德用不穷), hence it **returns once more to the boundless** (故复归於无极). **To err** (武) **is to deviate** (差也).

**The Imperial Commentary (御疏) says:**
*"To know the white and guard the black is to be the pattern of the world* (知其白，守其黑，为天下式). **White is illumination** (白，照明也), **black is darkness** (黑，暗昧也), **pattern is law** (式，法也).

**Those who guard the receptive’s tranquility** (夫能守雌静), **their conduct becomes radiant and clear** (则德行昭明). **Though their conduct is clear** (德虽昭明), **they do not pursue worldly matters** (不以务物), **and remain like darkness** (当如暗昧), **selflessly preserving purity and harmony** (自守淳和). **To do so is to become the pattern of the world.* (能如此则可为天下之法矣)."

「To be the world’s **pattern** (式), **virtue/power** is always unerring (常德不忒), **returning once more to the boundless** (复归於无极).
**To err** (忒) **is to deviate** (差, *also called* 武).
**Boundless** (极) **is the utmost limit** (穷极也).

**To know the white and guard the black is called complete virtue/power** (知白守黑，是谓德全).
**Those with complete virtue/power** (德全之人) **can become the world’s pattern** (可为天下法式), **then the Dao of true constancy** (真常之道) **flows in response and is applied** (随应而用), **its application never differing** (应用无差忒), **its use inexhaustible** (用亦不穷), hence it **returns once more to the boundless limit** (故云复归於无穷极也).

**Master He Shang Gong (河上公) said:**
*"To know the white and guard the black is to be the world’s pattern* (知其白，守其黑，为天下式). **White** (白) **illuminates** (喻昭昭), **black** (黑) **is silent** (喻默默). Though a person knows their own radiance and clarity (自知昭昭明达), they must **guard it with silence** (当复守之以默默), **remaining like darkness** (如暗昧无所见), **thus becoming the world’s pattern** (如是则可为天下法式也).

**To be the world’s pattern** (为天下式), **virtue/power is always unerring** (常德不忒). If a person can be the world’s pattern (人能为天下法式), then **virtue/power remains constant within them** (则德常在於己), **no longer deviating** (不复差武也).
**To return once more to the boundless** (复归於无极) **and have virtue/power that never deviates** (德不差武), **is to achieve longevity and eternal life** (则长生久寿), **returning one’s body to the boundless limit** (归身於无穷极也).

**Master Yan (严) said:**
*"To return to the unborn* (反於未生), **to return to the unbegun** (复於未始), **is to align with the Dao’s constancy** (与道为常), **thus returning to the boundless** (归於无极矣)."

**Master Rong (荣) said:**
*"To know the white and guard the black is to be the world’s pattern* (知其白，守其黑，为天下式). **Great brightness is like shame** (大白若辱), **great wisdom is like foolishness** (大智若愚). **To conceal oneself and remain harmonious** (晦尔安身), **this is the virtue/power of pattern** (斯为法式).
**Virtue/power** is always unerring (常德不武), **returning once more to the boundless** (复归於无极).
**To err** (忒) **is to deviate** (差也). If a person **does not dazzle others with their wisdom** (不以智耀人) **and does not let fame harm themselves** (不为名害己), **though their inner nature is pure and bright** (内虽洁白), **their outward conduct is like dust** (外实同尘), **then those who establish themselves receive endless blessings** (立身者受禄无穷), **and those who cultivate the Dao attain the boundless virtue/power of the Dao** (修道者成真无极).

**The Imperial Commentary (成疏) says:**
*"To know the white and guard the black is to be the world’s pattern* (知其白，守其黑，为天下式). **White** (白) **is radiance** (昭明也), **black** (黑) **is darkness** (暗昧也). **Pattern** (式) **is law** (法也).
**To display one’s brightness openly** (自显明白) **and dazzle others** (炫曜於人) **is to provoke their resentment** (人必挫之), **which is not truly wise** (良非知者).
**To conceal one’s light and obscure one’s traces** (韬光晦迹), **to retreat and guard in darkness** (退守暗昧), **and not offend against things** (不忤於物), **this is the conduct of the virtuous** (故是德人).
**Those who know the benefits and harms of white and black** (能知白黑利害者) **can serve as the great model for cultivators** (可为修学者之洪范也).
**Virtue/power** is always unerring (常德不忒), **returning once more to the boundless** (复归於无极).
**To err** (忒) **is to deviate** (差也). **Boundless** (无极) **is the Dao** (道也).
**If one constantly abandons brightness and guards in darkness** (常能弃明守暗), **their virtue/power will not deviate** (其德不差), **and having returned to purity and emptiness** (既复清虚), **they will return to the Dao’s utmost** (归於至道).

**The third teaching shows guarding shame and forgetting honor, returning to the root and reversing to the origin** (第三示守辱忘荣，归根反本).
**To know honor and guard shame is to be the world’s valley** (知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷).

**To be the world’s valley** (为天下谷), **virtue/power is then fully sufficient** (常德乃足), **returning once more to simplicity** (复归於朴).
**The Imperial Commentary (御注) says:**
*"Though virtue/power is exalted and honored* (德虽尊荣), **they must always guard lowliness and shame** (常守卑辱), **and things will respond accordingly** (物感斯应), **like a valley echoing to sound** (如谷报声), **endlessly receiving** (虚受不穷). **If virtue/power is fully sufficient** (常德圆足), **then it returns once more to the Dao** (则复归於道也).

**The Imperial Commentary (御疏) says:**
*"To know honor and guard shame is to be the world’s valley* (知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷). **Honor** (荣) **is exalted nobility** (尊荣也), **shame** (辱) **is lowliness and baseness** (卑辱也).
**When in exalted nobility** (处於荣贵), **one naturally rises to arrogance and extravagance** (遂起骄奢), **rewarding the good and punishing the wicked** (福善祸淫), **suddenly declining and falling** (忽然凋落), **thus this honor becomes the foundation of calamity** (此之荣宠，翻为祸基).
**If one knows that elevation and decline cannot be constant** (若知倚伏不可常), **and that nobility is the beginning of misfortune** (贵为祸始), **they must restrain themselves** (应须自戒), **and not indulge in recklessness** (勿为放逸).
**Though in honor and nobility** (处於荣华), **one must always be like the lowly and base** (恒如卑贱), hence **nobility takes baseness as its root** (故贵以贱为本), **and height takes lowliness as its foundation** (高以下为基).
**Thus, to know honor and guard shame** (是以知荣守辱), **the world will submit to it** (天下归奏), **like a river valley receiving all things** (譬彼川谷，包纳虚容也).
**To be the world’s valley** (为天下谷), **virtue/power is then fully sufficient** (常德乃足), **returning once more to simplicity** (复归於朴).
**Simplicity** (朴) **is the true origin** (真本也). **Beginning with knowing the masculine** (始自知雄), **ending with guarding shame** (终乎守辱), **these three stages of cultivation** (三种修学) **are the essentials of the Dao** (为道之要).
**Like an empty valley** (又如虚谷), **it exhausts nothing yet contains all** (罄无不容), **hence the Dao’s highest virtue/power** (所以常道上德) **is fully sufficient here** (於是乃足), **and it can return to true emptiness** (故能复於真空), **reverting to the wondrous origin** (归於妙本也).

**The fourth teaching reveals the artisan’s creation of myriad things, benefiting others while forgetting their own merit** (第四显匠成庶品，利物忘功).
**When simplicity disperses, it becomes vessels** (朴散则为器). **The Sage employs them** (圣人用之), **and they become officials and leaders** (则为官长).」

「The Imperial Commentary: When **virtue/power** (德) is contained within and harmonized (内融), it again returns to **simplicity** (朴).
When **virtue/power** (常德) responds and applies itself, it disperses and becomes **vessels** (器). Once engaged in form and vessel (形器), there must be both refined and coarse (精赢), hence the Sage employs them and they become **officials and leaders of the masses** (群村之官长).

○ The Imperial Exegesis: **Vessels** (器) are **forms and vessels** (形器). From **knowing the masculine** (知雄) to **guarding shame** (守辱), through cultivation of nature and return to **virtue/power** (德), it again returns to the **Dao/Way** (道). Here, when it says **simplicity disperses to become vessels** (朴散则为器), it clarifies that when **virtue/power** (德) is fully unified with the **Dao/Way** (道), it can respond and apply itself. When application becomes coarse (迹粗), it involves **forms and vessels** (形器), hence it says **simplicity disperses to become vessels** (朴散则为器). Once engaged in form and vessel, the **masses’** (村) usage will have refined and coarse (精粗), thus ordinary people employing them can only preserve their own **purity and simplicity** (淳朴), while the Sage’s broad salvation becomes **officials and leaders of the masses** (群村之官长).

○ Master He Shang Gong (河上公) said: When **simplicity** (朴) disperses, it becomes **vessels** (器). The **simplicity** (朴) of all things disperses to become **vessels and their uses** (器用). If the **Dao/Way** (道) disperses, it becomes **spiritual luminosity** (神明), flowing as the **sun and moon** (日月), dividing into the **Five Phases** (五行). The Sage employs them and they become **officials and leaders** (官长); when the Sage applies them externally, they become the **original leaders of all officials** (百官之元长).

○ Rong (荣) said: When **the seed** (种) disperses, it becomes **vessels** (器). The Sage uses them as **officials and leaders** (官长), hence the great measure is without harm (割). Before **qi** (气) is divided, it is **the seed** (种). When the three **kinds of virtue/power** (三种) have positions, they are **vessels** (器). From the **formless** (无形) to opening **manifest forms** (有象), hence it speaks of **dispersing simplicity to become vessels** (散朴以为器). The **noble** (尊) and **humble** (卑) nature of Heaven and Earth being established, the **noble** (贵) and **humble** (贱) nature of ruler and subject is also clear. It is set as ruler, hence it says **officials and leaders** (官长). Governing all under Heaven, hence it speaks of **great measure** (大制). The **high** (上) can nurture and give life (字育), the **low** (下) can receive without harm (不伤), hence it says **without harm** (无割). This also clarifies the Sage’s opening of the **teachings of the unsaid** (不言之教), which is the same as **dispersing simplicity to become vessels** (散朴为器).

□ The true **Immortal Adepts** (真仙) are the **officials and leaders** (官长). They employ the **Dao/Way** (道) to govern all things, and all things return to them—this is the **great measure** (大制). Their **compassion** (慈) can save all things, and all things are preserved whole—this is **without harm** (无割).

○ The *Ceng* Exegesis: The **Sage’s** (至圣) divine **virtue/power** (神力) is beyond thought or speech. Within the **Three Realms** (三界) and beyond, there is nothing not subdued. They lead and encompass all broadly and universally, hence they are called **great measure** (大制). Yet they **nurture and refine all things** (亭毒群品), **molding and tempering living beings** (陶铸生灵), **attributing merit to all** (推功於物), not harming them as a **butcher** (宰主). **Harm** (割) means to **butcher or judge** (宰断).」

**Chapter Twenty-Nine: The Chapter on "Those Who Would Take the Realm"**

This chapter follows the previous because the prior expounds on **forgetting merit and utility for things**, becoming a **sovereign and artisan** for the realm. Thus, this chapter reveals the **arts of governing the realm and body while benefiting things**.

Within this chapter, the text unfolds in three layers:
1. It first clarifies that **desire and action** ruin the body and destroy the realm.
2. It then presents the **manifestations of action**, demonstrating that all **phenomena are impermanent**.
3. Finally, it contrasts the **Sage**, who **mysteriously transcends attachment**.

**1. Clarifying that desire and action ruin the body and destroy the realm**

A **Dao-governed ruler** is a **non-acting sovereign**. To **take the realm**, one must **align with the times and respond to the people**. Thus, **King Wu of Zhou** overthrew Shang, and the **white banner hung from King Zhou’s head**; **Xiang Yu** ruled Han, and the **Red Emperor perished at his hands**.

Yet those who **do not know the coming of Heaven’s Mandate** and **arrogantly stir up ambition** are warned in the *Treatise on Fate*: *"Dragons, rhinos, and sun-horned beasts are signs of imperial rule; river-eyes and tortoise markings are signs of noble rank."* Is this not so?

The **High Ancestor** (Han Gaozu) **yielded and ascended** to power, while **Qin Shihuang** **brutally seized it** and saw his line **decline**. I see that those who **take the realm by force** cannot **sustain it**. Is this not the truth?

*"Those who would take the realm and do so—*
I see that they **cannot achieve their ends**."*

**Emperor’s Annotation:** *"The realm"* refers to the **precious position of sovereignty**. A ruler must **await the Mandate’s arrival**—if a **violent usurper** seeks to **seize it by force**, it will not endure.

**Emperor’s Exegesis:** *"The realm"* is the **precious position of sovereignty**. Heaven **commands emperors** and **governs all living beings**—this must await the **Mandate’s arrival** before one **rules over all**. Yet **wicked rebels** and **violent men**, who **seek to seize the realm by force**, will be **exterminated before they can even hope for Heaven’s blessings**. Thus, the **Daoist Master warns**: *"I see that such men **cannot achieve their ends**."* *"Already"* is a **particle of emphasis**.

**River Upper Master (河上公) says:** *"Those who would take the realm"*—meaning they **aspire to be sovereign**. *"And do so"*—meaning they **rule through action**. *"I see that they **cannot achieve their ends**"*—because **Heaven’s Way abhors turmoil and impurity**, and **human hearts abhor excessive desire**.

**Yan (严) says:** *"The realm"* is what **spiritual essences** create and **Great Harmony** fulfills—**spiritual essences perceive it**, and even **sages cannot fully grasp it**; **force cannot control it**.

**Li (李) says:** *"Non-action and non-doing"* can **govern the realm**. If one **acts and does**, I see that they **cannot achieve their ends**.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:** *"Those who would seize the realm and its people as sovereigns"* must **empty their hearts and abandon desire**. If they **seize it through action**, their **failure is already evident**.

*"The realm is a divine instrument*—it **cannot be forced**.*
*Those who force it—**ruin it**."*

**Emperor’s Annotation:** *"The realm"* is the **precious position of sovereignty**, a **divine instrument of Heaven and Earth**—thus, it **cannot be seized by force**. Hence, *"Those who force it—ruin it"*—this warns **wicked and rebellious ministers**.

**Emperor’s Exegesis:** *"The realm"* is the **precious position of sovereignty**, which **cannot be seized by force**—for it is a **divine instrument** meant for **eternal sages** who **spread benevolent transformations**, ensuring that **violent men do not poison the realm with their schemes**. Thus, it is **known that it cannot be forced**, and if forced, it **will surely fail**. This warns **wicked and rebellious ministers**.

**River Upper Master says:** *"The realm is a divine instrument*—it **cannot be forced**."* *"Instrument"* means **thing**—**humanity is the divine thing of the realm**. Divine things **love tranquility** and **cannot be governed by action**. *"Those who force it—ruin it"*—because **governing through action corrupts their innate purity**.

**Li (李) says:** If one **promotes the realm’s goodness without claiming its rewards**, **removes the realm’s harms without taking credit**, and **allows all to drink the harmony of virtue**, then **all things follow transformation in joy**, and one **can securely hold the precious position and guard the divine instrument**. But if one **does not know the error of action** and **clings to it**, then **ruin and loss are certain**.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:** *"The realm is a divine instrument*—it **cannot be forced**."* All **sentient beings** possess **spiritual essences** and **can receive the Dao**—thus, it is called a **divine instrument**. The **divine instrument** is also the **imperial position**. If one **governs with non-action and tranquility**, all things **prosper in harmony**; but if one **disturbs with action**, all living beings **lose their nature**—thus, it **cannot be forced**. *"Those who force it—ruin it"*—**clinging to action leads to ruin and death**; **fixating on desires causes loss of realm and state*. *"Those who cling—lose it."*

**Emperor’s Annotation:** *"The Mandate rests upon them"*—they have already **obtained sovereignty**, yet they **cling to this position**, **oppressing the divine sovereign**. Heaven’s **retribution will cause them to lose it**—this warns **emperors**.

**Emperor’s Exegesis:** A **ruler** may either **restore order from chaos** or **preserve the ancestral path**. All must **display virtue and block transgressions**, **relieve the hidden and seek the crippled**. But if they **cling to this position**, **oppressing the divine sovereign**, they **bring disorder without form**, causing **Heaven’s retribution to punish the wicked and bless the virtuous**, **divine wrath and human anger to arise**, **disasters to multiply**, and **chaos to ensue**. Who would **obey such a ruler**? They will **surely lose their position**. This warns **emperors**.

**River Master (He Shang Gong) says:**
If one **forcefully clings to teachings**, they lose their **true essence**, giving rise to **deception and falsehood**.

The second principle: **The Sage’s Minister** demonstrates that all **dharma/laws are impermanent**.
Thus, things **move or follow**, **warm or chill**, **strengthen or weaken**, **uphold or collapse**.

**Emperor’s Exegesis:**
To **act is to fail**; to **cling is to lose**. Hence, things may **move ahead**, **follow behind**, **warm by exhalation**, **chill by inhalation**, **strengthen when supported**, **weaken when suppressed**, **succeed when guided by Dao**, or **collapse from lack of virtue**.

**Emperor’s Commentary:**
This illustrates that all things are **not constant**, and affairs **rise and fall in turn**.
**Exhalation (mǘ)**—warm *qi*.
**Inhalation (chuī)**—cold *qi*.
**Weak (yíng)**—feeble.
**Uphold (zài)**—to **manage affairs**.
**Collapse (huī)**—to **ruin**.

Moreover, **action leads to ruin**; **clinging leads to loss**. Just as all things **move ahead or follow behind**, **warm or chill**, **strengthen when supported or weaken when suppressed**, **uphold affairs or push toward ruin**—like **red and black threads**, they cannot be measured by a single standard. Only by **aligning with natural inclination** can one **endlessly promote without exhaustion**.

**River Master says:**
Thus, things **move or follow**—what the **sovereign leads**, the **subjects must follow**.
**Exhale or inhale**—**exhale** is **warmth**; **inhale** is **cold**.
Where there is **warmth**, there must be **cold**.
**Strengthen or weaken**—where there is **strength**, there must be **weakness**.
**Uphold or collapse**—**uphold** is **stability**; **collapse** is **peril**.
Where there is **stability**, there must be **peril**.
This teaches that **rulers must not act**; governing a **state and the body** alike requires **non-action**.

**Honor (Rong) says:**
The **laws of action** have what may be **done ahead** or **followed behind**, **one warmth and one cold**, **one flourishing and one decline**.
**Gathered, they cohere**; **scattered, they collapse**.
If one **acts**, though it **succeeds, it must fail**.
If one **acts without action**, it **can decay yet renew**.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Things **move or follow**—**things** refers to **all phenomena**; **or** means **indeterminate**.
**Move**—**proceeds by itself**; **follow**—**conforms to others**.
This shows that **power and influence are unstable**.
**Exhale or inhale**—**exhale** (*mǘ-xī*) symbolizes **warmth** (*riches and nobility*); **inhale** (*chuī-qì*) symbolizes **cold** (*poverty and lowliness*).
Things may **first be noble then humble**, **first rich then poor**—
like **scarlet summer’s brilliance** or **dark winter’s chill**,
**Heaven’s heat and cold are unstable**, so too are **human fortunes**.
**Strengthen or collapse**—**what flourishes must decline**.
Thus, the *Western Ascension Scripture* says: **"The flourishing must decay."**
This shows that **flourishing and decline are unstable**.
**Uphold or collapse**—**uphold** is **continuity**; **collapse** is **ruin**.
**Continuity is success**; **ruin is failure**.
This proves that **safety and peril are unstable**.
Thus, *Zhuangzi* says:
**"Its completion is its ruin."**
These **eight unstable laws** demonstrate that **all phenomena are impermanent**.
Therefore, those who **govern states or cultivate the self** must **not cling to action or rigid control**.

---
**Third Principle: Responding to the Seated Sage**—**masterfully abandoning attachment**.

Thus, the **Sage eliminates excess**, **eliminates extravagance**, **eliminates excessiveness**.

**Emperor’s Exegesis:**
The Sage observes how things **move or follow**, knowing that **clinging leads to loss**, so they **avoid extremes**.

**Emperor’s Commentary:**
Therefore, the **Sage who governs the world**—
seeing that **movement and following are impermanent**—
knows that **arrogance and clinging must fail**.
Thus, they **restrain themselves**, **examine their conduct**, **cut greed**, and **control desires**.
They **reject excessive action**, **reject lavish adornment**, and **reject excessive indulgence**.
Examining their **names and principles**, they are divided into **three categories**.
Yet their **practical effect** aligns with **one principle**.
**Excess, extravagance, and excessiveness**—all are **transgressions**.

**River Master says:**
**Excess** refers to **lust for sounds and colors**,
**Extravagance** refers to **garments, food, and drink**,
**Excessiveness** refers to **palaces and pavilions**.
Abandoning these three, one **dwells in moderation**, **acts without action**—
then the **world transforms itself**.

**Yan (Yan) says:**
**Excess** is **action**; **extravagance** is **not moderation**; **excessiveness** is **grandeur**.
Thus, they are abandoned.

**Honor (Rong) says:**
**Extravagant Qin**—this is the **action of the past**.
**Pursuing desires is excess**; **a mind set on luxury is extravagance**; **unending indulgence is excessiveness**.
The Sage **empties the mind**, **knows contentment**—this is **abandoning excess**.
**Embrace simplicity, preserve purity**—this is **abandoning extravagance**.
**Forgot joy, then true happiness suffices**—this is **abandoning excessiveness**.

**Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The **Dao-endowed Sage**, **profoundly embodying emptiness and falsity**,
does not **cling to the eight unstable laws** above,
but **abandons the three temptations** below:
**Excess** beautifies **sounds and colors**,
**Extravagance** adorns **garments and playthings**,
**Excessiveness** expands **palaces and halls**.
Abandoning these **three delusions**, dwelling in **one moderation**—
governing the state brings **long-lasting blessings**,
cultivating the self brings **longevity and clear vision**.

---
**Chapter Thirty: Assisting the Sovereign with Dao**

This chapter follows the previous because the prior **correctly illustrates** that **rulers must not cling to rigid action**.
Thus, this chapter **clarifies that ministers aiding the sovereign** must also **abandon force and employ Dao**.

This chapter unfolds in **three distinctions**:
1. **Assisting the times with Dao**, **calming and settling the military**.
2. **Those who use Dao** **lack arrogance or self-aggrandizement**.
3. **Action contrary to Dao** **leads to peril and ruin**.

---
**First Distinction: Assisting the Times with Dao, Calming and Settling the Military**

When the **Dragon of the Clouds** transforms, **Heaven and Earth grow dark**.
When the **Phoenix soars aloft**, **the rivers rage in fury**.
Why?
Because **clouds amplify the Dragon’s power**, **water nourishes the Phoenix’s ambition**.

Likewise, a **sovereign** must **await a worthy minister**.
**King Wu** met **Ji Dan**—thus, the **Shang’s Dao flourished anew**.
**King Xiang** lost **Le Yi**—thus, **Yan perished in decline**.

「If a person can **expand the Dao**, how could it not be so?

A wise sovereign who secures a **virtuous** minister is like a flying **Hun** (wild goose) with wings,
A sage ruler who meets a **worthy** advisor is like a harmonious dish gaining its seasoning of salt and vinegar.
Thus, Jiang Chong met his end at **Fengchi** (凤池),
And Ho Guang’s statue was enshrined in **Lingge** (麟阁).
Is this not fitting?

**Those who assist the sovereign with Dao** do not **employ arms to overawe the world**—their deeds **invite reciprocation**.

**Commentary (御注)**:
When ministers **employ Dao to aid the sovereign**, they must **yield in submission through virtue**,
Not relying on the **threat of martial might** to **compel strength** from the world.

For **arms are instruments of calamity**, **war is perilous**.
When **arms are applied to others**, others **must respond in kind**—
Their deeds **invite reciprocation**, thus the **fortunes of victory and defeat** are **not easily measured**.

**Explanatory Notes (御疏)**:
*以 (yǐ)* means **employ/use**.
*佐 (zuǒ)* means **aid/support**.
*还 (huán)* means **reciprocate/report**.

It states that as ministers, one should **employ Dao to transform without action**,
**Aid the sovereign to attain the virtue of Yao and Shun**—
That is the **pillar and backbone** of the state.

**Displaying martial prowess** on the **two stages** (of governance),
**Cultivating cultural virtue** across the **four seas**,
**Directing the grand symbol** (of Dao) so that all under Heaven **converge in order**—
When the **great stage is level**, the **world is tranquil**.
But if one **brandishes the terror of weapons**,
**Exhausts oneself in plundering conquests**,
**Raises arms against others**—others **will inevitably respond**—
Their deeds **invite reciprocation**, thus who can **foresee the fortunes of victory and defeat**?

**Master He Shang Gong (河上公) said**:
**"Those who assist the sovereign with Dao"** means the sovereign **can employ Dao to aid himself**.
**Not employing arms to overawe the world**—
**Those who aid the sovereign with Dao** do not **use military force**,
But **follow the Dao and entrust in virtue**—enemies **will submit of their own accord**.

Their deeds **invite reciprocation**—
Their **undertakings invite reciprocation**—
**Self-reproach does not blame others**.

**Rong (荣) said**:
**Loyal ministers aid the sovereign above**,
**Worthy advisors regulate the **yin-yang** (cosmic balance)**,
**Employing Dao to triumph within the seas**—
**Not employing arms to overawe the world**—
The sovereign **also aids with Dao**,
The sovereign **already possesses Dao**—how could he **exclusively rely on arms**?

**If Dao is employed**, then **both sides settle in peace**,
**If arms are employed**, then **mutual aggression ensues**—
**One act leads to another**—thus it is said **their deeds invite reciprocation**.

**Master Cheng (成疏) said**:
**"Those who assist the sovereign with Dao"** do not **employ arms to overawe the world**—
*以 (yǐ)* means **employ/use**,
*佐 (zuǒ)* means **aid and assist**.
*Sovereign* here refers to **the ruler**.

It speaks of those who **employ the true Dao to aid the ruler**—
They must **lay down arms and cultivate culture**,
**Guide the people with virtue**,
Not **excessively using military force** to **oppress the world**.

If one takes it as a **metaphor for the mind and body**,
Then it is the **three poisons and six senses**—arms are **the six senses**.
Their deeds **invite reciprocation**—
*还 (huán)* means **to return/report**.

It states that **external reliance on arms** will **summon enemies’ grudges**,
**Internal indulgence in the three poisons** will **bring the retribution of the three realms of suffering**—
This matter **reciprocates in kind**—thus it is said **their deeds invite reciprocation**.

Where the **teacher’s influence lingers**, **thorns and brambles arise**.
After **great armies march**, **years of calamity follow**.

「**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
Where the military strategist stays, war disrupts agriculture—
If farming is neglected, thorns and brambles arise.

Weapons inflict harm, and drought or flood follows—
Farming is ruined before, and calamities ensue thereafter,
Thus there will surely be years of famine and disaster.

**Commentary of the Imperial Scholar (御疏):**
*Shī* (師), here means the ruler’s counselor,
Yet also the *Yì* (易, *I Ching*) says: *Shī* (師), means the multitude.
When armies are raised and the people mobilized,
Men are weary from service,
And those who march and those who send them off hinder agricultural labor—
Thus thorns and brambles arise.

After great armies return,
Accumulated expenses are vast,
And if the *héqì* (和氣, harmonious qi) brings blessings,
Weapons still inflict harm, drought and flood follow in succession—
Harvests fail, and so there will surely be years of famine and disaster,
To repay the grudges of relentless warfare.

**Master Héshànggōng (河上公) says:**
Where the military strategist stays, thorns and brambles arise—
Farming is neglected, and fields are left uncultivated.
After great armies return,
There will surely be years of famine,
As Heaven responds with malevolent *qì* (氣), harming the five grains—
And when the five grains perish, people suffer.

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
After great armies return,
There are surely years of famine,
And fine crops cannot be planted—
Thus thorns and brambles arise,
This is also the fault of excessive warfare.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary (成疏):**
*Shī* (師), here means the assembled forces.
Where soldiers and horses pass,
They harm both people and things—
Only thorns and brambles grow, no grain.
It is like the unrestrained *yùxīn* (欲心, craving mind) wandering where it will—
Only evil deeds multiply, no virtuous blessings arise.
Thus the virtuous are resolute in their purpose—
They dare not rely on force to prevail.
Resolute yet not arrogant,
Resolute yet not boastful,
Resolute yet not proud,
Resolute only when unavoidable.

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
The virtuous counselor is resolute in halting the enemy—
This lies in calming the people and harmonizing the multitude,
And they dare not seek victory or rely on force.
Thus, though resolute in stopping the enemy,
The enemy does not become a marauder.
Be cautious not to boast of achievements or claim credit,
Lest you become filled with arrogance and pride,
Hence it is a profound warning.

**Commentary of the Imperial Scholar (御疏):**
Thus the virtuous are resolute in their purpose—
They dare not rely on force to prevail.
The *Chūnqiū* (春秋, *Spring and Autumn Annals*) states:
*“Killing the enemy is resolute,”*
Yet now it is clear that the enemy-killer
Commands them not to invade each other,
But to stop their violence.
Thus Laozi (老君) says:
*“All actions should be unavoidable,
And those who must use arms
Should only seek to stop the enemy,
Preventing them from becoming marauders,
And should not use the many to oppress the few,
Nor invade others for the sake of force.”*
Their deeds invite withdrawal and retribution—
Hence the warning: *“They dare not rely on force to prevail.”*
Resolute yet not arrogant,
Resolute yet not boastful,
Resolute yet not proud—
The virtue of warfare lies in resolutely stopping the enemy.
Stopping the enemy out of arrogance is not true victory,
Hence, though able to stop the enemy,
Be cautious not to boast.
Boasting leads to reckless taking of credit,
Hence, though resolute in stopping the enemy,
The warning states: *“Do not claim credit for their deeds.”*
If one must claim credit for their deeds,
Then they become arrogant and overconfident.
Arrogance leads to delight in killing,
And defeat comes swiftly—
This is a clear warning, how could one not be cautious!

**Master Héshànggōng (河上公) says:**
Thus the virtuous are resolute in their purpose—
Those who act virtuously should be resolute and daring.
They dare not rely on force to gain the name of strength.
Resolute yet not arrogant—
They should be resolute in humility, not boast of their own greatness.
Resolute yet not boastful—
They should be resolute in yielding, not claim credit for their achievements.
*Páo* (骄), means to *overbear or deceive*—
They should be resolute in not overbearing or deceiving others.

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
Thus the virtuous are resolute in their purpose—
They do not rely on force, yet use it for virtue,
And stopping the enemy is their resoluteness.
When bandits invade us,
We remove them—
This is not an endorsement of exclusive military might.
Resolute yet not arrogant,
Resolute yet not boastful,
Resolute yet not proud,
Resolute only when unavoidable—
Arrogance is self-aggrandizement,
Claiming credit is self-praise,
Unending desire for victory is *fèn* (忿, resentment),
And showing superiority to the enemy is *jiāo* (骄, pride).
Hence it is said:
*“Righteous armies reign, responding armies triumph,
Resentful armies perish, proud armies are annihilated.”*
The virtuous wielder of arms,
Is resolute and daring,
Not arrogant nor resentful,
Not greedy nor haughty—
When forced to act, they respond from behind,
Their righteousness lies in removing the enemy and saving people,
Not in relying on strength or delighting in war.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary (成疏):**
Thus the virtuous are resolute in their purpose—
*Guǒ* (果), means *firmly determined*.
*Yǐ* (已), means *to stop*.
It states that those who cultivate the Dao and are virtuous,
Firmly determine to halt this violent mindset and not use arms.

Secondly, it clarifies that those who use the Dao
Are resolute yet do not boast or claim credit—
This is resolute yet not forceful.

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
When the enemy invades and cannot be stopped,
Arms are used to halt them—
Thus their resoluteness lies in responding to the enemy,
Not in using force to prevail.

**Commentary of the Imperial Scholar (御疏):**
Those who are resolute in stopping the enemy,
Are not those who delight in victory and overbear others—
But when the enemy invades and there is no alternative,
Thus it is said: *“Resolute yet not by choice.”*
*Yǐ* (已), means *to stop*.
Using arms to respond to the enemy,
Is not to seek victory—
If one can do so, victory does not rely on force,
Hence it is said: *“Resolute yet not forceful.”*

**Master Héshànggōng (河上公) says:**
Resolute yet not by choice—
They should be resolute in sincerity, not in being forced.
This is resolute yet not forceful—
They should be resolute in not relying on strong armies or formidable armor to overbear others.

**Master Róng (荣) says:**
If one is firmly determined not to be haughty or arrogant,
And acts only when unavoidable,
This is resolute yet not forceful.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary (成疏):**
Resolute yet not by choice—
Like Yáo (尧) attacking the Mǐáo (有苗),
And Yǔ (禹) attacking the Xù (有扈),
These were unavoidable actions, not a delight in arms.
This is resolute yet not forceful—
The first two lines establish that one must firmly decide not to use force.
Thirdly, it clarifies that deliberate actions contrary to the Dao
Will surely lead to peril and destruction.

When things reach their peak of vigor, they grow old—
This is called *bùdào* (不道, contrary to the Dao),
And contrary to the Dao is early ruin.

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
When things are overused in their vigor,
It is due to relying on force in arms.
When things are overused, they decline—
When armies are too strong, they meet defeat,
This is contrary to the Dao,
And such actions must be stopped early.»

**Commentary of the Master (御疏):**
All things at their peak of vigor grow old,
And armies at their strongest meet defeat.
Thus, armies relying on strength
Are like things in their vigor—
Their vigor only hastens decline,
And strength in arms cannot fully ensure victory.
These two matters are called contrary to the Dao.
Wise ministers and enlightened rulers,
Knowing them to be contrary to the Dao,
Must cease such actions early—
Hence, *"contrary to the Dao is early ruin."*
*"Ruined"* is the same as *"stopped."*

**River Above Master (河上公) said:**
Things grow old when vigorous—
Grasses and trees, at their peak, wither and fall;
Humans, at their peak, decline and age.
This shows that the strong cannot endure long.
This is called contrary to the Dao—
Withering and aging come from not following the Dao.
*"Contrary to the Dao is early ruin"*—
Those who do not follow the Dao die early.

**Honor (荣) said:**
Young yet already overgrown,
Flourishing yet bound to decline—
This is *"things grow old when vigorous."*
It clarifies that armies, when strong,
Will meet defeat and grow weak—
Hence, it is not the Dao.
The Dao can be perpetually practiced,
But what is contrary to the Dao must be stopped early.

**Commentary of the Master (成疏):**
Things grow old when vigorous—
Heat at its extreme turns to cold—
This is the natural order.
Things grow old when vigorous—
This meaning is inevitable.
Called contrary to the Dao,
Contrary to the Dao is early ruin—
Things grow old when vigorous,
Armies grow weak when strong,
For they lack humility and gentleness,
Thus not the true Dao—
Hence, they must be halted and not pursued.

---
**Chapter 31: The Chapter on Excellent Arms (佳兵章)**
This chapter follows the previous one,
For though the prior chapter expounds on ceasing arms and practicing the Dao,
Its meaning regarding the Dao’s application remains incomplete.
Thus, this chapter clarifies:
When rectifying the times through the Dao,
One must rely on both *quan* (权, expedient means) and *shi* (实, true principle).

This chapter unfolds in four distinctions:
First, it clarifies that though armies may seek strength,
The Dao forbids such actions.
Second, it reveals how things respond to the times,
And the superiority or inferiority of the two intelligences (*quan* and *shi*).
Third, it shows that *quan* does not abandon *shi*,
And action does not depart from truth.
Fourth, it broadly outlines military laws,
To demonstrate the superiority of *shi*-intelligence.

**First: Though armies may seek strength, the Dao forbids it.**
Heaven’s Dao aids what is natural—
To oppose it brings misfortune.
Human affairs require tranquility—
Disturbance brings calamity.
In the age of the Three Sovereigns,
Pure transformation abandoned arms.
In the age of the Five Emperors,
Ceremonial deference discarded warfare.
From then onward, ruthless ambition arose—
Thus, Bai Qi led armies, deceitfully burying Zhao’s soldiers alive,
And Tian Dan commanded troops, crushing Yan’s city.
They could not harmonize with humanity,
Nor adapt to the times—
Their evil spread through generations,
Yet they sought personal security.
How could they know the Old Master’s hatred of cruel weapons?
Standing alone, self-guarded,
Silent on the left, he issued clear warnings to all,
Commanding them to avoid cruel weapons,
And thus earned great virtue!
Why resort to killing?

Excellent arms are instruments of ill omen.
Things naturally abhor them—
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not wield them.

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
*"Excellent"* means *"good."*
*"Arms"* refers to *"strategic schemes."*
All who cultivate speech and establish sincerity,
Unable to conceal their virtue with morality,
Instead take pride in military schemes and tactics—
For these schemes rely on conquest, slaughter, and destruction,
Making them instruments of evil.
Even things naturally abhor them—
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not involve themselves in such matters.

**Commentary of the Master (御疏):**
Excellent arms are instruments of ill omen—
*"Excellent"* means *"good,"*
*"Arms"* refers to *"strategic schemes."*
*"Ill omen"* means *"not good."*
*"Instruments"* are *"evil tools."*
The virtuous cultivate virtue and refine their conduct,
Must be cautious from the start,
Concealing their abilities within,
Acting only when the time is right,
Their minds wandering through the realms of morality,
Their thoughts exploring the forests of ancient wisdom,
So their brilliance shines and their deeds prosper.
Yet some take pride in military schemes and tactics as excellence.
For strategic schemes rely on deception—
*"The Book of Changes"* says, *"Oddness is the basis of the extraordinary,"*
And military writings emphasize *"striking first in sound, second in action,"*
All centered on conquest, slaughter, and destruction—
Thus, they are evil tools.
Things naturally abhor them—
Hence, those who follow the Dao do not involve themselves in such matters.
To cultivate virtue in oneself is the true endeavor.
Since these are instruments of ill omen,
Even things naturally abhor them—
How much more would the virtuous avoid them?
Thus, *"those who follow the Dao do not wield them."*

**River Above Master (河上公) said:**
Excellent arms are instruments of ill omen—
*"Ill omen"* means *"not good."*
Arms disturb the spirit and muddy the harmonious *qi*—
They are not tools for the virtuous and should not be adorned.
Things naturally abhor them—
For whenever arms are used, harm ensues,
Thus, all things abhor them.
Hence, those who follow the Dao do not wield them—
Those who follow the Dao do not rule such lands.

**Honor (荣) said:**
*"Excellent"* means *"ornamented,"*
*"Ill omen"* means *"not good."*
Arms, when used, bring ruin to states and loss of lives—
Thus, they are called *"not good."*
Life is what people cherish,
Death is what things abhor—
Death is what things abhor,
Thus, enlightened rulers do not take pride in arms.

**Commentary of the Master (成疏):**
Excellent arms are instruments of ill omen—
*"Excellent"* means *"ornate."*
*"Ill omen"* means *"not good."*
Though frost-laden spears gleam in the sun,
And jade-like blades shine in the sky—
These are tools of famine and disaster,
Not instruments of peace.
Internally, they dissolve the three poisons and six senses—
If one sharpens these senses yet clings to desires,
Such actions are evil.
Things naturally abhor them—
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not wield them.
All beings fear arms and abhor greed,
Thus, those who practice the Dao do not fix their minds on arms or desires.

---
**Second: Revealing how things respond to the times, and the superiority or inferiority of the two intelligences (*quan* and *shi*).**

The virtuous, at rest, value the left;
In war, they value the right.

**Commentary of the Master (御注):**
*"Left"* is *"yang."*
Yang harmonizes and brings forth life—
Thus, it is valued in peaceful times.
*"Right"* is *"yin."*
Yin congeals and brings severity—
Thus, it is valued in war.

「Yang favors life, yin favors death.
Favoring life, thus it is prized in times of peace.
Favoring death, thus it is prized in war.
○ Master of the Yellow River (河上公) says:
In peace, the virtuous prize the left—
the gentle and weak.
In war, they prize the right—
the strong and resolute.
This states that the Way of arms and the Way of the virtuous are opposed,
yet their prized qualities differ.

○ Yan (严) says:
The virtuous are rulers of the land,
and prizing the left means valuing growth and nurturing.

○ Rong (荣) says:
The *Classic of Heavenly Patterns* (经天) speaks of *wen* (文) as peace,
and *wu* (武) as martial.
Though their uses are equal in essence,
rites and music must both be practiced,
and water and fire must be managed with difficulty.
War must be waged with reason,
action must follow the proper time—
thus, in peace, favoring life takes precedence,
and in war, the right is prized.

○ Master Cheng’s Commentary (成疏):
Those who possess the virtue of a ruler are called *junzi* (君子).
The left field is auspicious, favoring life and prosperity.
The right field is ominous, favoring death and severity.
It says that in times of peace, the *junzi* prizes the left and uses *wen* (文),
while in chaotic times, they prize the right and use *wu* (武).
This illustrates that true wisdom values longevity,
while expedient wisdom acts at times with severity—
thus the *Sutra on Guiding Sentient Beings* (度人经) says:
"Thousands upon thousands behead, tens of thousands dismember."
Arms are an ill-omened instrument,
○ Master’s Annotation (御注): *Ill-omened* means *not virtuous* (不善).
Those who favor arms uphold severity—
thus they are not virtuous material.
○ Master’s Exegesis (御疏):
Arms are ill-omened instruments,
not the tools of the *junzi*.
The earlier text states that fine arms are ill-omened instruments,
for when war is waged, one upholds the right and favors severity—
thus those who follow the Dao do not employ them.
This text says that arms are ill-omened instruments,
corresponding with the earlier passage to clarify that they are not the *junzi*’s tools.
The *junzi* uses virtue and the Dao as their instruments—
thus nothing can harm them.

○ Master of the Yellow River says:
Arms are not virtuous instruments.
○ Rong says:
Arms are ill-omened instruments,
not the tools of the *junzi*.
Though arms may be used,
they often cause injury—
this is the domain of claws and teeth,
not the ruler’s proper function.
○ Master Cheng’s Commentary:
Arms are ill-omened instruments,
not the tools of the *junzi*.
When used unavoidably,
they serve as a last resort—
thus the earlier text reiterates that arms are ill-omened,
not the tools of virtuous ones.
They must be employed only to subdue the wicked and aid the distressed,
used unavoidably—
expedient wisdom is the same.
To make arms the primary instrument,
is to wield a yin-strong axe that harms one’s own body—
thus they are called ill-omened instruments.
Not the tools of the *junzi*.
○ Master’s Annotation:
The *junzi* uses virtue and the Dao as their instruments—
they do not prize the schemes of arms.

○ Master of the Yellow River says:
They are not instruments the *junzi* should rely upon.

**Third: Demonstrating that expedient wisdom does not abandon true wisdom, and responses do not stray from authenticity.**
When unavoidable, use them—
yet tranquility is supreme.

○ Master’s Annotation:
When the *Rongdi* (戎狄) invade internally,
one must act unavoidably.
The virtuous conquer without contention—
thus tranquility is supreme.

○ Master’s Exegesis:
The virtue of *wen* (文) is the instrument of governance.
Arms are its auxiliary.
Thus it is said that *wen* governs like the threads of heaven and earth,
while *wu* (武) subdues calamities and chaos.
Though heaven produces five materials,
discarding one is impossible—
yet martial prowess must be tempered with restraint,
and moderation preserved.
Thus, the proper use of arms has its roots and branches,
its order and disorder—
all depend on circumstances.
When unavoidable, one responds—
meaning when the four quarters invade,
and the royal armies engage in battle,
one must still show them mercy,
and temper actions with virtue and the Dao.
Though one may repel like a mosquito stinging,
one should not lean on wrathful intent.
From this perspective,
tranquility is supreme.

○ Master of the Yellow River says:
Tranquility is supreme—
not greedily coveting land or wealth for others.

○ Rong says:
Tranquility is stillness—
the king deploys troops,
but only when called to defend,
never for reckless warfare.
Action does not lose stillness—
thus it is called tranquility.
They do not take pleasure in using arms.

○ Master Cheng’s Commentary:
Tranquility is non-action—
the *junzi*’s heart is also non-action,
so though arms are used,
they are not deemed beautiful.
This illustrates that practitioners, though employing expedient wisdom,
still hold true wisdom supreme—
responses do not stray from authenticity.
Victory is not beautiful.
Those who find beauty in victory,
are those who delight in killing.
But those who delight in killing,
cannot achieve their ambitions in the world.

○ Master’s Annotation:
To conquer an enemy,
one must pity them—
thus victory is not deemed beautiful.
Though victory brings many deaths,
if one takes victory as beautiful,
then one delights in killing many.
Delighting in killing many,
people will not follow.
To seek worldly ambition,
is it not difficult?
○ Master’s Exegesis:
Victory is not beautiful,
yet those who find beauty in it
are those who delight in killing.
Unable to embrace others with virtue,
they rely on arms to seek victory—
though they may triumph,
they still feel shame at their lack of virtue.
Victory must bring many deaths,
so those who take victory as beautiful
are those who enjoy killing.
Those who delight in killing,
cannot achieve their ambitions in the world.
The ruler is the parent of the people—
to find beauty in arms and killing
is not to nurture them.

○ Master Cheng’s Commentary:
Victory is not beautiful,
yet those who find beauty in it
are those who delight in killing.
The ruler, who delights in killing,
cannot achieve their ambitions in the world.
A ruler must not arbitrarily take lives—
they must not impose punishments recklessly.

○ Rong says:
The ruler is the parent of the people—
finding beauty in arms and killing
is not to nurture them.

「○ Master Cheng’s Commentary:
If one finds beauty in victory,
they will delight in killing.
If one finds beauty in fine arms,
then they love to wield the sword and spear.

To delight in killing—
this is what all under heaven detest.
With many slain in battle,
they cannot achieve their true ambitions.

The fourth passage broadly cites military laws
to illustrate the Daoist principle of **real wisdom’s victory**—
auspicious matters are placed on the left,
inauspicious matters on the right.
The **Viceroy-General** stands on the left,
the **Supreme-General** on the right.

○ **Imperial Commentary:**
The Viceroy-General is of lower rank,
placed on the left because they do not hold sole authority over killing.
The Supreme-General’s exalted status
places them on the right, as they command military strategy.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Auspicious matters are placed on the left,
inaspicious matters on the right—
the left embodies the **Yang Principle**, the source of life, hence auspicious.
The right embodies the **Yin Principle**, the path of killing, hence inauspicious.
*The Record of Rites (Liji) – Tan Gong* states:
When the Master stood with his disciples,
he bowed and took the rightmost position.
The disciples also took the rightmost position.
The Master said:
“My disciples’ zeal for learning
is but as my sorrow for my sister’s death.”
The disciples then took the leftmost position.

The Viceroy-General stands on the left,
the Supreme-General on the right—
this is to liken military command to funeral rites.
The Supreme-General, placed on the right,
holds sole authority over killing,
while the Viceroy-General, as deputy,
does not command life and death,
thus standing on the left.

Now, the left is exalted,
the right is lowly—
the Supreme-General, though now placed on the right,
is likened to the funeral rites’ position,
for though they command killing,
they are treated with the solemnity of death.
○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The left is the auspicious position,
the right is the funeral position.
Now, the Viceroy-General, of lesser rank,
stands on the left,
while the Supreme-General,
of greater rank, stands on the right—
this is to clarify that even if they command killing,
they are placed with the rites of death and mourning.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The funeral rites place the position on the right,
and now the Supreme-General stands on the right—
this is to liken them to the rites of death.
The departed are honored with **Yin**,
and killing many in battle
is met with tears of sorrow and lamentation.
○ **Imperial Commentary:**
Because life is precious yet must be sacrificed in war,
there is a compassionate and benevolent heart
that mourns the loss,
and this is fitting.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
To wage war and seek victory
must inevitably bring many deaths.
Victory is not beautiful,
so the Supreme-General mourns in sorrow and lamentation.
The people are the foundation of the state—
if they are secure, the state is at peace.
Now, in battle, many are slain,
so the benevolent heart feels sorrow and pity,
and this is indeed appropriate.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
This reflects the fear that one’s own **virtue/power** is thin,
unable to transform the people through the Dao,
and thus harming the innocent.

○ **Master Rong’s Commentary:**
The purpose of arms is to uphold justice
and rescue the people.
To mourn is to lament their straying from the Dao,
to sorrow is to regret the harm done.
In ancient times, the use of arms was guided by **compassion (慈)**,
and military affairs were valued by **virtue/power (德)**,
not by weapons alone.
After defeating the enemy,
the Supreme-General wore plain attire
and took charge of the funeral rites,
accepting condolences as part of the ceremony.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Wherever arms are used,
slaughter and harm abound.
Thus the Supreme-General mourns,
pitying the loss of life,
fearing that the Dao was not followed
and that the innocent may be harmed.

Victory in battle is treated with funeral rites—
the Supreme-General, though placed on the right,
is likened to the rites of death.
The right is exalted for the living,
yet now the Supreme-General stands on the right—
this is because war is an **unauspicious instrument**,
so they are honored with mourning attire,
though it is not truly a funeral rite.
○ **Imperial Commentary:**
When a warrior gains victory in battle,
they receive their title and stand on the right—
a position not auspicious,
hence it is likened to funeral rites.
But war is merely an **unauspicious instrument**,
so why must they don mourning robes
and use a staff of office
before it can be called funeral rites?
All commentaries on this meaning
claim that such a custom existed in antiquity,
but upon examining the ancient texts,
there is no evidence to support it.
The present interpretation is unsettling,
so it is omitted.

Again, citing the case of Qin Bo weeping before his defeated teacher—
this was lamentation for defeat,
not for victory in battle.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
In ancient times,
when victory was achieved,
the Supreme-General would take the funeral master’s position,
wearing plain attire and mourning,
to show that the **gentleman values virtue/power (德) over arms (兵)**,
and killing is only done when unavoidable.
Their reluctance toward killing
is likened to the sorrow of mourning.

Knowing that later ages would not cease from using arms,
they mourned in sorrow and grief.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
The **gentleman** and the **good person** value the use of the Dao.
When forced to resort to arms,
they do so only out of necessity.
Though they may defeat the enemy,
they do not take it as a good thing,
so they wear plain attire and mourn,
and still observe funeral rites in burial.

Though their martial prowess surpasses their literary skill,
this shows that **strategic expedience (权)** is inferior to **true wisdom (实)**.
In governing the state,
one must resort to arms when necessary,
and to **strategic expedience** when unavoidable.
By this measure,
it is clear that **strategic expedience is weaker than true wisdom**,
and that **martial force is lesser than virtue/power**.

**End of the *Zhuangzi* – *Xuan De* (玄德) Commentary, Volume Eight.**
**Begin of the *Zhuangzi* – *Xuan De* (玄德) Commentary, Volume Nine.**»

「Emperor Xuanzong’s Imperial Commentary and Exegesis
*Commentaries by Master He Shang, Lord Yan Junping, and Li Rong*
*Exegesis by Master Xihua, Fa Xuan Ying, and Master Qiang Si of Mengyang*

**Chapter Thirty-Two: Dao Constantly Without Name**

The reason this chapter follows the previous is that the prior chapter illustrates that "good arms are not auspicious," hence one with the Dao does not dwell in them. This chapter demonstrates that if a sovereign and king upholds the Dao, then all things will naturally submit to them.

This chapter is divided into four parts within itself:
The first marks the "Nameless One" to elucidate the Dao,
the second cites the sovereign who upholds the Dao and thereby attracts blessings,
the third introduces the creation of named things and expands their applications,
and the fourth concludes with the Dao descending to the "Nameless One."

**First: Marking the "Nameless One" to Elucidate the Dao.**

The most profound Dao, the true essence of the Way,
is the precious *Zhenjing* of the Supreme Official.
Its source is unfathomable, its nature serene and undisturbed—
length and brevity are equalized,
so that the morning mushroom and the ancient tree share the same lifespan;
foolishness and wisdom are unified,
so that the mythical *Tao* and *Liang* creatures merge into the dual *Zhuang* and *Yuan*.

From the root to the branches, all distinctions dissolve,
unified in speech yet divided in form,
encompassing all phenomena yet returning to the True.
Across the three lives, purity is complete—
names vanish, dust and hues dissolve,
and the transformation manifests:
the white deer appears at *Ren’an*,
