*loyalty* and *truthfulness* grow thin and weak.
And *rites* are the beginning of chaos,
for they value superficial appearances over substance,
thus the upright grow fewer,
while deceit and disorder multiply.

○荣曰：
*"Honor"* says:
When people are all earnest and sincere,
each holding *loyalty* and *truthfulness* in their hearts,
there is no need for elaborate *rites*.
But when *loyalty* and *truthfulness* have already thinned,
and the *wind of excess* has thickened,
confusion and disorder have spread even more—
using *rites* to govern them,
valuing outward forms over substance,
only increases deceit and disorder—
thus, they are said to be the beginning of chaos.

○成疏：
*"The Commentary of Cheng"* says:
Those who merely display outward forms of ceremony
have not yet attained sincerity from the heart.
Since they are not thick with genuine *loyalty* and *truthfulness*,
they only serve to thin the essence of sincerity.
They do not curb the roots of superficiality and deceit,
but instead provide the means for greater confusion and disorder.
Thus, the wise person who perceives this beforehand
knows that *rites* are the *flower* of the *Dao*,
and the beginning of folly.

○御注：
*"The Imperial Commentary"* notes:
*"Perceiving beforehand"* (前识者) refers to human nature and understanding,
meaning that those who establish these outward *rites*
before cultivating the inner nature of humanity
may seem to conform to the times,
but in reality, they abandon simplicity and purity—
thus, they are the *flower* of the *Dao*.

When *rites* are used to prevent chaos,
the most valuable thing is harmony and unity,
but those who practice *rites* without understanding their true intent
will only emphasize the jade and silk,
and value bowing and kneeling—
such people are the beginning of folly.

○御疏：
*"The Imperial Exegesis"* says:
*"Perceiving beforehand"* refers to those who establish *rites*.
It means that those who establish *rites* beforehand
do so before cultivating the inner nature of humanity.
The *Dao* follows human nature,
while *rites* preserve outward appearances—
this is why such a *Dao* is contrary to natural simplicity,
and thus is called the *flower* of the *Dao*.
Yet it is the beginning of folly,
for though *rites* are meant to pacify chaos,
they arise from chaos itself—
the ideal is to restore harmony,
but those who practice *rites* in this age
do not focus on the inner nature of humanity,
but only on outward forms.
When reverence and love are insufficient,
and ceremonial offerings are excessive—
this is not the vision of the enlightened,
but truly the beginning of folly.

○河上公曰：
*"Master He Shang Gong"* says:
*"Perceiving beforehand"* are the *flower* of the *Dao*,
for they claim to know without truly understanding—
this is what is meant by "perceiving beforehand."
Such people have lost the true *Dao*,
yet they possess its superficial *flower*—
and they are the beginning of folly,
for those who perceive beforehand
are the first to sing the praises of folly and darkness.

○荣曰：
*"Honor"* says:
*Virtue* and *power* are the true *Dao*,
while *benevolence* and *righteousness* are its *flower*.
Those who first recognize *benevolence* and *righteousness*
know only the *flower*, not the true essence.
The enlightened naturally align with *Dao*’s principles,
while the ignorant rely on teachings and guidance.
Recognizing *rites* is not the foundation of superior wisdom,
but the beginning of folly.

○成疏：
*"The Commentary of Cheng"* says:
To claim knowledge while knowing nothing
is called "perceiving beforehand."
It states that such people,
when cultivating the *Dao* and practicing its ways,
are deeply immersed in superficiality and artifice.
They are not the source of great wisdom,
but the beginning of ignorance and folly.

Thus, the *Great Man* abides in the *thick* and not the *thin*,
dwells in the *real* and not the *flower*.
○御注：
*"The Imperial Commentary"* notes:
The *thick* refers to those who engage in *action*—
the *Dao*’s *thick* aspect.
*Rites* and *righteousness* are the *flower* of *virtue*.
Hence, the Sage abides in the *Dao*’s inaction,
dwelling in the *thick*—
not in the *thin*.
He withdraws from the practice of *rites* and *righteousness*,
not dwelling in the *flower*—
but abiding in the *real*.

○御疏：
*"The Imperial Exegesis"* says:
The *Great Man* refers to the *Dao*-attained gentleman,
the same as the earlier *upper virtue* ruler.
*Virtue* and *power* are without *action*,
called the *thick* and *real*—
while *rites* and *righteousness* involve *action*,
called the *thin* and *flower*.
It says that the Sage first practices the transformation of *virtue* and *power*,
thus dwelling in the *thick* and *real*—
and later, the teachings of *rites* and *righteousness*,
thus not dwelling in the *thin* and *flower*.

○河上公曰：
*"Master He Shang Gong"* says:
Thus, the *Great Man* abides in the *thick*—
the *Great Man* refers to the *Dao*-attained ruler,
abiding in the *thick* means his body is sincere and pure.

「Not abiding in its thinness—
he does not act contrary to the Dao/Way in his body,
nor does he trouble the world with strife.

Abiding in its real—
he abides in *loyalty* and *trustworthiness*.

Not dwelling in its flower—
he does not indulge in empty, superficial words.

○ *Master Rong* says:
Thus, the *Great Man* abides in the *thick*—
not in its thinness,
dwells in its real—
not in its flower,
hence the saying: *forsake that and take this*.

*Dispersing* the *unadorned* to make *vessels*—
this is tracing its origin to the most *pure* and *unadorned*.
*Losing* the Dao/Way, then *virtue/power*—
this is its ultimate fate: *dissipated* and *thin*.

Thus, *benevolence* is not innate,
*righteousness* is not natural,
*trustworthiness* does not arise from sincerity,
*rites* are mere external adornment.
Discernment of *right* and *wrong*, warfare, deceit, and intricate cleverness abound—
fathers and sons lose the heart of *filial piety*,
rulers and ministers stray from the *loyalty* and *righteousness* of the Dao/Way.
Hence, the *Great Sage* *Laozi* lamented the great errors of the age,
pitied the decline of the *Dao/Way*,
desiring to suppress the superficial and exalt the fundamental,
to quiet the dissipated and return to the *pure*.

Thus, when the *Great Man* governs the nation and manages the household,
cultivates his person and establishes conduct,
he must take this *thick* and *real* of Dao/Way and *virtue/power*,
forsake that *flower* of *benevolence* and *righteousness*—
then he abandons the *customary rites*,
and returns to the *true Dao/Way*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis says:
Thus, the *Great Man* abides in the *thick*—
not in its thinness.
*Zhang* (丈), meaning *long*—
*Fu* (夫), meaning *support*.
It is one who possesses the courage, compassion, and wisdom to *save* and *uphold*,
capable of being the *leader* among all *creatures*,
to support and protect the *masses*.

His aspirations are vast and universal,
hence he is called the *Great Man*.
The *Great Man* should cherish the *thick* and *real* of Dao/Way and *virtue/power*,
how could he dwell in the *thin* and *flower* of *rites* and *righteousness*?
Abiding in its real—
not in its flower—
the *Dao*-attained person, the *unworldly* recluse,
should retain his *emotions* in the *pure* and *unadorned* real,
how could he fix his *mind* on the *superficial* and *flowery*?
Hence, *forsake that and take this*.

*Imperial Annotation*: Forsake that *flower* and thinness, take this *pure* and *thick*.
○ *Imperial Exegesis*: *That* refers to *rites* and *righteousness*,
*this* refers to Dao/Way and *virtue/power*.
The Sage abandons the *floating* and *flowery* of *rites* and *righteousness*,
takes the *thick* and *real* of Dao/Way and *virtue/power*,
hence the saying: *forsake that and take this*.
Yet, *firmly* discussing the Sage’s hundred deliberations converging into one,
both *boundaries* are extinguished—
how could there be *that* and *this* to forsake or take?
The teachings are set forth to guide the *common* and *ordinary*—
thus it is said.

○ *Master He Shang Gong* says:
Forsake that *flower* and thinness, take this *thick* and *real*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis says:
Forsake that *flower* and thinness—
this is to utterly reject *benevolence* and abandon *righteousness*.
Take this *real* and *thick*—
this is to return to the *unadorned* and restore the *pure*.
Moreover, the *upper virtue* Sage has no *distinctions*,
how could he have a *mind* on *that* and *this*,
or *emotions* bound to *forsaking* and *taking*?
It is only made clear that though he *forsakes*, he does not truly forsake,
though he *takes*, he does not truly take—
not the *forsaking* of *forsaking*,
nor the *taking* of *taking*.
Since *forsaking* and *taking* are thus,
*that* and *this* are also thus.

*Formerly, those who attained the One*—
Chapter Thirty-Nine
*Formerly* refers to the second major section,
while the first chapter expounds broadly on *virtue/power* and *righteousness*,
and within this chapter, *righteousness* is divided into three parts:
First, it demonstrates the efficacy of attaining the One,
Second, it reveals the harm of losing the One,
Third, it clarifies the Dao/Way’s *humility* and *modesty*,
concluding the meaning of attaining the One.

First, it demonstrates the efficacy of attaining the One.

From the *initial division* of the *One qi*,
the *Great Sky* and *Earth* established the *Two Principles*,
the *Three Realms* began their positions,
and *kings* and *lords* were honored as the *exalted* of the *ten thousand nations*.
Having both *clear* and *clouded* sources,
they also grasp the *potter’s wheel*—
the *beginning* is unseen,
*Emperor Han Wen* thus lost his way,
the *end* is unperceived,
*Master He Shang Gong* then revealed the *cover*.
*Mysterious* and *obscure*, yet *generous* and *lending*,
all *things* are enriched and *resources* abound—
*grains* attain *fullness*,
*kings* attain *nobility*,
thus it is known that the *unification* of *mysterious* and *pure* is the *wondrous* origin,
*mingling* the *Three Realms* and defying thought,
*obscure* yet the *true* *principle*,
penetrating the *Nine Heavens* and unfathomable,
the *logic* of *spontaneous* *wonder*—
its essence lies here.

*Formerly, those who attained the One*—
*Imperial Annotation*: The *One* is the *harmony* of the Dao/Way,
also called the *unifying qi*.
It is called the *One* because its *wondrous* *function* lies in *things* as a unified whole,
ancient and modern, without distinction—
this is called the *One*.
Hence, the *Book of Changes·Appendices* says:
*The interplay of one yin and one yang is called the Dao/Way*—
it is made clear that the Dao/Way’s *qi* in *yin* unifies with *yin*,
and in *yang* unifies with *yang*.
It says *formerly those who attained*—
they sought to trace the *origin* and grasp the *end*,
to suppress the superficial and return to the fundamental.
Thus, they cite *formerly attained* to confirm *now attained*,
the *number* of those attaining the One is as follows:

○ *Master He Shang Gong* says:
*Formerly* (昔), meaning *past*—
*One* (一), meaning *non-action*—
the *child* of the Dao/Way.

○ *Master Yan* says:
The *One* is the *child* of the Dao/Way,
in *spirit* it is *non-existent*,
in the Dao/Way it is *existent*—
the *primordial* of *primordials*,
the *beginning* of *beginnings*,
*verdant* and *solitary*,
*profound* and *wondrous*—
the *key* to *transformation*.

○ *Master Rong* says:
*Formerly, those who attained the One*—
the *Sky* attains the *One* and becomes *clear*,
the *Earth* attains the *One* and becomes *tranquil*,
the *spirit* attains the *One* and becomes *responsive*,
*grains* attain the *One* and become *full*,
the *ten thousand things* attain the *One* and come to *life*,
*lords* and *kings* attain the *One* to become the *correct* of the *world*.
The *One* is *primordial qi*,
undivided and without duality—
hence it is called the *One*.
Though *Sky* and *Earth* are vast,
what they receive is the *primordial One*,
though the *ten thousand things* are abundant,
what they rely on is the *unifying qi*.
Though *lords* and *kings* are noble,
what they depend on is the *true Dao/Way*.
Thus, the *clear* and *pure* are vast in *covering*,
the *tranquil* and *still* are thick in *bearing*,
*transformation* and *change* are *precise* and *responsive*,
*emptiness* and *openness* are *full* and *satisfied*,
*peace* and *contentment* are complete in *life*,
*non-action* yet *correct* and *fixed*—
how is this achieved?
All attain the *One* from the Dao/Way.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis says:
*Formerly* (昔), meaning *ancient*—
*One* (一), meaning the Dao/Way.
It speaks of the *beginning* of past *kalpas*,
the *state* of those who attained the Dao/Way,
all of which are listed in the following text—
this is to *verify* the present and *cite* the ancient.
The *Sky* attains the *One* and becomes *clear*—
*Imperial Annotation*: Among the *phenomena* of *qi*,
none surpass the *Great Sky*—
its *covering* is *vast* and *broad*.
○ *Imperial Exegesis*: The *phenomenon* of *qi* most grand,
none grander than the *Great Sky*—
hence it first marks the *One* attained by the *Sky*.」

The *pure yang* *qi* arises from attaining the *One*—
thus it can *cover* and *broadly* *ascend* the *Sky*,
and *nourish* the *beginning* of all things.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
The *Sky* attains the *One*—
thus it can *hang* the *phenomena* in *clear* radiance.
The *Earth* attains the *One*—
thus it can be *stable* and *unmoving*, never *shaken*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
*Receiving* the *Dao/Way*’s *radiance*,
*accumulating* *yang* to form the *Sky*,
*clear* and *floating* above.
The *Earth* attains the *One* and becomes *tranquil*—

○ *Imperial Annotation*:
Among the *forms* and *substances*,
none surpass the *Great Earth*—
*pure yin*’s *substance*,
from attaining the *One* it can be *massive* and *solid*,
*broadly* *bearing* all things,
and *nourish* the *beginning* of life.

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
Among the *forms* and *substances*,
none greater than the *Great Earth*—
*pure yin*’s *substance*,
from attaining the *One* it can be *massive* and *solid*,
*broadly* *bearing* all things,
and *nourish* the *beginning* of life.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
*All* *receiving* the *One Dao/Way*,
thus *congealing* *yin* to form the *Earth*,
*tranquil* and *stable* below.

The *Spirit* attains the *One* and becomes *wondrous*—

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
The *Spirit*—
this refers to the *marvelous* *transformations* of all things.
From attaining the *One*, it can *pervade* *changes* without *bound*,
and cannot be *traced* or *constrained* by form.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
The *Spirit* attains the *One*—
thus it can *change* and *transform* without form.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
The *Dao/Way* of the *Spirit* dwells in *yin*,
in *dark* and *dim* realms beyond measure.
From its attaining the *One*,
it knows *wondrous* things without limit—
as the *Zhuangzi* says:
*"The Spirit of ghosts and gods, the Spirit of the Sovereign and the Dao/Way,
give birth to the *Sky* and the *Earth*."*

The *Valleys* attain the *One* and become *full*—

○ *Imperial Annotation*:
The *Valleys* attain the *One* and become *full*—
all things attain the *One* and thus *come to life*.
Things refer to *all* that is *moving* or *still*,
*sentient* or *insentient*—
their *movement* and *growth* never *exhaust*.

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
Water flowing into rivers becomes the *Han*,
flowing into streams becomes the *Valleys*—
from attaining the *One*, it can *well* and *spring*,
*flowing* and *moistening*, *full* yet never *exhausted*.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
The *Valleys* attain the *One*—
thus they can be *full* and *never* *cut off*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
The *Valleys*—
these are the *vales* of rivers.
It states that the *Valleys*, from attaining the *One*,
can *well* and *spring*, *flowing* and *moistening*,
while *streams* and *ravines* become *full*.

All things attain the *One* and thus *come to life*—

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
Things refer to *all* that is *moving* or *still*,
*sentient* or *insentient*—
collectively called *things*.
From attaining the *One*’s *unrestrained* *qi*,
they can *come to life* and *move* without *ceasing* or *perishing*.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
All things *must* rely on the *Dao/Way* to *come to life*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
*Sentient* yet *insentient*—
all are called *things*.
*All* *receiving* the *One Dao/Way*,
thus they attain *life* and *formation*.

The *Lords and Kings* attain the *One*—
and thus *establish* *correctness* for all under *Heaven*.

○ *Imperial Annotation*:
The *Lords and Kings* attain the *One* to *establish* *correctness* for all under *Heaven*—
this is how they *achieve* it:
things attain the *Dao/Way* and *use* it,
and *names* are *established* by *use*.
When the *Dao/Way* *exists*, *names* are *established*;
when *use* is *lost*, *reality* is *forfeited*.
Thus, the *Sky* is *clear*, the *Earth* is *tranquil*,
the *Spirit* is *wondrous*, the *Valleys* are *full*,
and all things *come to life*—
all rely on the *marvelous* *use* of the *Dao/Way*
to *govern* thus.
Hence it says, *"this is how they achieve it."*

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
The *Lords and Kings*—
these are the *rulers* of men.
The *Lords* hold the *five ranks* of *nobility*,
the *Kings* command the *ten thousand chariots*.
It states that the *Lords and Kings*, from attaining the *One*,
can *permanently* possess the *Heavenly Mandate*,
so that *none* *resist* them,
and they *establish* *correctness* and *equity* under *Heaven*.

*"Correct"* can also be read as *"veritable"*—
*veritable* is the same as *correct*.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
The *Lords and Kings* attain the *One*—
thus they can *establish* *equity* and *correctness* under *Heaven*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
The *Emperor*, *King*, *Duke*, *Marquis*, and *Earl*—
none fail to *receive* the *transformations*.
Only by *non-action* do they attain the *One*,
and thus *spread* *correctness* under *Heaven*.
*Yu the Great* and *Shun* are examples of this.

*"This is how they achieve it."*

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
This *summarizes* the *meaning* of the prior *six* and *leads* to what follows.
*"Achieve"* means *"attain"*—
it asks: how does the *Sky* attain *clarity*,
the *Earth* attain *tranquility*,
the *Spirit* attain *wondrousness*,
the *Valleys* attain *fullness*,
all things attain *life* and *formation*,
and the *Lords and Kings* attain *correctness* and *equity*?
It is all from the *marvelous* *use* of the *Dao/Way*.
This *illustrates* that attaining the *Dao/Way* brings *benefit*.

The following text *warns* of the *harm* of losing the *One*.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
*"Govern"* means *"test"*—
this refers to the *six* matters below.

○ *Rong* says:
The *Dao/Way* has no *rise* or *fall*,
but *things* have *attainment* or *loss*.
Those who *attain* it *benefit*—
as in the prior text.
Those who *lose* it *suffer*—
as in what follows.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
*"Govern"* means *"attain"*—
it *connects* the prior *six*,
all of which *attain* the *One Dao/Way*.
If taken as an *internal* interpretation—
then it refers to *six* kinds of *conduct* within a single person.

The second section *reveals* the *disadvantages* of losing the *One*,
showing that it *must* bring *harm*.

The *Sky* without *clarity* would fear *rupture*—

○ *Imperial Annotation*:
This is the *language* of *warning* and *admonition*.

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
*"Without"* is the *language* of *sincerity*.
*"Use"* means *employ*.
Those who *cling* to *preservation* will *lose* it,
and those who *fixate* on *attainment* will *forfeit* it.
It states that the *Sky*, from attaining the *Dao/Way*’s *unrestrained* *qi*,
becomes *clear* and *floating*.
If it does not *guard* the *Dao/Way*’s *harmony* and *gentleness*,
but *fixates* on *using* its *clarity*,
then it would fear *breaking* and *scattering*,
and the *phenomena* would not *form*.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
The *Sky* must have *yin* and *yang* *alternating*,
*day* and *night* *replacing* each other in *function*—
it cannot be that one *only* desires *clear* radiance without end,
or it would fear *splitting* and *not* becoming the *Sky*.

○ *Rong* says:
The *Sky* without *clarity* would fear *rupture*,
the *Earth* without *tranquility* would fear *disturbance*,
the *Spirit* without *wondrousness* would fear *cessation*,
the *Valleys* without *fullness* would fear *exhaustion*,
all things without *life* would fear *perishing*,
and the *Lords and Kings* without *high* and *noble* *virtue* would fear *overthrow*.
The *true One Dao/Way* must not be *lost*.

*"Losing"* it leads to *phenomena* forming—
but fear *rupture* when they *break*.
*"Forming"* leads to fear *disturbance* and *movement*,
and when *unmeasurable* things are feared,
they would fear *cessation* and *extinction*.
The *void* and *intervals* would fear *drying up* and *exhaustion*,
*life* and *wondrousness* would fear *death* and *perishing*,
and *high* and *noble* *virtue* would fear *overthrow*.

○ *Master Cheng*’s Exegesis:
*"Use"* means *employ*.
*"Without"* means *not*.
*"Rupture"* means *destruction*.
It states that if the *Sky* does not *employ* the *Dao/Way*’s *clear* and *void* nature,
then the *sun* and *moon* will *flourish* and *eclipse*,
the *stars* will *lose* their *degrees*,
and *disasters* and *changes* will *frequently* *manifest*—
fearing that it would *reach* *destruction*.

The *Earth* without *tranquility* would fear *disturbance*—

○ *Imperial Annotation*:
*Admonishing* it to *not cling* to its *use*.

○ *Imperial Exegesis*:
It states that the *Earth*, from attaining the *Dao/Way*’s *use*,
*governs* with *tranquility*.
It must *forget* its *tranquility*—
if one *fixates* on *using* its *tranquility*,
it would fear *reaching* *disturbance* and *overflow*,
and the *form* would not *establish*.

○ *Master He Shang* says:
The *Earth* must have *high* and *low*,
*firm* and *yielding*,
*seasonal* *qi* and *Five Phases*—
it cannot be that one *only* desires *stability* without end,
or it would fear *disturbance* and *overflow*,
and *not* become the *Earth*.

○ **Master Cheng’s Exegesis**:
*Fā* means *dynamic transformation*.
It says that the *Earth*, if it cannot *apply* the *Dao/Way*’s *tranquility*,
would fear *catastrophes* of *collapse* and *ruin*.
In ancient times, the *Qí Shān* collapsed, causing the *Three Rivers* to tremble—this is an example.

The *Spirit* without *manifestation* would fear *cessation*,
○ **Imperial Annotation**:
*Admonishing* the *Spirit* to *not cling* to its *use*,
lest it *fail* to *wondrously* *apply* itself.

○ **Imperial Exegesis**:
It states that the *Spirit*, having attained the *Dao/Way*’s *use*,
can *manifest* *wondrously* without measure.
It must *forget* its *precision* and *verve*—
if one *fixates* on *using* its *manifestation*,
it would fear *reaching* *exhaustion* and *cessation*,
and *not* *wondrously* *apply* itself.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng** says:
The *Spirit* must have *sovereignty* and *ministerial* *roles*,
*prisonment*, *death*, *rest*, and *abandonment*—
it cannot be that one *only* desires *verve* without end,
or it would fear *emptiness* and *cessation*,
and *not* become the *Spirit*.

○ **Master Cheng’s Exegesis**:
*Xiē* means *abandonment*.
The *Spirit*, if it does not *depend* on the *Dao*,
would fear its *wisdom* *applied* becoming *foolish* and *faltering*—
once it lacks *precision* and *efficacy*,
it would fear *abandonment* and *cessation*.

The *Valley* without *fullness* would fear *exhaustion*—
○ **Imperial Annotation**:
*Admonishing* it to *not cling* to its *satisfaction* with *fullness*.

○ **Imperial Exegesis**:
It states that the *Valley*, having attained the *Dao/Way*’s *use*,
can *receive* *emptily*—
it must *forget* its *fullness* and *satisfaction*,
for if one *fixates* on *using* its *fullness*,
it would fear *reaching* *dryness* and *exhaustion*,
and *not* become *flowing* and *moistening*.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng** says:
The *Valley* must have *fullness* and *contraction*,
*emptiness* and *reality*—
it cannot be that one *only* desires *fullness* without end,
or it would fear *dryness* and *exhaustion*,
and *not* become the *Valley*.

○ **Master Cheng’s Exegesis**:
*Jié* means *blockage*.
It says that when *Rivers* and *Valleys* *deviate* from *unity*,
*calamities* and *disasters* arise,
leading to *springs* and *sources* *drying* up,
and *channels* *not flowing*.

All *things* without *means* of *generation* would fear *extinction*—
○ **Imperial Annotation**:
*Admonishing* them to *not cling* to their *useful* *generation*.

○ **Imperial Exegesis**:
It says that all things, when they attain the *Dao* and its *use*,
and are able to *generate* and *nourish*,
must *forget* their *generation*—
if they *fixate* upon it and *cling* to it,
they would fear *falling* into *death* and *extinction*,
and *not* become *living* and *sentient*.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng** says:
All things must *follow* the *times* of *death* and *birth*;
they cannot *always* be *born*—
if they *only* desire *constant* *birth*,
they would fear *extinction* and *not* become *things*.

○ **Master Cheng’s Exegesis**:
All things attain *Oneness* and thus *are born*;
if they *lose* the *Dao* and *deviate* from *Truth*,
then *death* and *extinction* would come in an instant.

**Noble lords** must *not* *fixate* on their *nobility* and *height*,
or they would fear *falling* and *ruin*.

○ **Imperial Annotation**:
Those who attain *Oneness* must *not* *fixate* on its *use*—
thus it is *admonished* that *Heaven* must *not* *fixate* on its *clarity*,
or it would fear *fragmentation*;
that *Earth* must *not* *fixate* on its *tranquility*,
or it would fear *dissipation*;
that *Spirit* *fixates* and *soul* *lingers*,
that *Valleys* *fixate* and *dryness* *exhausts*,
that *things* *fixate* and *life* *perishes*—
and noble lords *fixate* on their *nobility*,
then they would fear *overthrow* and *ruin*!

The *Sacred Teachings* descend to the world,
originally for the sake of *living beings*—
though they *extend* to *Heaven* and *Earth*’s *clarity* and *tranquility*,
they *ultimately* converge upon noble lords *guarding* *femininity* and *stillness*.

○ **Imperial Exegesis**:
*Ruination* means *overthrow*.
It says that noble lords, when they attain the *Dao*’s *use*,
and become *lords* of the *world*,
must *forget* their *honor* and *glory*,
and *humble* themselves to *nurture* [the people].
If they *fixate* on their *nobility* and *exaltation*,
they would fear *overthrow* and *ruin*,
and *not* be able to *stabilize* the *world*.

The *Annotation* says:
The *Sacred Teachings* descend to the world,
originally for the sake of *living beings*—
as the *Book of Documents* says:
*“Heaven generates all things, but only humans are sentient.”*
The *First Sovereign* acts as *parent*—
thus it is known that the *Sacred Teachings* belong to *one* person.
Though they begin by *admonishing Heaven* and *Earth*
to *forget* their *clarity* and *tranquility*,
they ultimately *admonish* noble lords
to *not* *fixate* on their *transformative* and *nurturing* *virtue*.

The *use* of the *Dao* of *humility* is fully elaborated below.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng** says:
Noble lords must *bend* themselves and *submit* to others,
*earnestly* seeking the *virtuous*—
they must *not* *only* desire to *exalt* themselves above others,
or they would fear *overthrow* and *losing* their *position*.

○ **Master Cheng’s Exegesis**:
*Ruination* means *defeat*.
If rulers cannot *use* the *Dao* to *guard* their *nobility*,
and *deviate* from *principle* and *contradict* *virtue*,
they would fear the *Sacred Vessel* being *overthrown*,
and the *altars* *tilting* in *danger*—
*Xià Jié* and *Yīn Zhòu* were such men.

**Thirdly**, it clarifies the *use* of the *Dao* in *humility*,
concluding the meaning of *attaining Oneness*.

Thus, *nobility* takes *lowliness* as its *root*,
and *height* takes *humility* as its *foundation*.

○ **Imperial Annotation**:
Noble lords are *noble* and *exalted*,
while the *common folk* are *lowly* and *humble*—
for those who *govern*, the *people* are the *root* and *foundation*.
They must *toil* in *humility* to *gather* the people,
so that they *rejoice* in the *harmonious* and *easy* *transformations*,
and *not* *dispersion*.

○ **Imperial Exegesis**:
*Nobility* refers to noble lords,
*lowliness* to the *common folk*—
it says that noble lords *obtain* their *nobility* *through* the *common folk*,
thus knowing that *lowliness* is the *root* and *foundation* of *nobility*.

As the *Book of Documents* says:
*“The people are the *root* of the state;
the *root* firm, the state is *tranquil*.”*
The *Annotation* says:
*“So they *rejoice* in the *harmonious* and *easy* *transformations*”*—
as the *Book of Odes* says:
*“The *harmonious* and *easy* noble one,
is the *parent* of the people.”*
*Harmonious* means *joyful*,
*easy* means *gentle*.
It says that the noble one has *joyful* and *gentle* *virtues*,
*nurturing* the people,
so the common folk *think* of them
as children think of their *parents*.
If their *virtues* are *opposite* to this,
then the people would *scatter*.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng** says:
Thus, *nobility* takes *lowliness* as its *root*—
it says that those who *must* be *exalted* and *noble*
should take *humble* and *lowly* things as their *root*—
like *Yǔ* and *Shī* *personally* *plowing*,
*Shùn* *molding* by the *riverbank*,
and the *Duke of Zhōu* *dwelling* in *white-walled* huts.

*Height* takes *humility* as its *foundation*—
it says that those who *must* be *exalted*
should take *humility* as their *foundation*—
like *building walls* and *constructing* *works*,
*elevating* from *lowliness*—
if the *foundation* is *not* *firm*,
then *ruin* will *inevitably* come.

○ **Master Róng** says:
Thus, *nobility* takes *lowliness* as its *root*—
this means the *state* takes the *people* as its *root*,
also saying that *nobility* comes from *lowliness*.
*Height* takes *humility* as its *foundation*—
even the *nine-tiered* *palace*
begins with *accumulated* *earth*.

○ **Master Cheng’s Exegesis**:
Thus, *nobility* takes *lowliness* as its *root*—
*nobility* means *exalted* and *high*,
*lowliness* means *humble* and *low*.
The ruler who attains *Oneness*
thus is able to *humble* himself.
The ruler who *loses* the *Dao*
must *necessarily* become *proud* and *arrogant*—
thus it is known that *arrogance* is the *foundation* of *lowliness*,
and *humility* is the *root* of *nobility*.
*Measuring* *gain* and *loss*,
therefore, such *admonitions* exist.

*Height* takes *humility* as its *foundation*—
even the *hundred-zhang* *height*
originates from a *single basket* of earth—
to illustrate that *nobility* and *lowliness*
take *humility* as their *foundation*.

Therefore, noble lords *call* themselves *“lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain”*—
is this not taking *lowliness* as their *root*?
Is it not?

○ **Imperial Annotation**:
*“Lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain”*—
these are what *common* people *despise*,
yet noble lords *use* them as their *titles*—
clearly, they *humble* themselves to *nurture* [the people],
and *do not* *fixate* on their *exaltation*.

*Is it not?*—
a *rhetorical* question,
to which the answer is: *“Indeed, it is taking lowliness as the root.”*

○ **Imperial Exegesis**:
*Therefore*—
concluding the *previous* meaning.
Noble lords *call* themselves *“lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain”*—
as the *Zuǒ Zhuan* records:
*“I, the lonely one, with my few ministers, grieve over lost plans.”*
Those who *call* themselves *“the widowed”* follow the *example*
where the *former sovereign* praised *“the widowed”* as *virtuous*.
Those who *call* themselves *“not-grain”* follow the *example*
where *“not-grain”* *hated* his *lack* of *sincere virtue*.

Again, according to *rites*,
a *son* does *not* call his *father* *“lonely”*,
a *wife* does *not* call her *husband* *“widowed”*,
and *“grain”* means *“to open”*—
*“not-grain”* is like *“not-good.”*
All these *three names*,
though *despised* by people,
are *used* by noble lords as their *titles*—
clearly, they *humble* themselves to *nurture* [the people],
and *do not* *fixate* on their *exaltation*.

*Is this not taking lowliness as their root?*
It says: *“If it is not like this, then what is?”*
*Is it not?*—
a *rhetorical* exclamation,
to which the answer is: *“Indeed, it is taking lowliness as the root.”*

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng** says:
Therefore, noble lords *call* themselves *“lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain”*—
*“lonely”* and *“widowed”* *illustrate* *isolation*,
*“not-grain”* *illustrates* *inability*—
like the *hub* of a *cartwheel*,
*supported* by all the *spokes*.

*Is this not taking lowliness as their root?*
Noble lords, though *most exalted*,
are able to *call* themselves *“lonely”* and *“widowed”*—
is this *not* taking *lowliness* as their *root*?
*—to enlighten the people.*

*Is it not?*
—a *sigh* of *exclamation*.

○ **Master Róng** says:
Therefore, noble lords *call* themselves *“lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain”*—
*“lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain”* are the *humble* *titles* of kings and lords—
this is also *not forgetting* their *root*.

「Is this truly taking *lowliness* as their *root*?
No—it is not that they *actually* take *lowliness* as their *root*.
○ **Master Chéng’s Commentary**:
*"Not-grain"* arises from *unvirtue*.
○ Noble lords and highborn, wise and perceptive, yet indulging in arrogance and self-indulgence—this is the *root* of their ruin. *Humility* is the foundation of true nobility, so they must stoop to embrace the lowly, governing themselves with *lowliness*—thus calling themselves *“lonely,”* *“widowed,”* *“not-grain.”*
Is this not taking *lowliness* as their *root*?
Yet they say *“Is it not?”*—this is merely an exclamatory rhetorical question, as if to affirm: *“Indeed, it is taking lowliness as their root.”*

Thus, *“count the carriages, yet there are no carriages.”*
○ **Imperial Commentary**:
*“Count the carriages”* and there are *“no carriages.”*
The *hub* and *axle* are the *root* of the carriage—
counting *nobility* reveals *no nobility*;
*lowliness* beneath is the *root* of *nobility*.
The *axle* is the *root* of the carriage—
if one *fixates* on it, the carriage is *established*;
*lowliness* is the *root* of *nobility*—
if one *guards* it, *nobility* is *secure*.
This admonishes noble lords:
to take *lowliness* as their *root*—
merely a metaphor for *“counting carriages”* without *carriages*.

○ **Imperial Commentary**:
*“Thus”* continues the preceding thought.
Earlier, it was explained that noble lords *gain nobility through lowliness*—
*nobility* has no fixed form,
its principle is difficult to clarify,
so it borrows *“counting carriages”* as an analogy.
Exhausting the *count* of carriages,
ultimately there is *no name* for *“carriage,”*
yet the *wheel* and *axle* are *falsely* called *“carriage.”*
This metaphorizes noble lords:
counting their *nobility* reveals *no name* for *“noble,”*
yet *lowliness* beneath is *falsely* borrowed as the *root* of their *nobility*.
The *wheel* and *axle* are the *root* of the carriage—
if the *root* is *preserved*, there is a carriage;
if the *root* is *lost*, there is no carriage.
*Lowliness* beneath is the *root* of *nobility*—
if the *root* is *preserved*, there is *position*;
if the *root* is *abandoned*, there is no *position*.
This is said to admonish noble lords:
to cherish and nourish the lowly,
not to abandon the solitary and bereaved.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng’s Explanation**:
*“Thus”* means *“to approach.”*
People approach the *counted carriages*—
as *spokes*, as *wheels*, as *hubs*, as *poles*, as *carriages*—
yet there is *no name* for *“carriage”* itself,
so it *becomes* a carriage.
This illustrates that noble lords,
not clinging to *exalted titles*,
are thus *established* in their *nobility*.

○ **Master Róng says**:
Noble lords are truly *noble* yet *name* themselves *lowly*—
these are *Dao*-realized rulers.
Songs and ballads *praise virtue* yet do not *glorify* them,
for this is *“counting praise” yet there is *no praise*—
*slander* hangs like a *suspended* *jewel*, yet it is not *blame*,
for this is *“counting blame” yet there is *no blame*.
The *Dao*-embodied gentleman
remains unmoved by external *honor* or *humiliation*,
*gain* or *loss*—
his *joy* and *anger* do not show on his *countenance*.

○ **Master Chéng’s Commentary**:
*“Carriage”* means *“chariot.”*
*Spokes*, *hubs*, *rims*—
*falsely* assembled, yet *only* the *name* of *“chariot”* remains.
Count them, and there is *no substance*—
the *Five Aggregates*, the *Four Great Elements*—
all are *illusion*.
Thus, the *body* being *empty* and *void*,
where shall *nobility* be *lodged*?
Therefore, in *nobility*, one must *practice humility*.
One should not be *polished* like *jade*,
nor *rough* like *stone*.

○ **Imperial Commentary**:
*“Polished”* (*liángliáng*)—the *appearance* of *jade*;
*“rough”* (*luòluò*)—the *appearance* of *stone*.
To take *lowliness* as the *root*.

○ **Imperial Commentary**:
*Jade* is *noble*, *stone* is *lowly*—
like *jade*, one *exalts* oneself;
like *stone*, one *humbles* oneself.
Since noble lords take *lowliness* as their *root*,
they must not be *polished* like *jade* in *self-exaltation*,
but rather *rough* like *stone* to *guard humility*.

○ **Master Hé Shànggōng says**:
*“Polished”* (*liángliáng*) means *“few”* (in virtue);
*“rough”* (*luòluò*) means *“many”* (in flaws).
*Jade* is *few* in *flaws*, hence *blamed* for being *precious*;
*stone* is *many* in *flaws*, hence *despised* for being *lowly*.
This says: *“Do not wish to be like jade, prized by others,
nor like stone, scorned by others—
but dwell in the *middle*.”*

○ **Master Yán says**:
Neither *few* nor *many*,
neither *noble* nor *lowly*—
without *acting* from the *body*,
the *Spirit* and *Clarity* are *unbound*;
without *acting* from *Heaven*,
one *aligns* with the *ten thousand things*.

○ **Master Róng says**:
*Jade*, *polished* and *few*, is thus *noble*;
*stone*, *rough* and *many*, is thus *lowly*.
*Lowliness* is what people *hate*,
*nobility* is what *things* *attack*—
both are *unstable*.
In *nobility*, yet *humble and retiring*,
one does not wish to be like *jade* under *attack*.
In *lowliness*, yet *aspiring to equality*,
one does not wish to be like *stone* and *abandoned*.
Obtain it with *oneness*,
dwell in it with *moderation*—
only the *highest* and the *lowest*
are *unstable*;
all else is *secure*.

○ **Master Chéng’s Commentary**:
*Jade*—*nobility*.
*Stone*—*lowliness*.
*Polished*—*few*.
*Rough*—*many*.
If one is *internally confused* by the *body*,
*externally misled* by *things*,
then one *values* *lowliness* while *degrading* the *body*.
Now, having *“counted carriages” yet found no carriage**,
one *awakens* to the *emptiness* of *self* and *things*,
thus *transforming* into *equality*—
*nobility* and *lowliness* are *indistinguishable*,
*separating* from *form*, *abandoning* *knowledge*,
*merging* into the *Ultimate Dao*—
thus, one does not wish to be *polished* like *jade* (as *precious*),
nor *rough* like *stone* (as *despised*).

---
**“The Chapter of *Reversal*: The Movement of the Dao”**
This chapter follows the previous,
properly illuminating those who *obtain Oneness*—
*humble* and *vacant*, *using* the *Dao*,
thus it is placed here,
clarifying how such a person,
*descending* from the *root* and *following* the *path*,
*stoops* to respond to the *people*.

This chapter opens into three distinctions.
**First**, it clarifies *compassionate* *salvation* of *things*,
*reversing* the *Sage* to *align* with the *common*.
**Second**, though *teaching* appears in *many forms*,
none surpass *gentleness* and *weakness*.
**Third**, the *Two Forces* and *ten thousand phenomena*
arise from the *Dao*.

**First**, it clarifies *compassionate* *salvation* of *things*,
*reversing* the *Sage* to *align* with the *common*.
Silent and *unmoving*,
ever *congealed* within the *Great Red*,
*Mysterious* yet *nameless*,
*Returning* to *begin* above the *Primordial Blue*.
*Uniting* the *One Qi* of *Origin*,
*Deploying* the *functions* of the *Three Powers*,
*Distinguishing* the *hard* and *soft* of *Heaven* and *Earth*,
*Operating* the *nurturing* of *Yin* and *Yang*.
Making the *Dragon’s head* into *virtue*,
*Alone* bearing *Pei Qiáng*,
the *Tiger* and *Rhinoceros* as *awe*,
*Following* *Dòng Fèng*’s *command*.
*Heaven’s* *writings* *shimmer*—
the *seventy-two* *characters* of *text*,
*Cloud-scripts* *radiant*—
the *eighty-one* *sections* of *mystery*.
*Emperor Yú* of *Xià* *revered* it, his *blessing* *distant*;
*Yǒu Lǘ* *stole* it, his *nation* *perished*.
At the *Jade Pool*, the *Minghu* *feasted*—
the *Han River* questioned *King Zhāo*, who *never returned*.
Thus it is known:
the *essence* of *obtaining the Dao*—
*spirits* and *numina* thereby *bless* people;
the *calamity* of *losing the Dao*—
*portents* and *omens* thereby *destroy* and *extinguish*.

*“Reversal”* means *movement*—
truly as it is said:
*Silent*, the *mystery* is *serene*;
*responding*, it *interacts* with the *common* for *use*.
The *Ultimate Dao* *reverses* and *lends*—
this is indeed *truthful speech*.

**“The Movement of the Dao”**
○ **Imperial Commentary**:
This clarifies *adaptation*—
*“Reversal”* takes *contrary* *principles* to *harmonize* *meaning*.

**“The Movement of the Dao” (Continued)**

**“Reversal of Principle, Unity of Meaning”**
This is how the Sage acts with *adaptation*—
*Adaptation* is the *Dao’s* movement,
hence it is said: *“Reversal”* is the *Dao’s* movement.

**Imperial Commentary:**
This clarifies *adaptation*—
*“Reversal”* takes *contrary* *principles* to *harmonize* *meaning*.
**Imperial Citation:**
*“Reversal”* is *adaptation* to *common* *usage* for *meaning*,
*“Movement”* is the name for *change*—
speaking of *adaptation* to the *Dao*.
It is said that *sentient beings* cling to *life* and thereby *lose* the *Dao*,
so the Sage *varies* and *adapts*, ordering *things* to *reverse* *common* *ways* and *align* with the *Dao*.

The *Commentary* says: *“Reversal of Principle, Unity of Meaning”*—
*“Principle”* means *constancy*,
*“Meaning”* means *appropriateness*.
To make the *noble* take the *lowly* as *foundation*,
the *high* take the *low* as *base*,
the *having* take the *non-being* for *use*—
first, it *contradicts* *common* *sentiment*,
then it *conforms* and *unites* with the *Dao*,
hence it is called the *Dao’s* movement.

Confucius said:
*“One may stand with him, but one cannot yet adapt with him.”*
Since *adaptation* to the *Dao* *contradicts* *constancy* and is difficult to grasp,
he used the analogy of the *mulberry tree*:
*“Its flowers reverse before they unite,”*
to illustrate that *adaptation* first *inverts* before it *conforms*.

**Master Hé Shàng** said:
*“Reversal”* means *returning* to the *root*—
the *Dao* moves to *generate* all *things*,
and *abandoning* it leads to *ruin*.

**Master Róng** said:
*“Reversal”* is the *Dao’s* movement,
*“Weakness”* is the *Dao’s* *use*.
The *Dao* employs *gentleness* and *weakness* for *use*—
all *movement* *reverses* *common* *ways*,
for *common* *ways* rely on *rigidity* and *strength*,
and all *things* thereby *lose* the *Dao*.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*“Reversal”* means *returning*.
*“Movement”* means *compassion*.
The *Sage* who *obtains* the *Dao* transcends the *Three Realms*,
yet with *compassion* and *pity* he *enters* the *Three Realms*,
mingling among *existence* and *responding* to *circumstances*—
hence the *Classic* says: *“Returning to the Sun.”*
The second section clarifies that though *teaching* may *vary* in *methods*,
nothing surpasses *gentleness* and *weakness*.
*“Weakness”* is the *Dao’s* *use*.

**Imperial Commentary:**
This clarifies *substance*—
*“Weakness”* takes *gentleness*, *femininity*, and *tranquility*,
for *gentleness*, *femininity*, and *tranquility* are the *Sage’s* *substance*.
To *dwell* in *substance* is the *Dao’s* *constant* *use,
hence it is said: *“Weakness”* is the *Dao’s* *use*.

**Imperial Citation:**
This clarifies the *substance* of the *Dao*—
people all *degrade* the *weak* and *exalt* the *strong*,
thus knowing that the *forceful*, *arrogant*, and *boisterous* are the *common* *ways*.
The *Dao* overcomes the *rigid* with *harmony* and *gentleness*,
thus knowing that *gentleness*, *weakness*, *femininity*, and *tranquility*
are the *Dao’s* *constant* *use,
hence it is said: *“Weakness”* is the *Dao’s* *use*.

**Master Hé Shàng** said:
*“Gentleness* and *weakness* are what the *Dao* *constantly* *uses*,
and thus it endures.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*Responding* to *circumstances* and *setting* *teachings*,
though *methods* may *vary*,
to discuss *appropriately*, nothing surpasses *gentleness* and *weakness*,
hence *gentleness* and *weakness* are taken as the *primary* *means* of *transformation*.

The third section clarifies the *Two Principles* and *ten thousand phenomena*,
which arise from the *Dao*.
All *things* under *heaven* are *born* from *being*,
and *being* is *born* from *non-being*.

**Imperial Commentary:**
As *substance* relates to *adaptation*,
so *non-being* *generates* *being*—
thus, those who *act* with *adaptation* *revere* *returning* to *substance*,
and those who *use* *being* must *depend* on *non-being*.
Yet the *Ultimate Dao* is *empty* and *serene*,
*separate* from *names* and *forms*,
all *dharma-nature* is *void*,
and *things* do not *depend* on each other.
If one can *forget* both *adaptation* and *substance*,
and *obliterate* both *being* and *non-being*,
then one attains *counting* without *counting*,
and may be said to *transcend*.

**Imperial Citation:**
It is said that all *things* under *heaven* with *form*
must *transmit* through *form*—
hence it is said: *“born from being.”*
Exhausting their *substantial* *bodies*,
they must *depend* on *non-being*—
hence *Listed Child* said:
*“Form moves yet cannot generate form, only shadow;
non-being moves yet cannot generate non-being, only being.”*
Thus it is said: *“The *void* is the *root* of *heaven* and *earth*,
*non-being* is the *source* of *ten thousand things.”*
This is spoken to make *sentient beings* *exhaust* the *source* and *recognize* the *root* to *awaken* to the *Dao*.

Since *being* and *non-being* are thus,
so too are *adaptation* and *substance*—
hence the *Commentary* says:
*“Substance* relates to *adaptation* as *non-being* *generates* *being.”*
Again, it says:
*“The *Ultimate Dao* is *empty* and *serene*,
*separate* from *names* and *forms*,
all *dharma-nature* is *void*,
and *things* do not *depend* on each other.”*
This means the *Dao* at its *extreme* is *empty* and *serene*,
neither *adaptation* nor *substance*—
how can it be *named*?
The *true nature* of all *dharma* in *principle*
is neither *being* nor *non-being*,
*cutting off* all *dependence*—
what is said of *“things born from being, being born from non-being”*
are all *approximations* by *analogy*.
If one knows *“counting without counting”*,
then one knows *“counting all *dharma* without *dharma*”**—
how could there be *being*, *non-being*, *adaptation*, or *substance*
that can be said to *generate* each other?
Those who *awaken* to this *principle* may be said to have *fully understood*.

**Master Hé Shàng** said:
All *things* under *heaven* are *born* from *being*—
all *things* under *heaven* arise from *heaven* and *earth*,
and *heaven* and *earth* have *form* and *position*,
hence it is said: *“born from being.”*
*“Being* is *born* from *non-being*”—
*heaven* and *earth* in their *divine* *clarity*,
*fluttering* and *creeping* *things*,
all arise from the *Dao*—
the *Dao* has no *form* or *image*,
hence it is said: *“born from non-being.”*
This speaks of *root* overcoming *flower*,
*weakness* overcoming *strength*,
and *humility* overcoming *fullness*.

**Master Róng** said:
*“Being”* refers to *heaven* and *earth*—
*heaven* and *earth* have *form*,
hence they are called *being*.
*Heaven* covers, *earth* bears,
and *things* thereby *obtain* *life*—
hence it is said: *“born from being.”*
*“Non-being”* refers to the *Dao*—
the *Dao* has no *form* or *appearance*,
its *nature* is *pure* and *empty*,
hence it is said: *“non-being.”*
*Heaven* and *earth* arise from the *Dao*,
and *being* is *born* from *non-being*—
hence it is said: *“The *void* is the *root* of *heaven* and *earth*,
*non-being* is the *source* of *ten thousand things.”*
The *bewildered* *lose* the *Dao* and do not *recognize* the *origin*—
the *Sage* *transmits* *teaching* to clarify the *beginning*.
If one can *return* to the *Dao*,
transcend *birth* and *death*, and *exit* *being* and *non-being*,
then one is *deluded* and *common*,
*entangled* in *being* and *non-being* and *bound* to *birth* and *death*.
*Form* and *spirit* *unite* and *appear* in *form*—
hence it is said: *“born from being.”*
*Form* and *spirit* *disperse* and have no *substance*—
hence it is said: *“born from non-being.”*

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*“Being”* responds to the *Dao*—
this is called the *original* *qi* of *Oneness*.
*“Non-being”* is the *mysterious* *root*—
this is called the *dark* and *silent* *foundation*.
It is said that *heaven*, *earth*, and *ten thousand things*
all arise from the *Dao’s* *response* with *law*—
this *response* to the *Dao* arises from the *mysterious* *root*.
*Original* to the *mysterious* *root* is *ultimate* *non-being*.
From the *Classic of the Way and Its Virtue*, *Volume Eleven*, *Commentary by Mù on the Profound Virtue*, ends.

**Chapter Forty-One: The Superior Person Hears the Dao**

The reason this chapter follows the previous one is that the prior chapter elucidates the *Dao’s* *response* with *law*—both its *trace* and *substance* are wondrous—so this chapter clarifies that the *superior person* can awaken to it, whereas the *inferior* cannot.

Now, examining this chapter, its meaning unfolds in three distinctions:
1. The three kinds of people who hear the Dao possess differing *natures* and *capacities*.
2. Those who embody the Dao conceal their light and obscure their brilliance.
3. The Dao’s transformative *power* gives rise to all myriad things.

**1. The three kinds of people who hear the Dao possess differing *natures* and *capacities*.**

The Dao is set forth in three categories, and people perceive it in myriad ways—
some soar upon the *path* of heaven, their flight surpassing the clouds of the *Great Peng* (鹏),
while others are confined to earthly *traces*, buried for a century beneath the mounds of ants.
The *foolish* adjust to the lowly, while the *virtuous* rise with lofty *qi*—
thus, by the seaside there are those who chase after stench,
and in the imperial halls, those who cherish fragrance.

The *superior sage* diligently practices the Dao,
while the *lowly* clap their hands and mock it—
lost in the *clear spring*, they forever wallow in *muddy waters*.
Ah! When the winds and rains darken the sky,
why does the *phoenix* not stir? Since they do not awaken,
how can the *rat* know what is *ugly*?
The distinctions among these three ranks lie here.

The *superior person* hears the Dao and diligently practices it.
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
*Awakened understanding leads to diligent practice.*

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Commentary:**
The *superior sage* possesses deep insight and piercing discernment.
Hearing the Dao, they grasp its provisional clarity,
yet its true essence is soft and yielding.
Thus, upon hearing it, they act without pause—
hence it is said: *“stirring and practicing.”*

**Shānshàng Gōng says:**
The *superior person*, upon hearing the Dao,
strives with utmost effort to embody it.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Their faith in the Dao grows ever stronger,
and they practice with resolute will—
unmoved by the shifts of cold and heat,
unshaken even as gold and stone dissolve,
their beginning and end remain constant,
firm and unyielding—
this is what is meant by *“stirring and practicing.”*

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The *superior* in *capacity* possesses keen wisdom and insight,
yet upon hearing the *Dao’s* ultimate truth,
they awaken to the emptiness of all phenomena—
thus, they exert themselves in study,
never ceasing in their diligence.

The *middle person* hears the Dao—
sometimes it seems to exist, sometimes not.
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
*The middle person* can ascend or descend,
hence their doubt.

Doubt makes it seem as if it exists or does not.
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Commentary:**
The *moderate* in understanding
have not yet clarified the distinction between clarity and obscurity.
Hearing the Dao’s wondrous *Way*,
they sometimes believe, sometimes disbelieve—
if they grasp its clarity, they hold fast in faith,
but if they fail to see its depth, they doubt and waver,
not yet firmly resolved—
hence it is said: *“sometimes it exists, sometimes not.”*

**Shānshàng Gōng says:**
The *middle person*, upon hearing the Dao,
pursue bodily preservation to extend their life,
and govern their state to achieve great peace—
they rejoice in its existence,
yet when confronted with wealth, desire, or honor,
they may succumb to emotion and lose sight of it.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Like raw silk, they lack constancy,
chasing after the fleeting hues of *Dao* and *non-Dao*—
the *middle person* is undecided,
their heart shifting with their likes and dislikes.
Hearing the *true Dao*,
they preserve their life to stabilize their nation—
then they uphold the Dao and abandon the mundane.
Seeing wealth and desire,
they delight in sensory gratification—
then they cling to the mundane and forget the Dao.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The *middle* in *capacity* have a balanced intellect,
yet their understanding of principle remains unclear.
Though they hear the Dao,
they cannot fathom its profundity—
if they restrain their emotions and return to the *Way*,
they attain emptiness in that moment,
yet their mind, once touched by worldly dust,
becomes entangled in the realm of *being*—
their resolve is uncertain,
hence it is said: *“exists or does not.”*

The *inferior person* hears the Dao and laughs loudly at it.
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
*They are lost and do not believe,*
hence they mock it.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Commentary:**
Those of shallow insight do not grasp the Dao’s principle—
hearing it, they dismiss it as empty fancy,
and thus scoff at it.
This is like the *Zhuofu* (章甫) being deemed coarse by the *Yue* people,
or the *Hepu* (和璞) being rejected by the *Chu* kingdom—
hence *Zhuāngzi* says:
*“A rigid thinker cannot be spoken to about the Dao.”*

**Shānshàng Gōng says:**
The *inferior person* is greedy and lustful, craving many things—
seeing the Dao’s softness and yielding,
they call it *frightening and cowardly*,
and when they see its simplicity and plainness,
they deem it *vulgar and crude*—
hence they laugh loudly at it.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Their mind is confused by gain and loss,
they know the near but not the far—
their senses are dull to truth and falsehood,
their understanding shallow, unable to perceive depth.
They only delight in the petty practices of worldly dust,
and mock the vast *Dao* of *emptiness and clarity*.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The *inferior* in *capacity* are dull and obtuse—
hearing the Dao’s profound and distant truths,
its vast and sweeping words,
they fail to awaken to its meaning,
deeming it empty and fantastic,
and thus slander it, clapping their hands in derision.

**If they do not mock, it is not sufficient to be called the Dao.**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
*If the Dao is not mocked by the inferior,*
it is not profound and wondrous enough.*

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Commentary:**
The Dao is *profound and mysterious*—
deep beyond comprehension,
bright yet veiled,
its principles contrary to ordinary perception—
thus, it is mocked.
If the inferior do not mock it,
it lacks subtlety and refinement—
it is merely a shallow, conventional teaching,
not worthy of being called the Dao.

The Dao is not a teaching for the *common* age—
thus, it is mocked by the *lowly and foolish*,
and this is why it is called the *wondrous Dao*.

**Shānshàng Gōng says:**
*If the inferior do not mock it,*
it is not sufficient to be called the Dao.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
The Dao is deep and intricate,
difficult for the inferior to grasp—
its subtlety and mystery
are not easily recognized by the *lowly and foolish*.
Now, if they mock it,
it cannot make the *true* blend with the *muddy*—
rather, it serves to highlight the Dao’s purity and distance.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*If the inferior do not mock it,*
it is not worthy to be called the *sage’s Dao*.
**Establishing the true *substance* of the Dao:**

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
*Establishing* means *setting forth*.

Now, setting forth this teaching,
to clarify the differing *paths* of the *superior person*,
the *middle person*, and the *inferior person* toward the Dao.

The *substance* here refers to
the subsequent elucidation of the Dao and other matters.»

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
*"Establishing"* means *"setting forth."* When the Dao is set forth in speech, it is as in the following passage.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Human inclinations vary—
the Sage establishes methods to harmonize divergent hearts.
Without teaching, there is no failing to teach;
yet common sentiments of approval or rejection
may lead to disbelief.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Establishing"* means *"setting forth"*—
the Dao practiced by the *superior person* is elucidated below.
*"The substance"* refers to the subsequent passages on the Dao and other matters.

---
**Second, elucidating those who embody the Dao in concealment:**

**The Dao appears as if obscured,**
**Advancing the Dao seems like retreat,**
**The Way of the plain seems like the flawed.**

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
*"The Dao appears as if obscured"*—
the *superior person* acts, yet in clarity, it seems obscured;
in advancement, it seems retreat;
in the plain, it seems flawed.
Thus, the *middle person* doubts it,
while the *inferior* laughs greatly.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
*"Clarity"* means illumination.
*"Obscured"* means dimness.
It speaks of those who cultivate virtue—
nurturing obscurity to achieve clarity,
abandoning form and discarding wisdom,
yet truly illuminated—
hence, *"as if obscured."*
The *superior person*, though diligent in practice,
appears in clarity as if obscured—
the *inferior*, not comprehending, thus mocks it.
The *middle person*, initially hearing of the illuminated Dao,
seems to retain it,
but later, as if forgotten, seems obscured.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those who illuminate the Dao
appear as if dark and seeing nothing.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Wisdom is all-encompassing—*clarity*.
Shining without dazzling—*obscured*.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Obscured"* means dim.
Those who truly perceive the Dao
conceal their brilliance, blending with the common,
not displaying their clarity,
as if foolish and aligned.

**Advancing the Dao seems like retreat,**
**The Way of the plain seems like the flawed.**

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
Those advancing the Dao
have no inner ambition,
forget external affairs,
daily diminishing fame,
yet great achievement seems lacking—
the *inferior*, observing this, deem it retreat and failure.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those who advance the Dao
appear as if lagging behind.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Hearing the Dao and diligently practicing—*advancement*.
Great achievement seeming incomplete—*retreat*.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The *greatly learned* show no progress—
though internally advancing,
externally they seem to retreat.

**The Way of the plain seems like the flawed,**
**The Dao of equality seems like the uneven.**

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
*"Plain"* means level.
*"Flawed"* refers to uneven silk.
The mind, pure and free of dust,
untainted by desire,
level and unobstructed,
yet externally like uneven silk.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
*"Plain"* means level—
those of the Great Dao
do not distinguish themselves,
appearing like many flawed comparisons.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Level and equal—*the plain Dao*—
harmonizing light with dust,
as if flawed.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Plain"* means level—
attaining the Dao of perfect equality,
those who practice know
all beings share the same substance,
seeing no distinction between wise and foolish,
equal in rank and kind.
This meaning—interpreted by Hé, Chéng, and Lǐ—
is the explanation for *"flawed."*

---
**The virtue of the highest is like a valley,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Empty and green, containing all things.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
Those who diligently practice are called *highest virtue*—
their virtue, fully manifest,
contains all without exclusion—
hence, *"like a valley."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those of highest virtue are like deep valleys,
unashamed by filth and turbidity.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Nothing is excluded.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
Those surpassing in virtue
equal the boundless void,
thus able to contain all things—
like an empty valley.
*"Common"* also written as *"society"*—
speaking of those who can even forget virtue,
not differing from the vulgar.

---
**Great purity seems like disgrace,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Pure yet containing filth.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
*"Pure"* means pristine.
*"Disgrace"* means dust.
Those attaining pristine purity
conceal their traces, blending with dust—
thus called *"as if disgrace,"*
yet truly pure and complete.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those of great purity
appear as if stained with disgrace,
not self-displaying.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Coarse yet not impure—*great purity*.
Mixed yet seeming turbid—*as if disgrace.*

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Pure"* means pristine and tranquil.
*"Disgrace"* means defiled.
Those of great purity and high conduct
harmonize their light with dust,
do not dazzle others,
thus blend into the waves—
as if stained with disgrace.
Hence, the Eastern Master said:
*"Purify the Dao yet soil its traces"*—
this is the meaning.

---
**Great virtue seems insufficient,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Great achievement yet holding humility.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
Those of ultimate virtue—
their virtue pervades all—*great*.
Guarding softness and practicing humility,
thus always appearing insufficient.
*The Records of the Historian* says:
*"A skilled merchant hides his wealth as if empty;
the virtuous man, though full of virtue,
appears as if foolish."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those of broad virtue
appear as if foolish and insufficient.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Great fullness seems empty.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Great"* means vast.
Those bearing great virtue,
embodying the Dao in emptiness and forgetfulness,
thus internally wise yet externally appearing insufficient.
*The Laozi Transmission* says:
*"A skilled merchant hides his wealth as if empty;
the virtuous man, though full of virtue,
appears as if foolish."*

---
**Establishing virtue seems like theft,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Accomplishing deeds without ostentation.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
*"Establishing"* means *"setting forth."*
*"Theft"* means stealth.
Those establishing hidden virtue
practice secretly,
like thieves who always fear discovery—
thus, *"as if theft."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those establishing morality
appear as if deceitfully emptied.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Secret practice, covert influence.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Theft"* means stealth.
Those establishing great virtue
hide their names, conceal their traces,
like thieves acting unseen—
hence, the Classic says:
*"As if fearing their neighbors."*

---
**True purity seems like theft,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Sincere and harmonizing light.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
*"True"* means pure and unadulterated.
*"Theft"* means transformation.
Those practicing the Dao—
their virtue pure and unadulterated,
yet seemingly transformable,
blending with others while harmonizing their light.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
The unadorned and simple—
if their colors seem to shift,
they are shallow and indistinct.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
*"Shift"* means transformation.
Nature untainted, substance ever-present—
this is true purity.
Forgotten life and death,
united with transformation—
this is *"shift."*

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Substance"* means reality.
*"Shift"* means transformation.
Those of innate truth and substance—
still yet moving, true yet responsive,
their transformations reveal impermanence—
thus, they seem to *"shift."*

**The Great Square has no corners,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
It does not erect rigid boundaries.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
*"Square"* means upright.
*"Corners"* means angles.
To polish one’s name and principles
to erect rigid boundaries—
these are the Eastern Teachings’ adherents,
not the true Great Square.
Ground smooth yet unbroken,
dwelling in mud without staining—
this is the Great Square.
Yet harmonizing light with dust,
not distinguishing itself—
no corners.
Thus, *"The Great Square has no corners."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
The truly upright and square
have no crookedness or sharp angles.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
The cosmos manifests forms,
it has squares.
The Supreme Dao is formless—
no corners.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Corners"* means angles.
Those embodying the Dao’s vast wisdom and elegance—
following naturally, conforming to things,
not clinging to principles or erecting angles—
this is called *"transcending principles."*

**Great vessels take long to mature,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
And yield no immediate gains.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
Vessels hold all things;
because of their lateness, they achieve greatness.
Thus, the superior sage diligently practices,
accumulating merit to attain realization—
gradual, not achieved in a day.
Hence, *"late maturity."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Great vessels—
like the Nine Tripods and jade ornaments—
cannot be rushed to completion.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Habits solidify over time,
perfection lies in duration—
thus, cultivation cannot be achieved in a single day.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The Nine Tripods and jade ornaments
are not completed in a day—
a parable for the truly great:
not attained by hasty effort,
requiring eons of refinement
to reach the utmost void—
as with the Master of the Empty Boat fishing.

**Great sound is rare in voice,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
It does not adorn with frivolous words.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
The Dao responds to all sounds—
great sound.
Listening, yet no voice—
rare in voice.
Thus, the Sage expounds the One Vehicle:
its law resounds widely,
awaiting awakening to respond—
hence, *"rare in voice."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Great sound is like thunder—
it moves when the time is right,
a metaphor for constant love of *qi* and rare speech.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
The great bell tolls in rhythm,
the Mysterious Teaching acts according to circumstances.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Rare"* means nonexistent.
The Supreme Dao’s great sound—
silent, yet without sound,
from origin to manifestation—
soundless sound.
Thus, Zhong Ziqi heard nothing,
yet the jade resonance shook the cosmos.
To clarify: it is both trace and origin—
hence, *"great sound is rare in voice."*

**Great form is formless,**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Thus, it can respond to all kinds.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
Those bound to form and substance
are confined to one aspect.
Only the Dao of Great Form—
originally formless,
responding as it is sensed,
shaping all forms—
hence, *"great form is formless."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
Those embodying the Great Law’s form
are simple, without embellishment.

**Lǐ Róng says:**
Great form is formless,
the Dao is hidden, nameless.
The void encompasses all forms—
thus, *"great form,"*
great form without form—
hence, *"formless."*
Form cannot be concealed—
thus, *"the Dao is hidden,"*
cut off from designation—
hence, *"nameless."*

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The Dao’s great form—
form yet formless.
Formless yet form—
formless.
Even Zhuli’s keen eyes could not perceive its form.
Its colors fill the void—
to clarify: it is both having and not having—
hence, *"great form is formless."*

**The Dao is hidden, nameless.**
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Its functions are not displayed.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
If we call its pervasive generation *"Dao,"*
forgetting its functions—
this is hidden, nameless.
Desiring to name it to describe its substance,
yet its mystery is formless—
thus, it cannot be named—
hence, *"the Dao is hidden, nameless."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
The Dao is concealed,
so no one can name it.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
The Supreme Dao’s mystery—
profound, hidden, and obscure—
beyond form and substance’s measure,
how could names and speech define it?

**A third sigh at the Dao’s creative power.**
Only the Dao
is both generous and accomplished—
**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
Though hidden and nameless,
it truly generously endows all with harmonious, wondrous use
and brings them to fulfillment.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
This concludes the Dao’s functions.
*"Ah!"*—a sigh.
*"Only"*—exclusive.

The lending is giving and bestowing.
This Dao, though nameless and formless,
without shape or sound,
alone spreads *qi* and transforms,
lending and bestowing upon all things,
bringing them to fulfillment—
thus, *"generous in lending and accomplished."*

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
*"Fulfillment"* means completion.
The Dao generously lends its vital essence to all
and brings them to completion.

**Master Róng says:**
Advancing yet appearing to retreat—
advancing without advancing.
Retreating yet appearing to advance—
retreating without retreating.
Illuminating yet appearing obscure—
not true illumination.
Obscure yet appearing illuminated—
not true obscurity.
The Supreme Dao is neither advancing nor retreating,
neither illuminated nor obscure,
without color, without sound,
without form, without name.
Though nameless, what name does it not establish?
Though formless, what form does it not manifest?
Thus, it spreads *qi* and transforms,
lending life to all existence,
acting yet not relying,
entrusting to the natural order.

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
*"Lending"* means borrowing.
This nameless Dao possesses great compassion,
thus it descends to save all beings,
borrowing its virtuous power
to shelter all creatures,
nurturing the Three Realms,
employing myriad expedients
to guide them toward fulfillment.

---
**Chapter Forty-Two: The Dao Generates One**

This chapter follows the previous,
for the prior expounds the Dao’s transformative power—
generous in lending, accomplished in creation—
thus this chapter clarifies what it generates,
though without sequential order.

Its meaning unfolds in three distinctions:
First, it reveals the Dao’s transformative power in generation,
Second, it displays the nature of things and exhorts adherence to harmony,
Third, it elaborates on gentleness and weakness as the foundation of cultivation.

**First: Revealing the Dao’s Transformative Power in Generation**

From the One *qi*, refined,
its principle penetrates the mysteries of subtlety.
The Three Pure Ones emerge first,
their essence returning to the Supreme Void.
Some ride cloud-dragons through the Great Net,
yet unseen when viewed;
some strike zithers and drums to ascend the Precious Realm,
yet unheard when listened to.
Vacuous and insubstantial, they emerge among mortals;
serene and silent, they transcend all forms.
Though chariots and cavalry fill the roads,
Laozi dines with the common folk at the lips of the people,
yet moves without exertion.
The Celestial Sovereign sits upon the dust of the earth—
thus it is known:
the Dao generates the Three Blows, embracing yin and yang,
all receiving the harmonious, stabilizing power of the True Mystery.

The Dao generates One,
One generates Two,
Two generates Three,
Three generates all things.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
The Dao generates One—
One generates Two—
One is the harmonious *qi*.
The Dao emits harmonious, wondrous *qi*,
yet insufficient for generation,
so it generates yang *qi*.
Yang *qi* alone cannot sustain life,
so it generates yin *qi*.
Accumulating the One’s harmonious *qi*,
thus it is said, *"One generates Two."*
Accumulating the Two’s yang *qi*,
thus it is said, *"Two generates Three."*
Three generates all things—
yin and yang embrace and conceive,
harmonious *qi* adjusts and refines,
thus it is said, *"Three generates all things."*

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
The Dao is the divine origin of the utmost vacuity,
One is the refined essence of harmonious *qi*,
*"Generate"* means dynamic emergence.
The Dao dynamically emits harmonious *qi*
to generate all things.
Yet in its transformative principle,
this alone is insufficient—
it further generates yang *qi*.
Accumulating yang *qi* to complete the One,
thus it is called *"Two."*
Pure yang alone cannot generate,
so it generates yin *qi*.
Accumulating yin to complete the Two,
thus it is called *"Three."*
Three generates all things—
when yin and yang harmonize,
harmonious *qi* becomes pure,
thus all existence is born.
This clarifies the meaning:
the Dao’s transformative power is generous in lending and accomplished in creation.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
*"The Dao generates One"*—
the Dao’s first generation is One.
*"One generates Two"*—
One generates yin and yang.
*"Two generates Three"*—
yin and yang generate the Three Pure *qi* of clear and turbid,
dividing into Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.
*"Three generates all things"*—
Heaven, Earth, and Humanity together generate all things.
Heaven bestows, Earth transforms,
Humanity nurtures them.

**Master Róng says:**
*"The Dao generates One"*—
from the void, *qi* stirs, hence *"the Dao generates."*
Undifferentiated primordial *qi*, hence *"One."*
*"One generates Two"*—
clear and turbid separate, yin and yang manifest.
*"Two generates Three"*—
the Two *qi* operate the Three Realms.
*"Three generates all things"*—
the round Heaven covers above,
the square Earth bears below,
Humanity governs between—
what thing does not arise?

**Master Chéng’s Commentary:**
One is the primordial *qi*.
Two is yin and yang.
Three is Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.
All things are all sentient and insentient beings.
The Supreme Dao’s mysterious origin,
its essence transcending form and name,
descending from its root,
first generating primordial *qi*,
then from primordial *qi* transforming into yin and yang.
Thus, yang *qi* ascends, clear and pure, becoming Heaven,
yin *qi* descends, turbid and heavy, becoming Earth.
The Two *qi* ascending and descending,
harmonious *qi* becomes Humanity—
the Three Realms arise,
then all things are generated in sequence,
to illustrate the Dao’s power of generous lending.

---
**Second: Displaying the Nature of Things and Exhorting Adherence to Harmony**

All things embrace yin while cradling yang,
harmonious *qi* as their balance.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Gloss:**
All things, by receiving yin and yang’s harmonious *qi*,
are generated—
thus they embrace yin and cradle yang,
nurturing harmonious *qi* as their gentleness.

**Emperor Xuánzōng’s Citation:**
Things, in their generation,
rely on yin and yang’s harmonious *qi* to be complete—
they must bear yin and embrace yang,
cherish harmonious *qi* as their gentleness.
Thus, Guangchéngzǐ instructed the Yellow Emperor:
*"I guard the One and embrace harmony,
thus my cultivation has reached twelve hundred years,
yet my form has never decayed."*
It is known that primordial *qi*, harmonious and gentle,
is what all creatures depend upon.
Laozi cites this to show:
since humanity abandons harmonious *qi* to generate,
*qi* is the foundation of life—
thus, one must preserve gentleness and weakness,
this is preserving the root.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
All things embrace yin while facing yang—
all things without fail embrace yin and turn toward yang,
their hearts returning to the sun.

The harmonious *qi* of the **Chong** is the foundation of all things—
within every creature lies primordial *qi*,
which, when balanced and gentle, sustains life.
As in the chest where essence is stored,
or in bones where marrow resides,
or in plants where hollow spaces allow *qi* to flow—
it is through this void and *qi* that longevity is attained.

**Master Róng says:**
If yang *qi* is hot and solitary,
it cannot generate life;
if yin *qi* is cold and lone,
it cannot form shape.
Thus, one must align with the **Great Dao** to harmonize it,
borrow the **Chong** *qi* to balance it—
this is how life is sustained.

**Master Chéng’s Exegesis:**
All things bear yin and embrace yang—
*bear* means to turn away, *embrace* means to face.
Yang is life, yin is death.
All things, sentient or not,
without fail turn away from yin and toward yang,
cherishing life and shunning death—
yet though they shun death, they cannot escape it,
and though they love life, they never fully attain it.
The Sage pities them, thus below follows the discourse on eternal life.

The **Chong** *qi* is harmony—
*Chong* means central, *he* means compliant.
To seek immortality, one must hold the heart upright,
practicing humility, gentleness, and weakness—
this is the way of eternal life.
Hence it is said below:
*"The rigid and strong are doomed to death,
the gentle and weak are destined to life."*

**Third Discourse on Gentle Weakness as the Foundation of Practice:**
What humanity despises—
the titles *Naolǎo Bùgǔ*—
are adopted by kings and nobles as their own.
**御注:** All things rely on the harmonious *qi* of the **Chong** as their root,
and those who preserve its gentle weakness must cultivate humility.
Thus, though kings and nobles hold the highest rank,
they adopt the titles *Naolǎo Bùgǔ*—
for humility and gentleness are their foundation.

**御疏:** The **Chong** *qi* is gentle and weak,
the root of life—
thus kings and nobles uphold humility to reinforce this principle.
*Naolǎo Bùgǔ* are terms of misfortune,
not titles of honor,
yet they are embraced by kings and nobles—
this is the ultimate in humility.
Kings and nobles are the models of civilization,
their fate determining life and death for all under heaven.
If they do not uphold gentleness to secure the realm,
the people will not follow.
Thus, they take humility as their root,
to achieve their towering virtue.

**Master Hé Shànggōng says:**
*Naolǎo Bùgǔ*—terms of ill omen—
are adopted by kings and nobles as their titles,
for they embody humility,
conforming to emptiness, harmony, and gentleness.

**Master Róng says:**
Those who embrace the harmonious **Chong** *qi*
hold neither preference nor aversion.
If one strays from the **One Principle**,
love and hatred arise.
Yet those who cling to titles of wealth and honor
do not delight in *Naolǎo Bùgǔ*—
only the Daoist kings and nobles
preserve themselves through these names,
for humility and retreat are their essence.

**Master Chéng’s Exegesis:**
Loneliness and widowhood are misfortunes,
yet kings and nobles adopt them as their titles—
this shows that nobility lies in embracing what is low,
and exaltation rests on what is humble.
Thus, those who seek cultivation must govern their hearts with humility and compliance.

Things may be diminished yet flourish,
or increased yet decline.
**御注:** Those who diminish themselves are benefited by others;
those who seek self-gain are diminished by others.
Thus, those who submit to the **Dao** are good at yielding,
and gentleness holds the power of virtue.
The titles *Naolǎo Bùgǔ* are fitting.

**御疏:** *Gu* (故) continues the previous thought.
*Shǔn* means to belittle or disparage.
Kings and nobles adopt the titles *Naolǎo Bùgǔ* to disparage themselves,
and thus the people joyfully promote them,
revering and serving them—
their governance is thereby strengthened.
Or, if they enrich themselves while in power,
