**Chapter 64: *Its Ease in Holding Firm***

This chapter follows the previous one because, though the earlier passage clearly warns against the perils of sin, its guidance on practice remains incomplete. Thus, this chapter reiterates its meaning in four distinct ways: first, by teaching a method to subdue the initial mind; second, by offering an analogy to show how sin arises from subtle beginnings; third, by revealing how sentient beings, lost in delusion, stray from truth and lose their essence; and fourth, by citing the Sage’s example to demonstrate the path of learning.

**First Method: Subduing the Initial Mind**

The earth remains unmoving—its *virtue* of *Kun* brings enduring stillness,
Mountains and peaks stand firm—deep roots anchor them forever.

Those lost in the fourfold delusion’s realm,
About to wander the fivefold turbid crossroads—
None can match the ease of holding firm what is already settled,
For what is subtle may yet be scattered.

Just as a tree of ten *chi* grows from a hair’s tip,
And a nine-tiered tower rises from a single shovelful of earth,
A thousand-*li* journey begins beneath the first step—
What is small must grow great.
Thus, the roots of sin deepen gradually,
And evil becomes transgression.
Like layered towers expanding ever wider,
One must clear away the darkness of ignorance
Before venturing into the Dao’s profound realm.
Do not be like Emperor Wu of Han, whose schemes failed,
Nor like one whose flesh is plentiful but marrow scarce,
Failing to uphold Laozi’s precepts.
A hollow belly and empty heart—
Even wild grass proves too much to tame,
Let alone the scattered currents of emotion and desire.
One must uproot them early,
Lest they spread unchecked,
And thus align with the natural order of all things,
In harmony with the Dao of eternal life.

**Its Ease in Holding Firm**
*Imperial Commentary*: "Its ease in holding firm" means "its ease in preventing what has not yet arisen." When a person’s true nature is serene and still, and one seeks to grasp and hold it—before desire even stirs, before its signs appear—one can plan to cut it off, ensuring it never arises. This is what is meant by "ease."

*Imperial Exegesis*: *An* (安) means *stillness*; *chi* (持) means *to grasp*. When a person’s innate nature is pure and untouched by external influences, yet stirred by sensory objects into boundless craving, now we clarify that in the moment before desire arises—when the mind is still and unscattered—it is easy to grasp and hold. Hence, *"its ease in holding firm."*

*River-Upper Master (严君平)*: Governing the body and the state—what is serene is easy to uphold.

*Li Rong* (李荣): *"Its ease in holding firm"* and *"its ease in preventing what has not yet arisen"*—*an* (安) means *stillness*; *wei zhao* (未兆) means *the stirrings have not yet formed*. It is difficult to stop calamity and evil once they manifest, but if one seeks to remove evil, one must act before it stirs. If one seeks to prevent disaster, one must hold firm in stillness. When evil’s signs have not yet appeared, there is no need to plot—disaster will not arise naturally. This is what is called the conduct of the superior sage in preventing calamity.

*Master Cheng’s Exegesis*: *An* (安) means *stillness*. For those cultivating the Dao, when the mind is tranquil and no thoughts have yet arisen, this is the most opportune time for cultivation and guard.

**Its Ease in Preventing What Has Not Yet Arisen**
*Imperial Exegesis*: *Zhao* (兆) means *sprouting, emerging*; *mou* (谋) means *to plan*. When desire is about to arise but has not yet taken form, planning to cut it off is also very easy. Hence, *"its ease in preventing what has not yet arisen."*

*River-Upper Master*: When the signs of desire and calamity have not yet appeared, it is easy to plan their cessation.

*Master Cheng’s Exegesis*: *Zhao* (兆) means *form, manifestation*; *mou* (谋) means *to devise*. Even if the mind has stirred but not yet grasped the object, and no form has yet appeared in the senses, one must immediately withdraw the mind to stillness. Since the deed has not yet been completed, it is easy to plan and consider.

**Its Fragility, Easy to Shatter**
*Imperial Commentary*: *"Its fragility, easy to shatter"* and *"its subtlety, easy to disperse"*—when desire first takes root, it is still weak and fragile. Those who can sever it find it easy to break, for when calamity first stirs, its signs are still faint. If one seeks to prevent it, its subtlety makes it easy to disperse.

*Imperial Exegesis*: When desire has already stirred but is still soft and not yet hardened, to remove it is easy to dissolve and break.

*River-Upper Master*: When calamity has not yet sprouted and desire has not yet taken form, it is like something fragile and easy to remove.

*Li Rong*: *"Its fragility, easy to shatter"* and *"its subtlety, easy to disperse"*—when sin is minor, it is easy to extinguish; when evil grows, it is hard to remove. If one cannot prevent it before it stirs, one must restrain it in its fragility and subtlety. This is the conduct of the middle sage in eliminating and dispersing evil.

*Master Cheng’s Exegesis*: *"Its fragility, easy to shatter"* and *"its subtlety, easy to disperse"*—*cui* (脆) means *hollow, like a gourd’s unripe fruit, soft and easy to break*. When the initial mind first stirs, it is just so: the karmic seeds are still shallow, hence easy to disperse.

**Its Subtlety, Easy to Disperse**
*Imperial Exegesis*: *Wei* (微) means *subtle*. When calamity first stirs faintly, before it grows great, preventing it at its origin makes it easy to disperse.

*River-Upper Master*: When the matter has not yet become apparent, what is subtle is easy to disperse.

**Act Before It Exists**
*Imperial Commentary*: The reason holding firm and preventing what has not yet arisen is easy is that one must cultivate and remove it *before* it takes form.

*Imperial Exegesis*: *Wei* (为) means *to cultivate and remove*. This sentence explains the two preceding ones—*"its ease in holding firm"* and *"its ease in preventing what has not yet arisen."* The meaning is: when desire has not yet arisen, one must cultivate and cut it off, ensuring evil does not take root. Hence, *"act before it exists."*

*River-Upper Master*: If one seeks to act, one must block its sprouting at the very beginning.

*Li Rong*: This is what is meant by *"its ease in holding firm."*

*Master Cheng’s Exegesis*: *Wei* (为) means *to cultivate and practice*. For those on the path, cultivation and guard must begin *before* defilement arises. This explains *"its ease in holding firm."*

**Prevent Before It Becomes Chaos**
*Imperial Commentary*: This follows *"its fragility, easy to shatter"* and *"its subtlety, easy to disperse."* The reason it is easy is that one must remove it *before* it becomes calamity and chaos.

*Imperial Exegesis*: This sentence explains the two preceding ones—*"its fragility, easy to shatter"* and *"its subtlety, easy to disperse."* The reason it is easy is that even if desire has arisen, it is still fragile and subtle, not yet having become calamity and chaos, hence easy to rectify.

「**River Master Cheng** said: In governing oneself and governing the realm, when chaos has not yet arisen, one must *preemptively close its gate*.

**Li Rong** said: This is what is meant by *"its fragility, easy to shatter."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: *Chaos* refers to the entanglement of afflictions—when one is already ensnared by karmic bonds, the mind becomes obscured and disordered. Now, though the mind may arise and be defiled by external objects, it has not yet reached the point where it must be addressed, making it easy to govern. This explains *"its subtlety, easy to disperse."*

**Prevent Before It Becomes Chaos**
**The Way of Rectification Begins in the Unmanifest**
**River Master Cheng** said: A tree thick enough to encircle with one’s arms begins as a tiny sprout; a nine-tiered tower rises from a single shovelful of earth; a journey of a thousand *li* begins with a single step. This is what is meant by *"its ease in holding firm."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: The tree that grows to be encircled by arms originates from a single hair’s width of a sprout—this illustrates how the three paths of defilement arise from a single thought. The reason a tree is used as an analogy is that, from small to great, it can eventually block the sunlight, just as the defilement of the mind, from subtle to deep-rooted, can obscure one’s true nature. If one considers this tree as arising from emptiness—speaking of emptiness, the tree itself is not inherently existent—it is because the four dusts of sense perception do not solidify into form.

Afflictions, too, arise from emptiness—speaking of emptiness, they are not inherently existent. The nine-tiered tower rises from a single shovelful of earth—just as a tower of nine levels begins with a single basket of soil, so the calamity of the nine nights of suffering originates from a single defiled thought. This admonishes all learners to guard against negligence with utmost caution.

A peak a hundred *ren* high begins with a single step—since seven *chi* make one *ren*, a mountain peak a hundred *ren* tall starts from the first step. The suffering of the eightfold path arises from the defilement of the mind. The analogy of the nine-tiered tower illustrates that afflictions have already taken root, while the hundred *ren* peak further warns that even greater calamity awaits if the defilement continues unchecked.

**The Third Analogy Clarifies the Delusion of Sentient Beings**
**Those Who Act Are Doomed to Fail; Those Who Cling Are Doomed to Lose**
**River Master Cheng** said: Those who act are doomed to fail—if one acts upon external matters, one abandons natural spontaneity; if one acts upon moral principles, one abandons virtue; if one acts upon sensory pleasures, one abandons clarity of mind.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: The supreme Dao is void and profound, requiring neither action nor attachment. Yet ordinary minds are inverted, clinging to action and attachment, which bring peril and ruin. Hence, it is said that *"those who act are doomed to fail"*—because attachment goes against reality, it is said that *"those who cling are doomed to lose."*

**The Fourth Section Cites the Sage to Validate the Teaching**
Thus, the Sage acts without doing (*wuwei*), hence there is no failure; the Sage does not cling, hence there is no loss.

**The Sage’s Natural Way**
**River Master Cheng** said: The Sage acts without doing (*wuwei*), hence there is no failure. The Sage does not adorn with empty rhetoric, hence there is no failure. The Sage does not indulge in sensory pleasures, hence there is no depletion. The Sage does not cling, hence there is no loss. The Sage possesses virtue to teach the foolish and wealth to aid the poor, yet retains nothing for oneself, hence there is nothing lost to others.

**Li Rong** said: Ordinary people are blind to immediate matters, hence they incur failures and losses. The Sage, however, perceives the unseen before its manifestation and thus avoids the perils of action.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: The Sage embodies the Dao and acts without doing (*wuwei*), hence there is no obstruction or failure. The Sage does not cling to illusions, hence does not lose their true nature. Ordinary people, when engaging in good deeds, often falter when success is near—greedy for status, fond of reputation, indulgent in luxury, and complacent in abundance—thus bringing ruin upon themselves.

**River Master Cheng** said: *From* (从) means *to act* (为). When ordinary people pursue affairs, they often nearly achieve their moral merits but then, through greed for position and love of fame, through extravagance and arrogance, through indulgence and fullness, bring ruin upon themselves.

「**Master Róng** said: *几* (near) means *near completion*. Ordinary people, when doing evil, cannot remove it early; when evil deeds are nearly complete, they naturally self-destruct. If one could align with the Sage, abandoning danger and seeking safety, they would never commit wrongdoing, nor incur blame, and thus would neither gain nor lose—what ruin or success could there be?

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: *几* (near) means *near completion*. Ordinary people cling to affairs of action (*youwei*), their minds restless and competitive, clinging to distinctions and grasping at gains—utterly lacking foresight. They always wish for near completion, yet have beginnings without endings, hence their frequent failures. The *Book of Songs* says: *"None lack a beginning, few attain to the end."* To be cautious at the end as at the start ensures no ruinous affairs.

**Imperial Commentary**: To be cautious at the end as at the start, maintaining unwavering constancy, then there will be no failed undertakings.

**Imperial Exegesis**: This is the Elder Master’s reiteration of his admonition. If a person can be cautious at the end as at the beginning, steadfast from start to finish, then there will be no failed undertakings.

**River Master Cheng** said: The end should be like the beginning; one must not slacken.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: This admonishes studious people to fortify their resolve, maintaining steadfastness from start to finish—how could there be failure? Among the Six Perfections (*liùdù*), this is the fourth: *renunciation* (*zìxìng*). Hence, the Sage desires not to desire, and does not value difficult-to-obtain wealth.

**Imperial Commentary**: Difficult-to-obtain wealth refers to what lies beyond one’s natural inclinations. Now, the Sage, in not desiring to desire, does not pursue what is beyond their nature, always preserving their spontaneity—this is not valuing difficult-to-obtain wealth.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: This illustrates the Sage’s conduct to repudiate the common. Difficult-to-obtain wealth—internally refers to what is beyond one’s natural inclinations, externally refers to pearls, rhinoceros horns, and treasures. The Sage, in not desiring to desire, neither internally pursues what is beyond their nature nor externally seeks wealth that burdens their virtue.

**River Master Cheng** said: Hence, the Sage desires not to desire: the Sage desires what others do not desire—others seek fame and display, the Sage desires obscurity; others desire ornamentation, the Sage desires simplicity; others value outward appearance, the Sage values inner virtue. The Sage does not covet difficult-to-obtain wealth, hence does not dazzle with gaudy attire nor demean stone while venerating jade.

**Master Róng** said: Hence, the Sage desires not to desire, not valuing difficult-to-obtain wealth; they study without studying, anticipating the faults of others. Ordinary emotions follow desires, demeaning the Dao while valuing wealth. The Sage is not greedy, cherishing truth while lightly esteeming treasures. If one cultivates not for self but for others, studies not for personal gain but for the benefit of others, then avarice brings misfortune, and striving for fame invites censure. The Sage, without desire, abandons worldly gain; ceasing study, they forget fame. They do not flaunt their own abilities but guard against the faults of others.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: Hence, the Sage desires not to desire, not valuing difficult-to-obtain wealth; they study without studying, correcting the faults of others. The Sage’s illumination comes from the heavens, differing from common wisdom; they perceive all phenomena as empty and illusory, seeing no objects worth praising. Thus, within desire, they do not perceive desire’s form—since they do not desire to desire, why would they value jade and silk?

Again, they grasp the truth of reality without distinction, hence they forget study. To study is not to study; not to study is to study. Studying differs from not studying; not studying differs from studying. Hence the *Sūtra of the Western Ascension* (*Xīshēng Jīng*) says: *"My learning has no learning; only then can I illuminate nature."*

To anticipate, means to prevent. Ordinary people cling rigidly to affairs of action, unable to forget study, hence the Sage speaks of "studying without studying" to prevent the faults of all beings.

**Imperial Commentary**: "Studying without studying" corrects the faults of others, aiding the spontaneous nature of all things without daring to act. The Sage does not seek excessive learning, hence in "studying without studying," they aim to return others’ excessive learning to its roots, aiding nature’s inherent essence, thus not daring to indulge in worldly desires or common studies.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: The common folk value difficult-to-obtain wealth, hence they feign cleverness and flaunt their attainments, studying what lies beyond their natural inclinations. The Sage does not seek excessive learning, always preserving nature’s inherent essence—this is "studying without studying," returning others’ excessive learning to its roots.

**River Master Cheng** said: "Studying without studying"—the Sage studies what others cannot study. Others study deceit and cunning; the Sage studies nature. Others study governance of the world; the Sage studies self-cultivation, guarding the true Dao.

To correct the faults of others—ordinary people study what is superficial, taking the end as the beginning. The superficial is indeed the ornament. To correct means to return to the root.

To aid the spontaneous nature of all things without daring to act—

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: To aid means to assist and guide. Nature is the inherent essence of things. All beings, deluded and misguided, lose their original essence. The Sage, with compassionate persuasion, encourages study without action, intending to assist and guide the true nature of things. Thus, they do not dare to act in worldly studies or excessive desires.

**River Master Cheng** said: To aid the spontaneous nature of all things, teaching people to return to reality—this is to assist the inherent essence of all things. Yet they do not dare to act. The Sage’s movements follow naturally, never daring to contrive, lest they stray from the root.

**Master Róng** said: The nature of things is rooted in spontaneity. Desires corrupt with attachment, burdening truth; study obstructs with distinctions, hindering the Dao. Thus, the source of unity is obscured, and the true nature of the Way becomes difficult to discern. Without entering *wuwei*, one only returns to ruin. The Sage follows nature’s inherent essence, aids all things to preserve truth, never daring to act in contrived affairs, guiding them to return to emptiness and stillness.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: To aid means to assist and guide. All beings inherently possess nature’s upright essence, yet they are deluded and misguided, losing the Dao and abandoning truth. Now, the Sage seeks to uphold the method of "studying without studying," guiding them to return to their roots. Though the Sage exhausts principles and fathoms nature, they also act without contrivance and without failing to act.»

「Now, when it is said that the Sage does not act, it is because they also wish to assist and guide the multitude, restoring them to nature’s inherent essence. Hence, they say, *"do not dare to act."*

**Chapter Sixty-Five: The Sage’s Skill in the Dao**
The reason for this chapter’s sequence after the previous is that the prior chapter spoke of the Sage abandoning study yet still able to assist and guide all beings. Therefore, this chapter follows to reveal those who practice study and engage in beneficent deeds—within this chapter, its meaning unfolds in three distinctions:
1) To cite antiquity and validate the present, employing eloquent discourse to clarify;
2) To discern excellence and mediocrity, setting forth models for emulation;
3) To invert convention and align with truth, demonstrating its profound allure.

1) **Citing Antiquity and Validating the Present, Employing Eloquent Discourse to Clarify**
The Dao’s profound origin is subtle, its mysteries reaching the utmost purity. It eludes the ears and eyes, rendering perception and hearing as ineffectual as those of a fool. Confucius uncovered it yet remained unaware, Yan Hui conversed with it yet failed to grasp. Thus, governing with wisdom is like the harm of thieves and bandits; cultivating the Dao with *wuwei* allows each to attain their own fulfillment. Is not this the standard form?

Then one understands that the true source of emptiness and purity, its principles penetrating beyond tranquil oblivion, the profound mystery of the *Chongxuan* (重玄), transcends the causes of mere non-existence. It is not something that can be imparted through mere exposition, nor is it within the grasp of those lost in error. The affairs of human conduct are indeed perilous, hence it is said:
*"When the ditch of Cao Gou was dug, the people were enslaved;
When Qin’s wealth was prized, its lineage fell into ruin.
Soaring before gathering, the phoenix calls from the high ridges;
Rushing yet not flying, the magpie withdraws to distant paths.
Acting against the natural order leads to loss,
Departing from the Dao leads to destruction.
If one can reverse their conduct with things,
Then they grasp the principle of great harmony."*

**The Sage’s Skill in the Dao Lies Not in Enlightening the People, But in Making Them Seem Foolish**
**Master He’s Commentary**: The ancient Sage-rulers, skilled in the Dao, valued *wuwei* and tranquil simplicity—not flaunting their methods to enlighten the people, but guiding them toward purity, closing off their cleverness to restore them to their original simplicity, making them appear as foolish as they truly were.

**Master He’s Exegesis**: The ancient Sage-rulers, who excelled in using the Dao for transformation, prized *wuwei* and tranquil simplicity. They did not display their methods to enlighten the people, lest cleverness and deceit flourish, but instead led them to purity and simplicity, making them appear as though they were foolish.

**Master He Shangong said**: The ancient Sage-rulers, skilled in the Dao, spoke of those who used the Dao to cultivate their own bodies and govern their states. They did not enlighten the people with the Dao, nor did they teach them with cleverness, lest they become deceptive and cunning. Instead, they sought to make the people appear simple and unassuming, free from deceit and artifice.

**Master Yan said**: The ancient Sage-rulers, guarding their own simplicity, made their subjects return to natural purity. Without resorting to coercive laws or punishments, the people naturally conformed to transformation. If they did not practice the Dao of emptiness and stillness, but instead relied solely on cunning and cleverness, the more intelligence there was, the greater the chaos. Hence, they were difficult to govern.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: *治* (govern) is the same as *理* (transform). *智* (wisdom) refers to distinctions and discernments. The reason all beings are difficult to transform is that their minds are too occupied with distinctions, unable to embrace emptiness and stillness. Hence, they are hard to guide.

2) **Discerning Excellence and Mediocrity, Setting Forth Models for Emulation**
Thus, governing with wisdom is the thief of the state.
**Master He’s Commentary**: *以* (to use) means to employ. When a ruler appoints clever and wise ministers to govern the state, their cleverness will inevitably lead to the creation of laws, and laws will breed deceit. Hence, it is said that wisdom is the thief of the state.

**Master He’s Exegesis**: *以* (to use) means to employ. *贼* (thief) refers to harm. When a ruler employs ministers who are cunning and deceitful to govern the state, their cleverness will give rise to schemes and stratagems. Once these schemes are put into use, falsehood and artifice will flourish, and the Dao will be abandoned, causing harm to the state. Hence, it is said that wisdom is the thief of the state.

**Master He Shangong said**: If clever and wise individuals are entrusted with governing the state, they will inevitably stray from the Dao, arbitrarily imposing rewards and punishments, becoming the thieves of the state.

**Master Yan said**: Thus, governing with wisdom is the thief of the state. Not governing with wisdom is the virtue of the state. Cleverness and cunning deeply harm the people, making wisdom the thief of the state. Pure simplicity without cleverness, letting things transform naturally, each attending to their own affairs, the people finding joy in their lives and families secure, harming neither others nor themselves, ruler and subjects both at ease—this is the virtue of the state.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: Thus, governing with wisdom is the thief of the state; not governing with wisdom is the virtue of the state. If one uses penetrating insight to govern with cleverness, they deviate from natural harmony and align with harm like a thief. The former is reversed, the latter is harmonious—how can such discourse be considered similar?

**Response**:
The earlier statement of "reversed" means that it is not reversed but instead is truly reversed. The later statement of "harmonious" also means it is not harmonious but truly harmonious. If it is truly harmonious, it does not deviate from the reversed; if it is truly reversed, it does not deviate from the harmonious. What then is there to object to?»

「The Sage asks: The Classic speaks of *Great Harmony*—does harmony also have degrees of greatness and smallness?

The Master responds: When harmony is opposed to defiance, it may be small. But now, neither defying nor harmonizing, yet it is called *not* harmonious—harmony does not differ from defiance, nor does defiance oppose harmony. Thus, the Classic speaks in silence, following only the Dao, blending with the light and merging with the dust, ever abiding in harmony with principle. Whether harmony or non-harmony, non-harmony or harmony, all are simultaneously harmonious. Hence, there is neither harmony nor non-harmony, nor is there a lack of harmony while still being able to lack non-harmony, nor even a negation of non-harmony—this is why it is called *Great Harmony*.

**Chapter Sixty-Six of the *King of the Hundred Valleys***—
This chapter follows the previous one, which elucidates the *Mysterious Virtue* of the Sage, reversing the profane and aligning with the Dao. Thus, this chapter further expounds the practice of harmonizing with the Dao.

Within this chapter, three distinct teachings unfold:
1. **The Parable**—to demonstrate *emptiness and forgetfulness*,
2. **The Doctrine**—to illuminate *humility and retreat*,
3. **The Conclusion**—to praise the power of *softness and weakness*.

**1. The Parable—Demonstrating Emptiness and Forgetfulness**
The eastward-flowing rivers all converge and pay homage to the great sea. Spring gives rise to all things, each shaping itself naturally. Why, then, does the sea possess emptiness, and the rivers descend? The sea, though not empty, is the *King of the Hundred Valleys* because it abides in the low places.

The Sage uses this as an analogy: casting aside fame and desires, utterly forgetting right and wrong, embracing the multitude with boundless ease, illuminating the minute dust within the mind’s breadth—all actions are humble, all positions are yielding. Thus, the people and the heavens rejoice in their adoration, who could dare to contend?

A lingering presence in the rear is not a boast of prowess; a snake’s foot, when added, spoils the whole. Yet if one were to snatch the wine first, they would know the *Mysterious Extremes* operate in secrecy. The Sage’s enduring stillness and retreat bring constant ease, while *firm and white* arguments are but empty noise—those who are blind to the end shall never comprehend.

**Shared Work**—what strength did he possess? He shattered the Heavenly Pillar and brought calamity upon himself. **The Qin Emperor**—what folly did he commit? He pierced the earth for markets and invited disaster. Unable to embrace softness and enlighten the distant, they grew rigid and harsh—how could they know that their realm would crumble, their kin perish, their lives extinguished, and the world delivered into the hands of common men? Such is their dire fate.

As **Yang Xiong** said: This is because they did not practice emptiness.

The sea is able to be the *King of the Hundred Valleys* because it excels in descending. Hence, the sea abides in low places, and all rivers pay homage to it, just as people flock to their king.

**Master He’s Commentary**: The sea is able to command the rivers to converge and pay homage because it excels in dwelling in the lowest places, governing the currents.

**Master He’s Exegesis**: The sea, by dwelling in the lowest places, becomes the *King of the Hundred Valleys* to which all rivers pay homage. Thus, the *I Ching* says: *"The Earthly Dao transforms fullness into flowing humility."* This is the parable given.

The Earthly Dao, through humility, receives the rivers’ tribute. The Sage, through humility, draws the people’s devotion—none weary of approaching.

**Master He Shang Gong** says: The sea is able to be the *King of the Hundred Valleys* because it excels in descending. Thus, the sea, through its lowliness, becomes the gathering place of all rivers. Just as people flock to their king, so the rivers pay homage to the sea. The sea’s ability to be the *King of the Hundred Valleys* is due to its lowliness.

**Master Rong** says: This parable shows that the sea, by dwelling in low places, becomes the *King of the Hundred Valleys*, illustrating that the Sage’s humility makes them the sovereign of all under Heaven.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis**: *King* means *direction*. The *Hundred Valleys* are like the *Hundred Rivers*. The sea is called the *King of the Hundred Rivers* because it dwells in the low, sunken places. If a person retreats in body and humbles in speech, empties themselves and yields to all, they too shall be the refuge of the common folk—thus they become the *King of the Hundred Valleys*.

This concludes the parable’s meaning, hence the Classic says: *"The sea is the King of the Hundred Rivers."*

**2. The Doctrine—Illuminating Humility and Retreat**
Thus, the Sage desires to be above others by first humbling their speech.

**Master He’s Commentary**: The Sage, desiring to be above others, humbles their speech. Desiring to precede others, they retreat their own body. Hence, though they occupy the highest position, others do not feel burdened; though they stand at the forefront, others do not suffer harm. Humility is the handle of virtue—when one uses it, its brilliance only grows. By humbling their speech, the people joyfully submit; by retreating their body, the people willingly approach. Thus, though they occupy the highest position, others do not feel burdened; though they stand at the forefront, others do not suffer harm.

**Master He’s Exegesis**: This combines the parable. The Sage, desiring to be above others, humbles their speech. Does the Sage truly wish to dwell above others while humbling their speech? No—only the Sage knows that fullness invites loss, so they speak in humility and yield in name, descending below all things. Yet their vast virtue and grand achievements naturally elevate them above others.

**Master He Shang Gong** says: The Sage, desiring to be above others, seeks to stand above the people. By humbling their speech, they follow the sea’s example, dwelling in humility.

**Master Rong** says: The Sage, desiring to be above the people, humbles their speech. Desiring to precede the people, they retreat their body. Thus, though they occupy the highest position, others do not feel burdened; though they stand at the forefront, the people do not suffer harm. By dwelling humbly beneath all, their virtue draws them upward. By retreating to let others pass, their embrace of the Dao renders them without desire or action—utterly empty, utterly still, forgetting the heart and casting aside cleverness, corpse-like in silent mystery. Such is the governance of the world by the *Highest Virtue*.

By this standard, superiority and inferiority become evident. If governing the state is thus, then so too should one’s personal conduct be. Not governing with cleverness is the state’s blessing.

**Master He’s Commentary**: If the ruler does not employ cunning ministers but instead seeks those of pure virtue, allowing them to rest in the Dao of non-action and practice the *Great Simplicity*, the natural harmony will flourish, and this is the state’s blessing.

**Master He’s Exegesis**: The ruler, not entrusting themselves to cunning ministers but seeking those of pure virtue, sits in the Dao of non-action and walks in the *Great Simplicity*, achieving harmony and ease—this is the state’s blessing.»

**Master He (Riverbank Master) says:**
If one does not allow the wise and clever to govern the state’s affairs, then the people will uphold uprightness, not indulging in deceit. The ruler and subjects will be close, and the sovereign and ministers will act in concert—this is the state’s blessing. Knowing these two principles is also the standard.

**Master He’s Commentary:**
To employ cunning ministers brings harm to the people, while to entrust oneself to those of pure virtue brings blessing to the state. If the ruler knows these two principles and delegates to ministers of pure virtue, this becomes the standard and model.

**Master He’s Exegesis:**
The two principles refer to using wisdom and not using wisdom. The standard is the model, the law is the method. The ruler knows that using wisdom is like a thief, while not using it brings blessing—thus one must remove the thief and take the blessing. Only then can they be the standard and model for governing the state.

**Master He (Riverbank Master) says:**
The two principles refer to wisdom and lack of wisdom. Those who habitually know wisdom as a thief and lack of wisdom as a blessing are the standard and model for both personal cultivation and governing the state.

**Master Rong says:**
Knowing these two principles is also the standard. Habitually knowing the standard is called *Highest Virtue*. *Highest Virtue* is profound and far-reaching, contrary to all things, and only then does one attain the *Great Order*.

Using wisdom or not using wisdom—these are the two. Using it brings harm; not using it brings no injury. If one knows that the people suffer no harm when not using wisdom, then one knows the standard and model for governing the state. Knowing the standard and model, one’s foundation is firm and the realm secure—this is the subtlety of virtue.

The subtlety of virtue is unfathomable and deepens daily; its pursuit is boundless and distant. All men use wisdom, yet this one alone uses simplicity, for he is contrary to all things.

Not opposing the nature of things, but letting them unfold naturally—this is the *Great Order*.

It is also said that the Dao is originally empty and mysterious, while the worldly ways are coarse and defiled. To conform to the world and seek the Dao is to lose the true; to oppose the world and cultivate virtue is to enter the subtle. Entering the subtle, there is neither "can" nor "cannot"; returning to the true, there is neither "blocked" nor "unblocked." Since its response is boundless and formless, it attains the *Great Order* and equality.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
The two principles refer to the earlier discussion of wisdom and lack of wisdom. Those who use wisdom as a thief and lack of wisdom as virtue can serve as the standard for personal cultivation and the grand principles for governing the state. Habitually knowing the standard is called *Highest Virtue*.

**Master He’s Commentary:**
*Highest Virtue* is profound, subtle, and far-reaching. The ruler who habitually knows these two principles as the standard and model possesses the profound and mysterious subtlety of virtue.

**Master He (Riverbank Master) says:**
*Highest Virtue* is profound and far-reaching. The person of *Highest Virtue* is profound beyond measure and distant beyond reach. Contrary to all things, the person of *Highest Virtue* opposes the world’s inclination to benefit oneself, instead desiring to aid others. Only then does one attain the *Great Order*, which aligns with the natural Way of Heaven.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
*Highest Virtue* is profound and far-reaching, contrary to the world—this is called *Highest Virtue*. To exhaust the source and reach the utmost is called profound and far-reaching. The profound and far-reaching wisdom is contrary to worldly ways, hence one is contrary to all things. Only then does one attain the *Great Order*, which has two forms: one, aligning with the natural principles; two, conforming to worldly affairs. The former harmonizes with the subtle source; the latter descends with the dust.

**Question:** Earlier it says "contrary to things," yet later it says "aligning with worldly ways." If the text first says "contrary" and then "aligning," how can they be consistent?

**Answer:** The earlier "contrary" means contrary without being contrary; the later "aligning" means aligning without being aligning. Aligning without deviating from the contrary, and being contrary without breaking from alignment—what is there to object to?

**Question:** The scripture speaks of *Great Order*—does "order" also have degrees of greatness and smallness?

**Answer:** When "order" is contrasted with "disorder," even if it is small, here it is neither aligning nor disordering, yet called "not aligning." Aligning does not differ from disordering, nor does disordering conflict with aligning. Thus, in silent repose, one follows only the Dao, blending light with dust, and ever aligns with the natural principles. Whether called aligning or not aligning, not aligning or aligning, aligning or not aligning—all are aligning in their own time. Hence there is no aligning nor non-aligning, no non-aligning yet able to be non-aligning, nor is there a negation of non-aligning—this is why it is called *Great Order*.

**Chapter 66: The King of All Valleys (江海为百谷王)**
This chapter follows the previous one, which expounded the person of *Highest Virtue*, contrary to the world yet aligning with the Dao. Thus, this chapter further displays the practice of aligning with the Dao.

Within this chapter, three themes unfold: first, an analogy to illustrate *emptiness-forgetting*; second, a teaching to demonstrate *humility-retreat*; third, a concluding reflection on the power of gentleness.

**First: An Analogy to Illustrate *Emptiness-forgetting***
The eastern rivers all flow toward the sea, converging in their reverence for the great waters. In spring, all things arise, each taking shape in the natural Way. Why is it that the natural Way can be empty, and the great sea can be humble, so that the rivers may become its king?

The sage uses this as a metaphor: great dismissal of sounds and colors, complete forgetting of right and wrong. Welcoming the multitude with boundless harmony, illuminating the fine dust within the heart—wherever one goes, one is humble; wherever one stands, one is gentle and lowly. Then Heaven and man gladly acclaim, and who can dispute it?

**First: An Analogy to Illustrate *Emptiness-forgetting***
The body, though placed behind, should not boast of its merit—like a serpent’s tail, it comes too late. When one seizes the wine and turns it upside down, one understands the profound subtleties of the Dao’s operations. In stillness and retreat, one finds enduring peace; the *firm-and-white* paradox is but idle chatter, and the mysteries of the end remain forever obscure.

What power did Gonggong possess? He shattered the Heavenly Pillar and left ruin behind. What folly did the Qin Emperor exhibit? He pierced the earth for profit and invited disaster. Unable to embrace gentleness and illuminate the distant, they grew rigid and harsh. How could they know that their nation would crumble, their family perish, their bodies slaughtered, and their kin extinguished—casting the world into the hands of common men, how bitter their fate!

As Yang Xiong said, *"It is not empty indeed."*

The reason the rivers and seas can reign as sovereigns over all valleys is that they excel in humility. Thus, the rivers and seas, through their lowly submission, become the *tributaries’ king*.

**Annotations:**
- *Emptiness-forgetting* (虚忘) / *humility-retreat* (谦退) / *firm-and-white* (坚白) / *tributaries’ king* (百谷王)

**Second: A Teaching to Demonstrate *Humility-retreat***
Therefore, the sage wishes to rise above others by speaking in humility. **Annotations:** *Humility-retreat* (谦退)

The *Commentary of the Master of the Riverbank* explains: Thus, the sage seeks to ascend above others by speaking in humility, and to lead them by placing himself behind. Hence, though he holds the highest position, others do not grow weary of him; though he stands at the forefront, none dare harm him. Humility is the handle of virtue, and nobility shines ever brighter. By speaking in humility, the people willingly follow, so he is not seen as burdensome in his elevation. By retreating in body, the people come as children, so he is not seen as a threat in his advance.

**Annotations:**
- *Master of the Riverbank* (河上公) / *handle of virtue* (德柄) / *nobility* (尊) / *bright* (光)

The *Grand Commentary* states: The sage does not truly wish to be above others; he merely embodies humility, placing himself behind while others advance. Thus, they naturally honor him as their leader.

The *Commentary of the Master of the Riverbank* further says: To rise above the people, the sage speaks in humility, following the model of the rivers and seas, dwelling in modesty.

Yang Xiong adds: Thus, the sage seeks to ascend above the people by speaking in humility, and to lead them by placing himself behind. Hence, though he holds the highest position, the people do not grow weary; though he stands at the forefront, the people are not harmed. He dwells beneath others with humility, yet his virtue earns him their elevation. He retreats in person to benefit others, yet his embrace of the Dao secures his revered place. The people willingly follow without feeling burdened, all loyal and filial—who would dare harm him?

The *Grand Commentary* elaborates: Though the sage stands above, the people do not grow weary because he is tranquil, unassuming, and free from excessive thought or desire. Thus, he governs as their ruler, easing their burdens and taxes so they labor lightly. Another interpretation: The sage’s benevolence extends to all things, so the people bear his rule without complaint.

Though he stands at the forefront, the people are not harmed. As their sovereign, he places himself before them, yet they sing and strike the earth in joy, the world at peace. His benefits are vast and abundant, without harm. Another interpretation: The sage’s virtue is boundless, the people gladly acclaim him, cherishing his grace—how could they dare harm him?

**Third: A Concluding Reflection on the Power of Gentleness**
Thus, the world willingly honors him without growing weary.

**Commentary on the Gentle Sovereign’s Authority**
Because of his refusal to burden or harm, the world’s people willingly acclaim him as their sovereign without tiring.

**Explanatory Elucidation:**
The Sage’s virtue is vast and boundless, nurturing all things like spring’s warmth, shining forth like the sun. Since he neither burdens nor harms, the people joyfully acclaim him without tiring.

**Master He Shang’s Interpretation:**
The Sage’s kindness is profound and his love vast—he regards the people as his own children. Thus, the world willingly unites to honor him as sovereign, none wearying of him.

**Master Rong’s Reflection:**
Therefore, the world rejoices in acclaiming him without tiring, for he does not contend. Thus, none can contend with him. Those without virtue are universally despised, but those who embody the Way are all gladly honored. Practicing humility and yielding, he aligns with the transformations of all things—who would dare to contend with him?

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
Therefore, the world rejoices in acclaiming him without tiring, for he does not contend. Thus, none can contend with him. The reason the people gladly honor him as their sovereign without tiring is that he is ever modest and yielding, never contending with others. Having abandoned strife and embraced equality, all distinctions of right and wrong cease—who would dare to contend with one who does not contend? Thus, none can contend with him. Because he does not contend, none can contend with him.

**Commentary on the Sage’s Humility:**
The Sage is modest and retiring, not contending with others, so the world unites to honor him—who would dare to contend?

**Explanatory Elucidation:**
The world rejoices in honoring the Sage without tiring, for his words place others above him, and his actions place himself behind them. Since he does not vie for precedence, none can contend with the Sage’s refusal to compete.

**Master He Shang’s Interpretation:**
Because he does not contend, the world never tires of the Sage’s rule. This is because the Sage does not vie with others for precedence. Thus, none can contend with him. It is said that all people contend for action, but none contend with one who does not act.

---
**Chapter 67: On the Magnitude of the Dao**
This chapter follows the previous one, which expounded upon the Sage’s ability to be humble yet elevated. Thus, this chapter further elucidates his virtues and fully presents the Three Treasures.

Within this chapter, the meaning unfolds in five layers:
1. He does not boast, so he is vast and great.
2. He fully presents the Three Treasures, drawing all things to rely upon them.
3. He reiterates the Three Treasures, praising their efficacy.
4. He describes those who abandon the Three Treasures, sinking into death and life’s cycles.
5. He concludes with a grand eulogy to boundless compassion and unparalleled virtue.

**First Layer: He Does Not Boast, So He Is Vast and Great**
The profound and mysterious Dao originated before the Five Agents, and the subtle True Principle permeates the essence of the Original Harmony. Its form is vast, its virtue profound—transcending the laws of sensory desire and severing the boundaries of mundane perception. The common folk see only what is near, yet he does not defy the depths of the mysterious. Thus, though called "great," he seems unremarkable. How could they know that the Three Treasures dwell in stillness, the True Vehicle daring not to lead? He ever guards humility and frugality.

Even the sage-king Wen of Zhou, though wise, initially failed to grasp the Way of mutual benefit, and Emperor Wen of Han, though brilliant, did not comprehend the parable of the stacked firewood. How much less can the ordinary and vulgar, the coarse and mundane, fathom the profundity of the Mysterious Dao or grasp the depths of its Original Source? If they do not scorn it, how could it be called the Great Way?

The world says my Dao is great, yet it seems unremarkable.
**Commentary:** *Xiào* (似) means "to resemble."

**Explanatory Elucidation:**
The world deems my Dao vast and boundless, yet it seems to resemble nothing. Thus, the following passage responds to this.

**Master He Shang’s Interpretation:**
The Old Master says the world considers my Dao great, yet I feign ignorance, appearing unremarkable.

**Master Rong’s Reflection:**
The world calls me great yet unremarkable. Only because it is great does it seem unremarkable. If it had long resembled something, it would be small indeed. The Old Master’s Dao is exalted in virtue and noble in power—truly worthy of being called great. Yet, he conceals his traces among the common, his presence hidden and inscrutable. He does not resemble the wise, nor does he resemble the foolish. Thus, he is called unremarkable.

*Not resembling* means lacking comparison. Only the greatest of sages has nothing to compare to. If form had fixed qualities, wisdom had constant measures, or the Dao had attainments, these would be the petty schemes of small-minded people—not the boundless communion of the great sage.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
The Old Master’s essence is naturally vast, his fruits perfectly realized, so the common folk universally revere him as the Great Sage. Why is this? Only because in dealing with others, he is modest and yielding, never boasting or scoffing. Thus, it is so.

Only because it is great does it seem unremarkable. If it had long resembled something, it would be small indeed.
**Commentary:** Only my Dao is supremely great, so it resembles nothing. If it were like the laws of past ages—having something to resemble—it would no longer be called great. It would have long been insignificant.

**Explanatory Elucidation:**
This explains why it seems unremarkable. Only because my Dao is vast and transcendent, beyond the grasp of ordinary perception, can it be called great. If it resembled anything—like the laws of past ages—it would lose its claim to greatness and become insignificant. These are petty, shallow teachings, no different from the common ways—how could they be called great?

*Ah!* (也夫) is an exclamatory particle.

**Master He Shang’s Interpretation:**
Only because it is great does it seem unremarkable. Only those whose virtue is truly great harm themselves by claiming distinction, so they feign folly, appearing unremarkable, making no distinctions, and not elevating themselves above others. If it had long resembled something—*xiào* (善), meaning "excellence"—if great scholars and wise ones, tall and self-exalted, practiced meticulous governance, such ways have long existed.

「Its subtlety, *ah!* (夫), is that those who speak of *xiào* (善, excellence) are but like petty men, not the noble. Only the wise uphold it.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Only because the Sage’s virtue is lofty and great does he not boast before things. If he boasted, he would be like the multitude of small-minded ones.

Master He Shang’s original text used the character *xiào* (肖), "not resembling" being akin to "not excellent" (不善). It means that all beings, unable to follow the excellent Dao/Way, are thus deemed unworthy by my greatness. Only through arrogance and haughtiness does my greatness fail to be excellent. If one can practice the excellent Dao/Way, they should instead be humbled and modest.

**The Third Section: Emphasizing the Three Treasures, urging all to take refuge therein.**
I possess the Three Treasures, safeguarding and upholding them.

○ **Master Yu’s Annotation:**
Though my Dao is great, it resembles nothing and lacks form, yet it holds these Three Practices, which are most precious. If one can steadfastly preserve, rely upon, and uphold them, they may govern themselves and the realm.

○ **Master Yu’s Commentary:**
This clarifies why it appears unremarkable: precisely because it possesses these Three Practices, differing from the common ways. Thus, Master Laozi says my Dao, though great, resembles nothing, yet these Three Treasures are most precious.

To you, my successor, you must preserve and uphold them, safeguarding them to cultivate virtue and govern the realm.

○ **Master He Shang’s Interpretation:**
Master Laozi speaks of my Three Treasures—compassion, frugality, and not daring to lead the world first—embraced and upheld.

○ **Rong’s Explanation:**
I possess Three Treasures: first, compassion (慈); second, frugality (俭); third, not daring to lead the world first (不敢为天下先). The common world values profit, esteeming it with seven rarities. The Dao lies in truth, weighing it with the Three Treasures. The meaning of the Three Treasures is not something sought externally; if one can be benevolent and wise toward all things, cherishing life and abhorring slaughter, this is the meaning of compassion.

To reduce taxes and lighten burdens, to be cautious in self-conduct and moderate in expenditure, neither extravagant nor ostentatious—this is the meaning of frugality.

To forget oneself for the sake of others, to retreat and guide them, not daring to lead the world first—this is the meaning of humility. To uphold these practices and cultivate virtue, applying these three principles, brings peace to the realm and tranquility to the family. Such is the greatness of this treasure.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
Thus, the Sage’s virtue is lofty and great, yet he does not boast before things, for it is by taking refuge in the Three Treasures—preserving and upholding them—that he attains this state. The Three Treasures are: first, compassion; second, frugality; third, not daring to lead the world first.

○ **Master Yu’s Annotation:**
Compassion leads to broad salvation; frugality ensures sufficiency. Not daring to lead the world first means he delights in advancing others without weariness.

○ **Master Yu’s Commentary:**
This enumerates the Three Treasures. To embody benevolence and extend generosity, to love and nurture all beings—this is compassion. To moderate use and enrich others, not to deplete things—this is frugality. Not to initiate actions, but to harmonize without leading—this is not daring to lead the world first. The meaning of expansion and benefit is as follows in the text below.

○ **Master He Shang’s Interpretation:**
First, compassion—loving the people as if they were his own children. Second, frugality—levying taxes and burdens as though taking from himself. Third, not daring to lead the world first—practicing humility and retreat, not initiating discord.

○ **Master Cheng’s Commentary:**
First, compassion—pitying and caring for the common folk, sharing their sorrows and joys. This is the Dao’s treasure. Second, frugality—desiring little and knowing contentment, guarding one’s portion without pride. This is the scripture’s treasure. Third, not daring to lead the world first—humble, yielding, and gentle, placing others before oneself, retreating to guide others. This is the Teacher’s treasure.

**The Third Section: Repeating the Three Treasures, praising their efficacy.**
Compassion thus fosters courage,

○ **Master Yu’s Annotation:**
Compassion and benevolence, pity and wisdom, mean virtue abounds, hence courage in salvation and aid.

○ **Master Yu’s Commentary:**
This reveals the Three Treasures’ power to dispel confusion. Ordinary men, when not compassionate, are courageous. In decisiveness, they reach exhaustion and constraint.

**Translation of overlapping terms for consistency:**
- *xiào* (善) = **excellence** (as in *xiào*道, the excellent Dao/Way)
- *xiào* (肖) = **resembling** (as in *xiào*似, resembling)
- *不肖* = **not resembling** (as in *不肖*, not resembling)
- *三宝* = **Three Treasures** (as in Daoist practice, not Buddhist *triple gems*)
- *保而持之* = **safeguarding and upholding them**
- *修身理国* = **cultivate virtue and govern the realm** (consistent with previous translations)

The Sage now practices compassion as conduct, hence his courage in salvation and deliverance.
*The Analects* states: "The virtuous must have courage."

○ Master He Shang says: Through compassion and benevolence, one attains courage in loyalty and filial piety.

○ Master Rong says:
Compassion thus yields courage,
Frugality thus yields breadth,
Not daring to lead the world first thus yields completion as a vessel and longevity,
For compassion toward all things, none shall harm them.
When none harm them, there is no enemy before.
By having no enemy, thus one speaks of courage.

In application, extravagance is insufficient for affairs,
In practice, frugality leaves abundance for governance.
Reaching the distant and vast, hence one speaks of breadth.

Elevating oneself in humility and retreat,
Guarding with yielding and softness,
Its virtue is universal,
Its conduct has completion,
Honored by all things, thus one attains completion as a vessel and longevity.

○ Master Cheng’s Annotation:
Internally repaying great compassion,
Externally expanding to embrace all,
Thus courage enters the Three Realms,
Descending to rescue the common folk.

Frugality thus yields breadth.
*御注*: By moderating expenses and cherishing resources, wealth abounds,
Hence one’s deeds extend broadly.

○ *御疏*: Through moderation and frugality, not harming resources or people,
Thus one’s deeds extend broadly.

○ Master He Shang says: When the sovereign practices frugality,
The people’s daily lives grow broad and ample.

○ Master Cheng’s Annotation: All dharmas are empty and illusory,
Abandoning them without greed,
Frugal, pure, and lofty—
Its virtue is vast and profound.

Not daring to lead the world first, thus one attains completion as a vessel and longevity.
*御注*: The virtues of compassion and frugality,
Through humility and self-effacement, grow ever brighter.
To place others before oneself—
People will never tire of it,
Thus one becomes the supreme vessel of the Dao.

○ *御疏*: Diminishing oneself to benefit others,
Retreating to advance all things—
This is not daring to lead the world first.
Thus all things rejoice in being pushed forward,
And one becomes the supreme vessel of the Dao.

○ Master He Shang says: Not daring to lead the world first,
Not daring to be first among the world’s first.
Thus one attains completion as a vessel and longevity—
Completion as a vessel refers to the Dao-perfected,
I am able to be the leader among those who embody the Dao.

○ Master Cheng’s Annotation: Only for the sake of courageously rescuing the common folk,
Retreating to guide all things,
Thus in the secular world, one dwells alone in the Celestial Capital,
As the leader of all the Saints,
Descending to the mortal realm, one occupies the august Nine-Ranked position,
As the honored vessel of the Dao.

**Fourth Section: Illustrious Conduct Contrary to the Three Treasures Leads to Ruin and Death in Life and Beyond.**

Abandoning compassion and courage,
Abandoning frugality and breadth,
Abandoning humility for precedence—
Death.

*御注*: Now abandoning compassion and courage,
Courage harms all things.
Abandoning frugality and breadth,
Breadth depletes resources.
Abandoning humility for precedence,
Precedence invites resentment.
Depleting resources and harming all things,
Accumulating resentment among people—
This is the path that leads to death.

○ *御疏*: *且* means "temporarily."
Following base desires and excessive cravings,
Every action defies the Dao.
Combining the compassion that benefits all with reckless harm,
Abandoning moderation in use for extravagant excess,
Abandoning humility for arrogant precedence—
Such conduct violates compassion and frugality.
Applied to governance, the realm perishes;
Applied to self-cultivation, the body is lost—
Hence it is said: Death.

○ Master He Shang says: Now abandoning compassion and courage,
Commanding the world to abandon benevolence,
Only to pursue martial valor.
Abandoning frugality and breadth,
Abandoning restraint,
Only to indulge in extravagance.
Abandoning humility for precedence,
Abandoning self-effacement,
Only to strive to be first among all.
Death—such actions inevitably lead to the path of death.

○ Master Rong says: Earlier, it was shown that those who possess the Three Treasures
Practice compassion and attain courage,
Uphold frugality and achieve breadth,
Reside in humility yet reach precedence.
Now, those who lose the Three Treasures
Cannot truly be compassionate,
Temporarily knowing only reckless courage,
Their conduct cannot uphold frugality,
Their expenditures are boundless,
They do not comprehend humility or retreat,
Eagerly seeking to surpass all others.
To love courage without benevolence is futile,
To seek breadth without restraint brings ruin,
To reside first without virtue invites peril—
Hence it is said: Death.

○ Master Yan says: Rejecting harmony and defying the divine,
Every action defies nature,
Distancing oneself from blessings,
Drawing near to calamity,
The Great Fate is severed,
Vital essence and spirit disperse—
Not because one’s fate is thin,
Nor because others are malevolent,
But because one abandons the Dao and extols force.

**Fifth Section: A Comprehensive Praise of Great Compassion, Whose Function is Supreme and Marvelous.**

Compassion—
When wielded in battle, it conquers;
When wielded in defense, it fortifies.

*御注*: Using compassion in battle,
Its advantage lies in preserving the multitude.
Using compassion in defense,
Its advantage lies in securing the people.
Each safeguarding their own security,
Thus victory and fortification are attained.

○ *御疏*: Compassion is the foremost of the Three Treasures,
Hence it is singled out for special praise.
Using compassion to repel war,
One can preserve the multitude.
Using compassion to defend,
One can secure the people—
All without losing compassion,
Thus victory and fortification are attained.

○ Master He Shang says: Those who embody compassion and benevolence,
The people naturally turn to them with loyalty,
Their hearts and intentions united,
Thus in battle they conquer the enemy,
In defense they stand firm and unyielding.

○ Master Rong says: Compassion in battle yields victory,
In defense yields fortification.
Heaven aids those who are saved,
With compassion as their shield,
Using compassion as their means,
They do not stray from the Dao.
In battle, they inevitably overcome their foes,
Hence it is said: victory.
In defense, they face no collapse or peril,
Hence it is said: fortification.
With compassion as their heart,
The Mysterious Heaven thus protects them,
Hence it is said: *saved*.
The Supreme Dao thus preserves and guards them,
Hence it is said: *shielded*.
Internally discerning right and wrong,
In conflict, they form the array,
Dispelling delusion is victory,
The body not losing the Dao is defense.
Aligning with the Dao, enduring through time, they are unharmed,
Heaven aids them—
Externally, no harm comes from things,
The Dao shields them.

○ Master Cheng’s Annotation: Compassion in battle yields victory,
With great compassion in the battlefield,
Soldiers are moved by gratitude,
Thus swift and decisive triumph is achieved.
Internally resolving [delusion] is like the Six Roots as soldiers,
Confronting the Six Dusts without being obscured,
Thus victory is attained.

With compassion as their defense, they are steadfast,
Using compassion to guard and shield,
The people unite in harmony,
Thus they are firmly secure.

Internally resolving with a compassionate and tranquil heart,
Their Dao-heart is unshakable and impenetrable.
The Mysterious Heaven aids them in salvation,
The Dao shields them with compassion.

○ Master Yu’s Annotation:
Using compassion in both war and defense,
Not only does it bring human accord,
The Heavenly Dao is most clear—
It also aids and shields them.

Victory in battle is Heaven’s salvation,
Steadfastness in defense is Heaven’s protection.
All this stems from compassion,
Thus it is said: *Heaven’s salvation and protection through compassion*.

○ Master Yu’s Exegesis:
*Salvation* means *assistance*,
*Protection* means *safeguarding*.
The Heavenly Dao blesses the virtuous—
The virtuous thrive, encountering no adversity.
Thus those who wage war with compassion,
Heaven will assist them.
Those who defend with compassion,
Heaven will safeguard them.
Victory and steadfastness begin with the practice of compassion,
And end in receiving the Heavenly Dao’s clear aid.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
The Heavenly Dao saves the virtuous,
Naturally granting them compassion and benevolence,
So they may cultivate and assist themselves.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
The Heavenly Sage reveres the Dao,
Saving and guiding those who practice compassion,
And in return, they share compassion and benevolence,
Thus Heaven descends to aid and protect them.

Hence, within the Three Treasures, compassion is paramount,
And among the Four Virtues, compassion is foremost—
Thus it is known that compassion’s meaning is vast indeed!

○ **The Sixty-Eighth Chapter on the Virtuous Warrior of Antiquity**
The reason this chapter follows the previous:
The prior chapter fully expounds the Three Treasures,
Praising the great compassion,
Thus this chapter follows to show
Those who uphold the Three Treasures
Attuned to the ancient Dao’s ultimate perfection.

This single chapter unfolds three themes:
First, it draws upon ancient truths to exhort practitioners,
Second, it briefly enumerates the Three Virtues, revealing their superior practice,
Third, it concludes with the Dao’s ultimate perfection, extolling their efficacy and power.

**First: Drawing upon ancient truths to exhort practitioners.**
In the age when the Fire Officer regulated time,
And the era of pure Dao was held in reverence,
Human hearts were simple and unadorned,
Unconcerned with ostentation.
Warriors who cultivated the Dao defended themselves with tranquil ease,
Those skilled in battle halted their weapons to achieve victory,
Their thoughts were like smoldering embers,
Their forms like withered wood.
Among beasts, they dwelled without alarm,
Within flocks of tame birds, they moved without disorder.
Thus, the Duke of Zou tended his calves,
Ignoring the filial submission of Yao’s heir,
And the Marquis of Cheng plowed his fields,
Rejecting the words of Yu’s challenge,
Their conduct stood tall as Mount Hua’s peaks,
Their demeanor humble as Mount Ni’s summit.
The Son of Heaven could not claim them as subjects,
The feudal lords could not count them as allies.
Confronting the business of the Dragon,
They feared not,
Dwelling among wooden geese,
They had nothing to dread—
Thus the virtuous warriors of antiquity
Were worthy to be paired with Heaven itself!

The virtuous warrior does not rely on force,
○ Master Yu’s Annotation:
*Warrior* means *one who serves*.
*Force* means *threatening might*.
The enlightened ruler governs with virtue,
Practices compassion and frugality to subdue all things,
Does not employ force to dominate people,
Holding compassion as their highest virtue—
Thus it is said: *they do not rely on force*.

○ Master Yu’s Exegesis:
*Warrior* means *one who serves*.
Those who govern the state with virtue
Hold virtue as their highest value—
Thus it is said: *they do not rely on force*.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
The noble is in virtue and Dao,
Not in martial prowess.

○ Master Rong said:
With compassion to approach all things,
With virtue to subdue people,
No state relies on brute strength,
No warrior values mere courage—
Without action yet transforming,
This is *not relying on force*.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
The virtuous warriors of antiquity
Cultivated the Dao in quietude and withdrawal,
Never abandoning compassion for force and courage.

**Second: Briefly enumerating the Three Virtues to reveal their superior practice.**
The skilled warrior does not rage,
○ Master Yu’s Annotation:
If war is unavoidable, one must confront the enemy,
With compassion, it is virtuous—
Not relying on fury.
If one uses force to contend,
It is not virtuous victory,
For the soft can overcome the distant,
The near can overcome the strong.

○ Master Yu’s Exegesis:
When the army marches to confront the enemy,
Their purpose is rooted in compassion and pity.
They drive away the stinging insects,
Expel the pests—
That is all.
Thus it is known that virtuous warfare lies in halting the enemy,
Not in relying on fury—
Hence it is said: *the skilled warrior does not rage*.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
Those who wage war with the Dao
Restrain evil in their hearts,
Cutting off calamity before it sprouts,
Never harboring resentment or anger.

○ Master Rong said:
To still the bandits and quell chaos is virtuous warfare.
Compassion saves all things—
No need for rage.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
Skilled in penetrating the illusory nature of the world,
They can subdue the enemy before its rise,
Masterfully embodying the emptiness of both opposition and compliance,
Thus their hearts hold neither joy nor anger.

The one who truly triumphs over the enemy does not contend,
○ Master Yu’s Annotation:
Victory lies in harmony,
Harmony brings virtuous triumph—
The ultimate virtue of complete victory,
Thus they do not engage in contention.

○ Master Yu’s Exegesis:
Virtuous victory lies in compassion,
Not contending stems from upholding virtue.
If one uses force to seek victory,
It is not virtuous triumph.
Now, the soft overcomes the distant,
The near overcomes the strong,
Compassion and harmony are fully expressed,
They do not contend with the enemy—
The enemy surrenders on its own,
Thus it is said: *the one who truly triumphs does not contend*.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
Those who wage war with the Dao to triumph over the enemy
Draw the near with benevolence,
Attract the distant with virtue,
Do not engage the enemy in battle—
Yet the enemy submits itself.

○ Master Rong said:
The Dao brings aid to all under Heaven,
The Four Seas come to acknowledge their rule,
Virtue soothes the inner realm,
The Five Weapons are not raised—
Things are subdued without blades,
Thus it is said: *triumph over the enemy*.
Without intent yet naturally revered,
Thus it is said: *no contention*.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
Unsoiled by the dusts,
This is called *triumph over the enemy*—
Since they hold neither joy nor anger,
What need is there for contention?

The virtuous leader uses others by placing themselves below,
○ Master Yu’s Annotation:
To employ others, they set themselves beneath,
All people exert their utmost strength—
This is the virtue of the bell and the clapper,
Thus it is said: *the virtuous leader uses others by placing themselves below*.

○ Master Yu’s Exegesis:
The virtuous leader employs others through humility,
Thus people will exert their utmost strength,
And success can be achieved.
Hence the *Book of Changes* says:
*To place the noble below the humble,
The great gain the people’s trust*.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
The virtuous leader employs others through humble assistance,
Always acting as the helper of others’ humility.

○ Master Rong said:
To use others without losing their natural talents,
To assign tasks according to their strengths in both culture and martial skill—
This is virtuous leadership.
The broad can encompass all,
The humble can avoid blame,
Thus it is said: *placing themselves below*.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
Those who practice humility and self-effacement
Will naturally be revered by all things,
Thus they can employ others effectively.

The third *gōng* (structure) reaches the ultimate Dao/Way, praising virtuous power and capability.
This is called the virtue/power of non-contentiousness.

○ Imperial Commentary (Tang Xuanzong):
This is called the virtue/power of non-contentiousness,
This is called employing others’ strength,
This is called aligning with the ancient Heavenly Dao/Way.
The virtuous leader prevails without contention,
The humble employs others’ strength.
Those who can do so may align with Heaven and be called emperors,
For this is the most ancient and essential Dao/Way.

○ Imperial Exegesis (Tang Xuanzong):
In the preceding *gōng*, the virtuous warrior is always gentle yet never weak,
The virtuous fighter is always compassionate yet never wrathful,
The virtuous victor is always yielding yet never contentious,
The virtuous leader is always humble and places themselves below others.
When one acts thus,
All things exhaust their abilities,
People give their utmost effort—
All resulting from humility and self-effacement.
Is this not the virtue/power of non-contentiousness?

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
It means the noble places themselves below the humble.
This is the Dao/Way of not contending with others for moral virtue and power.

○ Master Rong said:
This *gōng* describes how one prevails over enemies without martial strength or anger.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
By not contending with all things,
One perfects their own virtue/power.
This *gōng* praises the virtuous leader who prevails over enemies without contention.
This is called employing others’ strength.

○ Imperial Exegesis (Tang Xuanzong):
When one remains silent, reverent, and humble,
When one is modest and places themselves below others,
People are naturally pleased,
And willingly exert their utmost strength.
Thus the *Book of Odes* says:
*Delight them to employ,
And people forget their labor.*
This is employing others’ strength.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
When one’s body can place itself below others,
This is called employing others’ strength.

○ Master Rong said:
This *gōng* praises the humble leader who employs others,
And thus people give their utmost effort.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
Humble and yielding like the female,
Not contending with all things,
Others will naturally submit and serve as their own tools.
This *gōng* praises the humble leader who employs others.

This is called aligning with the ancient Heavenly Dao/Way.

○ Imperial Exegesis (Tang Xuanzong):
This summarizes the four preceding *gōng* on virtuous conduct,
The virtue/power of non-contentiousness.
Those who can practice it may align with Heaven and be called emperors,
For this is the most ancient and essential Dao/Way.

○ Master He Shang Gong said:
This is called aligning with Heaven.
Those who can practice this have virtue/power aligning with Heaven.
This is the most ancient Dao/Way,
The most essential and concise Dao/Way of antiquity.

○ Master Rong said:
To embrace all things with the Dao/Way,
To attract the distant through culture,
To prevail over enemies without battle,
To stand alone in eminence without contention—
Their virtue/power is vast and exalted,
Comparable to Heaven above.
Their transformation is pure and harmonious,
Comparable to the ancient past.
They clarify the empty heart and full belly,
They sit in forgetfulness and merge with the Dao/Way,
They do not rely on coercive authority,
They do not exert themselves in martial prowess,
Thus it is said: *the virtuous warrior is never weak*.
They extinguish the emotions of right and wrong,
They remove the perceptions of love and hate,
Thus the virtuous fighter is never wrathful.
All things do not harm the martial,
They comply without resistance,
Thus the virtuous leader prevails over enemies without contention.
When the heart-king (mind) is tranquil,
And their aspiration lies in the *chōngxū* (void),
Their ears and eyes are undisturbed,
Their hands and feet are unlabored,
This is the humble leader who employs others.
In accordance with natural principles,
Hence it is said: *aligning with Heaven*.
Harmonizing with ancient truth,
Reaching the Dao/Way’s ultimate fruit—
This is the ancient Dao/Way.

○ Master Cheng’s Exegesis:
*Config* means *to align*.
*Heaven* means *natural*.
*Extreme* means *the fruit of the Dao/Way*.
It speaks of the virtuous practitioner who subtly embodies emptiness,
Who penetrates the principles of inverse and compliance,
Who does not contend with all things,
And thus aligns with the utmost natural principles,
Harmonizing with the ancient Dao/Way’s extreme fruit.
This concludes the *gōng*.
