**Chapter 78: The Soft and the Weak**

This chapter follows the previous one, which debated the merits of strength and softness. Since the prior chapter expounded on diminishing and augmenting, this chapter uses water as an analogy to illustrate the power of softness and weakness.

Within this chapter, the meaning unfolds in three parts: first, the analogy begins, clarifying that softness excels strength and weakness overcomes force; second, the analogy is applied, lamenting the common inability to practice it; third, the Sage is cited as proof, demonstrating the true Dao.

**First, the analogy begins, clarifying that softness excels strength and weakness overcomes force:**
The highest virtue is humble and soft—nothing surpasses water. The great artisan takes his standard from it; the virtuous person’s mind flows like water toward the east into rivers, while Confucius marveled at its ceaseless passage. The southern currents converge at the lowly ditches, and Guo Pu praised its boundless spirit.

When autumn waters first rise, they cannot distinguish between cattle and horses; when winter ice first forms, it listens to the calls of foxes and rabbits. Crossing the Yellow River in a small boat, returning to the sea upon a raft. The virtue of softness and weakness triumphs over hardness and strength—white stones boil in cauldrons of stone until they turn to mud, yellow gold is refined into powder by water’s embrace. All these are the power of water, unmatched by any, making it the sovereign of the world. It must be called *"lonely and solitary"* (孤寡), bearing the filth of the land, yet truly it is auspicious.

Speaking of fish, they do not wish their bodies to grow fat; riding cranes, one must have a slender frame. The noble person exchanges with others in simplicity to compare virtue, while the spirit of clarity is marked by pouring and measuring. A loyal subject can summon wind and rain, and a virtuous wife, if reverent and filial, will have the courtyard fountain flow of itself.

Oh, how vast is water’s meaning!

When one acts, he must dwell in tranquility and harmony, not imposing himself upon others. He must yield and adapt, following the Way of things. Water’s nature is pure and reflective—how can I not take virtue from it?

**The soft and the weak of the world have none greater than water.**
Yet in overcoming hardness and strength, there is none that can surpass it.

**Tang Xuanzong’s Imperial Commentary:**
To break hardness with hardness, both must be diminished. But when softness strikes strength, the strong are broken while the soft remain whole. Thus, in overcoming hardness and strength, there is none that can rival water.

**Imperial Exegesis:**
Water’s nature is to descend without contention, moving or still according to the time, conforming to square or round vessels. Therefore, when speaking of the soft and the weak of the world, none surpass water. Yet in overcoming hardness and strength, water cannot be rivaled—though water is soft, it can erode stone, and though stone is hard, it cannot harm water. If hardness attacks hardness, both are damaged; if water attacks stone, stone is worn away while water remains unharmed. Hence, in overcoming hardness and subduing strength, nothing precedes water—this is why it is said that none can surpass it.

**He Shang Gong says:**
The soft and the weak of the world have none greater than water—when contained in a round vessel, it is round; when in a square vessel, it is square. Block it, and it stops; unblock it, and it flows. Yet in overcoming hardness and strength, there is none that can surpass it. Water can embrace mountains and nourish hills, wear away iron and dissolve copper—none can overcome water and achieve success.

**Rong says:**
Observing all things, summarizing all existence, the ultimate soft and weak is water. It dissolves gold and stone, breaks hills and mounds—none can surpass water. In the method of breaking hardness and strength, since water is supreme, there is none to replace it. For governing the body, if one can take humility as virtue and the Dao as application, he can surely break strong adversaries and vanquish the fierce. The Dao must come first, so there is none to replace it. In cultivating oneself, if one can uphold the utmost softness and weakness, he can break the hard and strong. I grasp the principle of dwelling in emptiness and stillness, surpassing all disputes of right and wrong, and only the Dao can prevail—none can substitute for it.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
No thing is as soft and weak as water, and no hardness and strength surpasses gold and stone. Yet water, though soft and weak, has boundless utility, and in overcoming hardness and strength, it is unmatched. The principle of breaking the hard with the soft is the same—its meaning is timeless.

There is none to replace it.

**Imperial Exegesis:**
Though water is the softest, in overcoming hardness and strength, none can replace it. Is this not because it possesses the virtue of non-contention and lacks the desire to hold onto victory? Governing the state and cultivating oneself must also be so.

**He Shang Gong says:**
In overcoming hardness and strength, there is none to replace water.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
Water can naturally overcome hardness and strength—this is the unchanging principle of breaking the hard with the soft, a truth that will never fade through the ages.

**Second, the analogy is applied, lamenting the common inability to practice it:**
Though softness overcomes strength and weakness triumphs over force, the world knows it not, nor can it practice it.

**Tang Xuanzong’s Imperial Commentary:**
The Dao of softness and weakness surpasses that of hardness and strength, yet the world knows it not and cannot practice it.

**Imperial Exegesis:**
The Dao of softness and weakness surpasses that of hardness and strength. All people know this principle, but they are confused by their own perceived superiority, valuing themselves above others, and cannot put into practice what they already know. This is why it is said that they cannot practice it.

**He Shang Gong says:**
The triumph of weakness over strength is seen in how water extinguishes fire and how darkness consumes light. The victory of softness over hardness is seen in how the tongue, soft yet flexible, precedes the rigid teeth—teeth are broken before the tongue perishes. The world knows this well: weakness endures, while strength and force are injured. Yet none can practice it, for they are ashamed of humility and prefer the glory of force.

**Rong says:**
Many favor strength and force, few preserve softness and weakness—they cannot retreat in humility, always striving to be first among things.

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
Water can overcome gold and stone, so it is known that softness triumphs over hardness and strength. This is understood by both the wise and the foolish, yet all the world cannot follow it in practice.

The Third [Section] presents the Sage’s proof to establish the true Dao, demonstrating its rectitude.

Thus, the Sage speaks:
*"To bear the filth of the state is called the steward of the ancestral altars.
To bear the state’s misfortunes is called the sovereign of all under Heaven."*

**御注:**
*"To gather the faults of all directions is to bear the filth of the state.
To alone assume the titles of ‘Orphaned, Lonely, and Unworthy’ is to bear the state’s misfortunes.
His virtue thus established, the ancestral altars will be reverently served."*

**御疏:**
*"The Sage’s words are cited to confirm the meaning above—this is the one who practices the Way of softness overcoming hardness.
Filth (*rǔ*) means defilement and disgrace.
If a ruler can contain and bear defilement, taking all the world’s faults upon himself, then people will revere his virtue and not abandon him, and the ancestral altars will be served. Hence, he is called the steward of the ancestral altars.
To bear the state’s misfortunes is to be the sovereign of all under Heaven—*xiáng* means ‘good.’ If a ruler practices humility and softness, bearing the state’s ills and assuming the titles ‘Orphaned, Lonely, and Unworthy,’ then the Four Seas will turn toward virtue, and he is called the sovereign of all under Heaven."*

**River Upper Master (Hé Shànggōng) says:**
*"Thus, the Sage speaks—this is addressing the subjects below.
To bear the filth of the state and uphold the ancestral altars’ master: if a ruler can bear the state’s turbid defilements, like the rivers and seas not resisting the inflow of streams, then he can long preserve the ancestral altars and be the state’s sovereign.
To bear the state’s misfortunes is to be the sovereign of all under Heaven—a ruler who takes faults upon himself and bears the calamities of the people can thus reign over all under Heaven."*

**Yán says:**
*"To endure what others find shameful and bear it.
What others hate, when it becomes the people’s great calamity, is not taken as virtue—yet if it leads to the loss of the state, it does not lose the Mandate of Heaven. If it risks one’s life, it does not lose the extinction of blessings.
Thus, if one acts this way, Heaven and Earth bow in deference, and all that is imposed upon him vanishes, while all that is plotted against him submits. All under Heaven becomes tranquil, merging into one domain, and those facing the winds and looking upward are transformed without failing to receive blessings."*

**Róng says:**
*"Embodying the Way of softness and weakness, then nothing is excluded.
Awakening to the realm of profound mystery, then no matter is left unaccommodated.
To contain what is rejected and suppress what is evil is to bear the state’s filth.
To blame oneself and take responsibility is to bear the state’s misfortunes.
This suffices to be the master of all things, hence he is called the sovereign of all under Heaven.
These words invert the common and align with the Dao, hence it is said, ‘Rectitude in speech is as if inverted.’
Filth (*rǔ*) is defilement; *xiáng* is goodness.
Though one may practice self-cultivation amid defilement and purity, defilement and purity are both forgotten. Though one passes through goodness and evil, both are harmonized.
Illuminating the original stillness of one principle, establishing that all phenomena are empty—this suffices to realize the Dao and become the Law-King.
From the perspective of convention, filth and goodness are distinct, and the mind perceives them as real.
From the perspective of the Dao, all is empty, hence it is said to be inverted."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
*"Thus, the Sage bears the filth of the state and is called the steward of the ancestral altars—*guó* means ‘the domain of the state,’ and *rǔ* means ‘disgrace.’
The one who embodies the Dao, dwelling in the world, practices humility, softness, and weakness, reaching the point of yielding and compliance, bearing humiliation without contending with others—this is worthy of being the steward of the ancestral altars to shepherd the people.
To bear the state’s misfortunes is to be the sovereign of all under Heaven—thus, *bùxiáng* is the same as ‘not good.’
The Sage’s spiritual insight is vast and penetrating, reaching into goodness and evil. If there are misfortunes in the state, he immediately blames himself and takes the faults upon himself—this is worthy of being the sovereign of all under Heaven. The case of Tāng setting fire to his granaries to summon distant aid is an example.
Earlier, it was said that the ancestral altars could be entrusted to the feudal lords; now, it is said that all under Heaven should belong to the sovereign of all under Heaven.
Rectitude in speech is as if inverted."*

**御注:**
*"To bear the filth of the state is to be the steward of the ancestral altars; to bear the state’s misfortunes is to be the sovereign of all under Heaven. These words, though seemingly inverted, are indeed the true rectitude—hence it is said, ‘Rectitude in speech is as if inverted.’"*

**御疏:**
*"This sentence concludes the preceding text.
To bear the state’s filth and turbidity is to be the steward of the ancestral altars; to bear the state’s misfortunes is to be the sovereign of all under Heaven. His words contradict convention and differ from the common view, hence the Old Master elaborately explains that these are indeed true and genuine words. Though they seem inverted to the common ear, they are trustworthy in practice—but people initially perceive them as inverted."*

**River Upper Master (Hé Shànggōng) says:**
*"These are the words of true rectitude; the world does not understand them, taking them for inverted speech."*

**Yán says:**
*"To hold oneself lightly and others heavily, to be at ease with disgrace—this inverts conventional perception and is the true speech of governance."*

**Master Cheng’s Exegesis:**
*"When speaking in accordance with principle, it seems to invert convention—why? The common people all love goodness and honor, yet now one bears defilement and ills, which seems inverted.
Yet the phrase ‘as if inverted’ (*rú fǎn*) aims to clarify that though it appears inverted, it is not truly so—though it seems inverted, it is not. Though it seems inverted, it is not. It constantly aligns with convention, not truly inverted, yet aligning with convention in truth.
It is said that the profound virtue is deep and distant, contrary to things, and only then does it reach the greatest harmony—this is its meaning."*

**Chapter on Harmonizing Great Grievances (Chapter 79)**
The chapter on *Harmonizing Great Grievances* follows the previous one because the prior chapter broadly expounds on hardness and softness, yet even at its utmost, it has not fully penetrated to forgetfulness. Hence, this chapter follows, dispelling the earlier obscurity to reveal the intent of the *Double Mystery*.

Within this chapter, the meaning unfolds in three distinctions:
1. Though one departs from the two extremes, one has not yet ascended to the Dao’s peak.
2. The Sage’s empty unity and mysterious correspondence with the *Double Mystery*.
3. The distinction between those with virtue and those without, and the difference in letting go of fixation.

**First: Though one departs from the two extremes, one has not yet ascended to the Dao’s peak.**
*"Heaven has no favorites—if one acts, it is good. Great grievances will arise; even if harmonized, there will be no peace.
Thus, the Sage empties his heart to benefit others, holds the left contract without blame, and embraces virtue while overseeing life.
It is like the bright sun ascending to Heaven—all under Heaven is illuminated, and the warm breath of yang stirs the earth, making all things spring.
The burden of strength is vast, yet the Dao of the formless is great—how could one cling to it and merely calculate right and wrong?"*

「Though the Master of the Eastern March inclines his heart toward the Wu and Yue regions, his mind already wanders with the ambition of Jing Ke to gaze southward and emulate the valor of Yan and Qin.
Or perhaps he laments the emptiness of Luochuan, then sings a sorrowful song at Yishui—how much like the painted beauty of the crucian carp, which stirs Zhang Han’s longing to return, or the white deer with its unbroken loyalty, which evokes Liu Cang’s remembrance of old bonds!
One must always attend to the roots, for noble deeds are thus exalted.
Hold the Primordial *qi* in pure unity, and do not let passion flow into the Three Evils.
Embody the true and tranquil stillness, and perceive the profound mysteries of the Dao.
Many are lost in the flickering lamps of the world, while few awaken to the reflection in the mirror—this is the way to verify the Path of Eternal Life and enter its wondrous gate.

To harmonize great grievances, there will inevitably be lingering grievances.

**Commentary:**
*"To harmonize great grievances"* refers to the ruler’s desire to use words and teachings to reconcile the people, eliminating their passions. Hence, it is called *harmonizing great grievances*.
There will inevitably be lingering grievances—once a doctrine is established to guide the people, traces of it must remain, and these traces will still breed grievances. Thus, lingering grievances arise.

**Further Commentary:**
At first, humanity was born with a pure and tranquil mind, but now they are entangled in the dusty realm, straying from the Dao and falling into corruption—all due to the influence of passions. Thus, the greatest grievance for the body is indeed passion.
*Harmonize* means to reconcile and adjust.
The people, already ensnared by passion and thus giving rise to deceit, cannot be transformed by the ruler’s passive non-action. If he instead establishes doctrine and law to curb their treachery and adjust them toward harmony, it is called *harmonizing great grievances*.
Yet lingering grievances remain—once laws and doctrines are set, their traces cannot be entirely erased, and these traces will still provoke grievances. Hence, lingering grievances persist.

**River Master’s Saying:**
To *harmonize great grievances*, one must let the killer face death and the wounder receive punishment—this is the way of mutual retaliation.
There will inevitably be lingering grievances, for those who enforce punishments will lose the people’s trust, and lingering grievances will extend even to the innocent.

**Rong’s Commentary:**
To *harmonize great grievances* is to invite lingering grievances—how can this be considered good? When all things are unified in their natural state, right and wrong dissolve. Yet when distinctions arise and conflicts ensue, great grievances take form.
Thus, rituals include the duty of repaying grievances, and laws prescribe punishments for crimes. Grievances come and go, never ceasing. If one seeks to extinguish them by reconciling and adjusting, it is to invert the natural order—making them follow what is unnatural. When people outwardly comply but inwardly resist, or speak well while harboring ill will, lingering grievances and resentments only grow. This is to invite further evil—how can it be called good?
If one truly desires goodness, it is better to refrain from provoking grievances. If grievances are not provoked, there is no need for reconciliation or adjustment. When both inversion and compliance are forgotten, great grievances naturally cease. Only then, when one does not know what is called good, can it be named *the utmost good*.

**Cheng’s Commentary:**
*Grievances* are oppositions—this encompasses all distinctions of good and evil, presence and absence, and every principle that requires opposition.
Though one may reconcile the oppositions of having and not having, achieving neither having nor not having, and thus harmonize the two extremes into a singular middle, this is still the realm of *Xuan* (the Mysterious), not yet the essence of *Double Mystery*.
This is a state of *non-dependence*, yet one has not yet attained *absolute non-dependence*—this is *dependence on singularity*, not yet *singularity without dependence*. Hence, lingering oppositions remain.
How can this be considered *the utmost good*?

**Commentary:**
Once lingering grievances arise, how can one still claim to act in *the utmost good*?
The traces of laws and doctrines inevitably lead to lingering grievances—thus, how can they be called *the utmost good*? This is merely the nature of goodness in learning, striving to restore the original purity.
If one ascends to the transformation of pure tranquility, doing nothing and attending to nothing, the people will naturally adopt simplicity and sincerity, and the traces of lingering grievances will vanish. Only then can one truly be called *the utmost good*.

**River Master’s Saying:**
If one person sighs in complaint, the harmony of Heaven is lost—how can reconciling grievances be considered *the utmost good*?

**Cheng’s Commentary:**
*How* can this be *the utmost good*?
Though one may abandon the two extremes, one has not yet forgotten the singular middle—thus, how can one fully attain *the utmost good*?

**Second: The Sage’s empty gathering and his wondrous correspondence with the *Double Mystery*.**

Therefore, the Sage holds the *Left Contract* and does not blame the people.
**Commentary:**
*The Left Contract* refers to the mind.
The mind is the *yang* repository, binding with the external realm—thus it is called the *Left Contract*.
The Sage knows that establishing doctrine will inevitably leave traces, and these traces will still breed lingering grievances. Therefore, he holds fast to this mind, making it pure and tranquil, and transforms the people through its power. Thus, their passions are eliminated, and they do not need to be punished—they naturally align with non-action.

**Further Commentary:**
*The Left Contract* refers to the mind.
The mind is the *yang* repository, binding with the external realm—thus it is called the *Left Contract*.
The Sage knows that establishing doctrine will inevitably leave traces, and these traces will still breed lingering grievances. Therefore, he holds fast to this mind, ensuring it does not scatter or become confused, and transforms the people through its power. Thus, their passions are eliminated, and they do not need to be punished—they naturally align with non-action.

**River Master’s Saying:**
Therefore, the Sage holds the *Left Contract*—in ancient times, the Sage held the *Left Contract*, which was a pledge of mutual trust.
Without written laws, they carved contracts and pledges into wood as tokens of faith.
Yet he did not blame the people—only the tokens of the *Left Contract* were enforced; no other punishments were imposed.

**Yan’s Commentary:**
*Contract* is a token of trust.
The Sage holds the Dao’s token and wields the virtue’s pledge, uniting them within himself and not blaming others.
Thus, when he would act, he first aligned with Heaven; when he would move, he verified with the tokens of trust.
He sought faults within himself, never reproached others.
He attributed blame to himself, never to others.

**Rong’s Commentary:**
In ancient times, the Sage carved contracts into wood—the ruler held the left, the subject the right—as tokens of trust.
They bound the people to the contracts and pledges, without further laws or punishments. Hence, it is said that the Sage did not blame the people.

**Cheng’s Commentary:**
*Contract* signifies trust and unity.
*The Left* signifies *yang*—life and generation.
The Sage’s insight into the Dao is profound, like the binding of the Mysterious—his unity of subject and object transcends these four phrases, separating himself from all hundred faults.
Thus, he attains eternal vision and longevity.»

The *Left* is held in *yi*—this is indeed *non-attachment* yet *attachment*.

Just as the sovereign ordinarily grasps the left contract, by which he governs all affairs,
the Sage’s subtle contract embraces the world,
thus he can rectify and guide the myriad peoples,
yet speaks of no blame—
for though the Sage rectifies and guides all beings,
he forgets his virtue,
treating the people as straw dogs.
Hence, he does not demand their gratitude in return.

**The Third Distinction:** The difference between *de* and *non-de* lies in *holding* and *forgetting*.

Thus, the virtuous ruler governs by *contract*,
while the unvirtuous governs by *simplicity*.
**Yu’s Annotation:** *Govern* means *to master*.
*Simplicity* means *to permeate*.
The virtuous ruler masters the *heart-contract*,
and thus the people transform of themselves.
The unvirtuous ruler, unable to empty his heart and forget himself,
seeks only to impose laws to permeate the people—
and where laws are made, harm arises.
Hence, he is without virtue.

**Yu’s Citation:**
The virtuous ruler governs by *contract*—
the virtuous sovereign merely oversees the *contract of trust*.
The unvirtuous ruler governs by *simplicity*—
the unvirtuous sovereign abandons the *contract of trust* and oversees what is lost.

**Yan’s Commentary:**
*Simplicity* may also be read as *slaughter*.
The unvirtuous ruler’s governance brings disorder and chaos;
he does not seek faults within himself,
but only oversees the people’s transgressions,
driving them with harsh punishments—
thus, families bear guilt and crimes abound.
The virtuous ruler, however, determines right and wrong within himself,
distinguishing black from white without action—
before he moves, the world responds;
before he commands, the world complies.

**Rong’s Commentary:**
*Govern* means *to master*.
*Contract* means *unity*.
*Simplicity* means *dispersion*.
The virtuous ruler’s governance stems from his heart,
harmonizing with the Dao of *non-action*,
mysteriously one above, drawing all things below.
His trust is the *contract of unity*.
But if unvirtuous, he fails to practice goodness,
neither holding to the Dao’s *contract*
nor uniting the people—
thus, they scatter.
Within, the virtuous ruler aligns with principle,
hence *governs by contract*;
the unvirtuous defies truth,
hence *governs by simplicity*.

**Cheng’s Citation:**
*Govern* means *to master*.
*Simplicity* means *trace*.
The virtuous ruler’s subtle governance does not cling to names or words,
while the unvirtuous, still entangled in *qi* and form,
cannot penetrate and release—
their traces remain unvanquished,
hence *governs by simplicity*.

The Dao of Heaven knows no favoritism—
it always aligns with the virtuous.
**Yu’s Annotation:**
To govern by *contract* is to remain pure and unspoiled;
to legislate is to bring decay and ruin.
Heaven favors none—
it aids only virtue.
Thus, the sovereign must always cultivate purity through *non-action*,
never legislate and create strife.

**Yu’s Citation:**
Though Heaven’s way is impartial in its bestowal,
it does not deceive the virtuous—
those who govern by *contract* attain purity,
and Heaven blesses their goodness with unending benefit.
But those who legislate bring harm,
and Heaven visits calamity upon them—
who cannot escape?
Is this not proof that Heaven favors none,
aiding only virtue?

**He Shang Gong’s Saying:**
The Dao of Heaven knows no near or far—
it aids only the virtuous,
which is to govern by *contract*.

**Rong’s Commentary:**
Heaven’s way is equal, knowing no near or far.
The wicked stray from the path, thus distant;
the virtuous draw near to truth, thus close.
Speaking of ultimate principle,
it is neither distant nor near—
only those who practice virtue are blessed by Heaven,
hence it is said to *aid the virtuous*.
Yet it aids the virtuous while abandoning the unvirtuous—
thus, one knows that Heaven aids virtue,
not the lack thereof.
If one walks the path of virtue,
virtue naturally returns to them.

**Cheng’s Citation:**
Heaven’s true principle knows no near or far.
The supremely virtuous naturally harmonize with it—
this is the same as holding the left *contract*
and not blaming the people.

---
**The Chapter on Small States and Few People**
This chapter follows the previous because,
though the prior displayed the two *mysteries*’ essence,
its practice was not yet complete.
Thus, this chapter clarifies entering the great through the small.

Within this chapter, the text unfolds in four layers:
First, it illuminates the *xiao xue* (small learning) person,
who does not enter the realm of dust;
Second, it speaks of emptying the heart to verify principle,
abandoning teaching and forgetting *qi*;
Third, it returns to ancient purity,
harmonizing light and blending with customs;
Fourth, it embodies truth and unites with the Dao,
transcending all comings and goings.

**First Layer: The *xiao xue* Person Does Not Enter the Dusty Realm**
In the age of the Flaming Han,
the sovereign merely harmonized with *endurance and repose*;
in the time of Xi and Nong,
people simply adhered to *non-action*.
They dwelled in caves to avoid wind and frost,
nested in trees to evade summer’s heat.
A woman conceived once every fifteen years,
and lived nearly a hundred before death.
They died piled on kindling,
and lived cradling their food at the breast—
how could there be great states claiming empire,
small states claiming subjecthood,
where officials did not aid in planning,
and Feng Huo did not apply his wisdom?
Who calculated the *shi-bo* tools,
who served as magistrates?

Though they had boats and carriages,
they abandoned them by rivers and plains;
though they had armor and weapons,
they stored them away and did not use them.
The transformation of knotted cords was lofty,
the wind of *ya* music reached its peak—
the old died without mutual visits,
until the later age of chaos and peril,
when kings waged war,
Yin overthrew Xia’s governance,
Zhou invaded the Zhou dynasty,
and Yi Yin carried a cauldron to counsel the release of Jie,
while Liang Si wore a jade to deceive Qin.
Qin Shi Huang demoted King Zhou of Zhou to commoner,
Liu Yu bound Emperor Gong of Jin to a pillar—
ministers usurped the sovereign’s power.
Alas, who could endure it?
How could they know that in the age of the Great Dao,
all embraced the transformation of *non-action*?
Comparing today to antiquity—
how deep the sorrow!

Small states, few people—
let there be *shi-bo* tools, yet unused.

The heart, when it does not seek greatness, is free from greed and rivalry.
The affairs, when not sought in multitude, become simple and easy.
When the Way of simplicity is established,
then the pure winds take root.

Even if there are those with talent and skill,
capable of leading as *shi-bo* officers,
there is no need to employ them.

---
**River Upper Master** said:
Though the Sage governs a great state,
he still considers it small,
practicing frugality without extravagance.
Though the people are many,
he treats them as few,
so they dare not be burdened.

Let the people have *shi-bo* tools,
and let each have their own *bu-qu* and *shi-bo* ranks,
so that nobles and commoners do not encroach upon one another.

Though there are tools for the people,
these tools—referring to the farmer’s implements—
are not used, meaning they are not conscripted
to disrupt the people’s prime seasons.

---
**Yan** said:
A small state has narrow lands and few people,
no unshakable foundations,
but only the peril of precarious reliance.
Yet if governed by the Dao,
it can turn misfortune into blessing.

---
**Rong** said:
The Sage governs the state with the Way of *non-action*.
Whether military implements are few or many—
whether in ranks of *bo* or *thousand*—
they are all unused.
If even small states are thus,
how much more so great states?

---
**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
"State" refers to the domain of the mind.
Thus, "small state" means the mind dwelling in simplicity,
a person of few desires—
this is humility.
The conduct of a small state with few desires:
its "tools" are the six senses and ten evils as weapons.
Though the senses are six,
their uses are boundless.
Speaking of *shi-bo* is to cite their greater numbers,
but "unused" means to still the senses
and not be stained by the dust of the world.

Let the people hold life dear
and not wander far.
**御疏** said:
"Wander" means to migrate.
When customs return to simplicity and frugality,
government is not burdensome or harsh.
The people cherish their lives,
so they hold death dear.
They take root in their occupations,
seeking nothing beyond,
each content in their dwelling,
so they do not migrate far.

---
**River Upper Master** said:
Let the people hold life dear—
if the ruler can bring them benefit and remove harm,
each attaining their place,
then the people will cherish life and responsibility.
Not wandering far—
this is to avoid burdens,
so the people remain settled in their occupations,
and do not stray from their accustomed ways.

---
**Yan** said:
Establish them with virtue and morality,
and the people will rejoice in life and longevity,
not becoming thieves or bandits.
At such times,
there are no bells and drums yet ten thousand are joyful,
no rewards given yet ten thousand are content.
Each remains settled in their dwelling,
not abandoning their homeland,
even with a hundredfold gain,
they would not leave their state.

---
**Rong** said:
When governance encounters crises,
people grow light in their regard for life.
When transformation aligns with *non-action*,
people hold death dear.
Fathers protect their children,
wives do not lose their husbands,
each attains joy in their occupation and settled home,
with no further exile or migration.

---
**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
All actions emphasize stillness,
knowing contentment and guarding one’s portion,
thus attaining the fulfillment of one’s natural years,
without chasing distant realms.

---
**Secondly, it clarifies the empty heart and the realization of principle,
the gathering of teachings and forgetting the raft.**

Though there are boats and carriages,
there is no need to ride them.

**御疏** said:
Boats and carriages were established
to traverse water and land,
to aid in scarcity and surplus.
Since there is no travel,
both boats and carriages are abandoned,
with no purpose for use.
*Zhuangzi* says:
*"In the age of supreme virtue,
mountains have no paths or tunnels,
marshes have no boats or bridges."*

---
**River Upper Master** said:
Pure and unadorned, without indulging in ornate pursuits,
they do not delight in travel or amusement.

---
**The Two Rongs** said:
Water travel requires boats,
land travel requires carriages.
In the age of *non-action*,
mountains have no paths or tunnels,
marshes have no boats or carriages—
cutting off the root and discarding the branches,
what need is there for riding?

---
**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
Boats and carriages refer to the Three Vehicles of teaching.
Boats float on water,
symbolizing teachings that ferry all beings
across the sea of birth and death.
Thus, the *Elevating the Mysterious Classic* says:
*"Long abandoned the sea of birth and death,
cutting off the flow of greed."*

Carriages move on land,
their wheels turning,
symbolizing teachings that transform the vulgar into the sage.
Having attained the principle, one forgets the words,
thus discarding the teachings and not using them.

Though there are armor and weapons,
there is no need to array them.

**御疏** said:
Armies are arrayed
to subdue the unyielding,
to repel enemies.
With virtue practiced above and harmony below,
since hostile attacks cease,
armor and weapons are sheathed and not deployed.

---
**River Upper Master** said:
There is no resentment or hatred in the world.

---
**Rong** said:
Weapons are used to punish the rebellious,
martial might to quell disorder.
Since the ruler practices the Dao above,
the people below love virtue,
naturally conforming to transformation—
what need is there for arraying troops?

---
**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
Though there are the "armor and weapons" of body and mind,
when one collapses the body and sits in forgetfulness,
the objects and their realms become empty—
what need is there for deployment?
This sentence reverses the earlier "tools of *shi-bo* are unused."

Let the people return to knotted cords for use.

**御疏** said:
In ancient times, before writing was invented,
knots in cords recorded events.
Thus, the *Systematic Pivot* says:
*"In the upper antiquity, they governed by knotted cords;
later sages replaced them with written contracts."*
To illustrate the age of knotted cords,
people were pure and unadorned.
Once writing emerged,
deceit and artifice flourished.
Now, to make people forget emotions and desires,
returning to ancient simplicity,
it is said: "Let the people return to knotted cords for use."

---
**River Upper Master** said:
Abandon artifice and return to simplicity,
truth without deceit.

---
**Rong** said:
In ancient times, before writing was created,
knots in cords were used for governance.
Once writing appeared,
corruption grew even more severe.
The Sage’s teaching aims at *non-action*,
singing to make them abandon corruption and return to simplicity,
discarding ornamentation and embracing reality.

---
**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
Having emptied the heart and realized the principle,
discarded teachings and forgotten the raft,
thus relying on knotted cords
to demonstrate a return to the root.
This sentence concludes the earlier "though there are boats and carriages, no need to ride them."

---
**Thirdly, it clarifies returning to antiquity and simplicity,
harmonizing with the light and blending with customs.**

Let their food be sweet,
their clothing beautiful.

「The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
To eat sweetly is to eat in moderation—moderation makes all food sweet.
To dress beautifully is to wear appropriately—appropriateness makes all clothing beautiful.
If not moderate and fitting, even jade-like delicacies and brocade garments
cannot truly be called sweet and beautiful.

**He Shang Gong** said:
*"Sweet their food"* means sweet their coarse meals,
not plundering the people for fine cuisine.
*"Beautiful their clothing"* means beautiful their rough garments,
not prizing the five colors.

**Rong** said:
Sweet their food, beautiful their clothing,
settle their dwellings, delight in their customs—
when people’s desires are unfulfilled,
even jade food and silk brocade are not deemed beautiful.
But when the heart finds contentment,
plain rice and coarse hemp robes suffice as sweetness.
Let **Tao Sheng** and **Da Jun** transform the world,
and all shall eat sweetly without distinction of rank.
Clothing shall have no preference for good or ill,
all garments worn shall be deemed beautiful.
Homes shall know no poverty or wealth,
all dwellings shall be deemed settled.
Villages shall know no excess or want,
all abodes shall be filled with joy.
Since none seek distant migration,
the weak and bereaved shall find no need to wander.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
*"Sweet their food"*—flavor attains the Dao.
*"Beautiful their clothing"*—virtue/power shines in the body.
*"Settle their dwellings"*—delight in their customs.
The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
Without desire, their dwellings are settled.
With simplicity transformed, their customs are joyful.
If one pursues desires without restraint,
how could they settle in their dwellings?
Harsh governance and burdens bring only trouble—
how could they then delight in their customs?

**He Shang Gong** said:
*"Settle their dwellings"*—settle in thatched huts,
not favoring ornate houses.
*"Delight in their customs"*—delight in simple and unadorned ways,
not shifting to foreign norms.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
*"Settle their dwellings"*—all places are settled,
stillness within motion.
*"Delight in their customs"*—harmonizing with the world’s light,
motion within stillness.

**Fourthly, it illustrates attaining true Dao/Way and harmonizing with its flow,
exceeding all coming and going.**
Neighboring lands face one another,
the sounds of roosters and dogs reach across them—
yet the people, until death, never visit one another.

The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
Neighboring lands face one another—
the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard—
this speaks of their closeness.
That the people, until death, never visit one another,
is because each has their own sufficiency,
and nothing more to seek or give.

**He Shang Gong** said:
Neighboring lands face one another,
the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard—
this marks proximity.
The people, until death, never visit one another—
this is their lack of emotional attachments.

**Rong** said:
Two lands as neighbors, visible to the eye,
roosters crow and dogs bark, heard by the ear—
from beginning to end, in youth and age,
they never visit one another.
Each person is self-sufficient,
each home holds the Dao.
Thus it is said:
*"People forget the Dao as it spreads,*
*fish forget the rivers and lakes they dwell in."*

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
Neighboring lands face one another—
*neighbor* means near,
*lands* refers to the realms of life and death,
and the Dao’s domain.
This says that these two realms lie close within the heart,
so they are said to face one another.
The sounds of roosters and dogs are heard—
roosters watch for dawn,
dogs guard through the night—
these teachings serve as warnings against the long night of ignorance,
and calls to the morning of wisdom.
Thus, these teachings are near in expounding the unity of mind,
so they are said to be heard.
That the people, until death, never visit one another—
when one attains true understanding and harmony,
this is the Dao.
The Dao is neither born from life and death,
nor does it depart through any path—
when these two realms merge as one,
there is no coming or going,
no distinction between beginnings and ends.

---
**Chapter Eighty-One of *Sincere Speech Not Beautiful***

*Sincere Speech*—this chapter is the third section,
its text summarizing earlier themes.
Within this chapter, the meaning is divided into three:
**Firstly, it shows the virtuous/powerful person,
whose wisdom transcends all speech and argument.**
Good medicine tastes bitter,
sincere speech is not beautiful,
great eloquence seems dull,
the learned do not know all.
The Sage scatters Dao/Way to teach the common and foolish,
yet does not hoard it.
He laments the long night of ignorance,
while the foolish and dull remain unaware—
I, like grass, am but one of these common folk,
standing at the edge of the boundless sea of desire,
yet unable to unfurl my ragged robes.
Before the mountain of error, who dares lift a foot?
The owl that neither cries nor flies—
when it rises, it soars to the heavens.
The man who is both foolish and dull—
how could he awaken in a hundred years?

The Sage labors to point out the Great Dao/Way,
but distorts the natural transformations of life.
In darkness, they do not know—
what more can be said?

I have privately observed the utmost sincerity,
refining the self and governing the realm—
above, it ascends to the brilliance of the sun,
soaring through the clouds like a bird.
Below, it cleanses the intestines and washes the heart,
leading many to follow in its path.
To act without effort is the Dao’s honor—
dwelling in the source of harmony and balance,
virtue/power can nourish all things.
The child of a skilled craftsman
must first learn to make his own leather coat—
my disciples embrace the True,
so why do they not gather?

My spirit is weary from yellowed scrolls and shallow learning,
my Dao is impoverished by clear streams.
Day and night, I strive in fear,
never ceasing in sleep or waking.
I regret not attaining the likeness of the Sage,
nor the colors of his teachings.
My wasted bones and tattered soul—
how could my sighs ever end?
Those who share my resolve—
do not forget this heart’s intent.

*Sincere speech is not beautiful—*
The *Rong*’s Commentary said:
*Sincere speech*—this refers to the Sage’s teachings,
truthful and real.
Laozi wished to clarify his established teachings,
to transform and guide all beings,
and truly, these are words of utmost sincerity—
yet they conflict with common ways,
so people deem them not beautiful.

**He Shang Gong** said:
*Sincere speech*—speech that matches reality.
*Not beautiful*—simple and unadorned.

**Rong** said:
Sincere speech is not beautiful,
beautiful speech is not sincere—
speech reveals the heart,
not a matter of idle fabrication.
It seeks true principles,
not flashy words.
Thus it is said: *sincere speech is not beautiful,*
*sweet words lose truth,*
*light promises lack substance.*

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
*Sincere speech is not beautiful,*
*beautiful speech is not sincere*—
*sincere* means real,
*beautiful* means superficial and gaudy.
The virtuous/powerful person, obscured yet in accord with the Dao,
speaks teachings that are real without ornamentation.
Superficial and gaudy speech—
mere tales from the common world—
deviates from ultimate truth,
so it is not believed.»

「Thus *Zhuangzi* states: *"A dog is not considered good merely because it barks well; a person is not deemed virtuous/powerful merely because of eloquent speech."* **Beautiful speech lacks sincerity.**

**Yu’s Commentary** said:
**Beautiful speech** refers to teachings that are sweet and adorned.
Speech that is excessive in superficiality and conforms to worldly tastes—
though it lacks sincerity and substance—
it cannot transform others.
Thus, *sincere speech is not beautiful*
because **beautiful speech lacks sincerity.**

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
Those who speak in **honeyed beauty**—
their words are **nailed and polished** with ornate phrases.
Those who lack sincerity—
their speech is **decorated with falsehoods**, full of emptiness.

The **good** do not **argue**—
**Yu’s Commentary** said:
The **good** in understanding teachings
lie in **cultivation and practice**—
acting without clinging,
never fixating or obstructing,
thus they do not **argue** for their views.

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
The **good** cultivate themselves in the **Dao/Way**,
without embellishing with **literary refinement**.

**Yan** said:
Those who appear **naive and slow** in speech
are called **not argumentative**—
yet their words are **drawn out and true**,
their silence **deep and trustworthy**,
thus they can **achieve goodness**—
how so?
Their actions **move the heart of Heaven**,
their stillness **aligns with the will of Earth**—
the foundation of the **virtuous/powerful person**,
the longest-lasting of all **conducts**.

**Rong** said:
The **good** do not **argue**,
those who **argue** are not **good**—
**great argumentation seems naive**,
without **labored words or empty rhetoric**—
thus the **good** do not **argue**.
Excessive **partial phrasing**,
overly **prolific speech**,
**argumentative words exhaust truth**—
thus those who **argue** are not **good**.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
**Argumentation** means **distinction and separation**.
Those who **grasp the ultimate Dao/Way**,
point to the **horse of Heaven and Earth** with the **unity of One**,
thus have nothing to **distinguish or separate**.
The **Confucian and Mohist debates** on right and wrong—
those who rigidly cling to **self/other duality**—
are indeed those who have not yet **attained the good Dao/Way**.

**Secondly**, it clarifies that the **virtuous/powerful person of highest virtue** engages in **twofold giving**—
**of wealth and of virtue**.

The **good** do not **accumulate**—
**Yu’s Commentary** said:
**Accumulation** means **obstruction and stagnation**.
The **sage** **penetrates the subtle source of principles**,
**deeply understands the nature of dharma**,
**discerns the emptiness of words and teachings**,
and **realizes the void of verbal instruction**.
Since their **understood principles are clear**,
their **spoken teachings are also abandoned**,
thus they **do not accumulate** in those teachings—
hence it is said: *"The sage does not accumulate."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
The **sage accumulates virtue, not wealth**,
using **wealth to aid the poor**,
using **virtue to guide the ignorant**.

**Yan** said:
The **sage** **discards argumentation and literary refinement**,
like **void and emptiness**,
holding nothing in **stagnation or accumulation**,
adapting with all things—
thus it is said.

**Rong** said:
The **sage does not accumulate**—
when they give to others, their own **virtue/power grows**,
when they give to others, their own **virtue/power becomes more abundant**—
**not accumulating** means **an empty heart**,
like the **radiance of the sun and moon**,
shining upon all **regions and lands**,
things **obtain their own illumination**,
yet their **light becomes ever more brilliant**—
just as the **sage’s wisdom permeates all things**,
their **dharma-giving is boundless**.

The **rivers and seas** **nourish and moisten**,
**benefiting all creatures**—
things **gain life through them**,
yet their **source never runs dry**—
also like the **sage’s wealth-giving**, which is **never exhausted**.

**Cheng’s Commentary** said:
**Accumulation** means **gathering**.
The **sage** has **wealth to benefit others**,
has **virtue to teach others**,
thus they do not **accumulate**.

When they give to others, their own **virtue/power grows**,
when they give to others, their own **virtue/power becomes more abundant**—
**Yu’s Commentary** said:
**Exhaust** means **complete**.
Though the **sage** does not **stagnate or accumulate** in teachings,
yet **sentient beings** **awaken their wisdom**,
must rely on the **sage’s guidance**.
Thus the **sage** uses **pure and clear rational insight**,
**fully imparting** to the **common and ignorant** for instruction.

In the **sage’s nature of wisdom and penetration**,
there is **no depletion or waste**,
hence it is said: *"The more they give, the more they possess."*
The **annotation** states:
**Self-illumination** refers to **inherent clarity**,
**external illumination** refers to **wisdom gained from teaching**—
the **nature of insight**,
though not **originating from others**,
is said to be **self-illumination**.
The **benefit from teaching**,
not arising **from within themselves**,
is said to be **external illumination**.
Thus, the **sage’s instruction** of the **common and ignorant**,
**their wisdom grows ever clearer and more fluent**,
hence it is said: *"The more they teach, the more abundant their wisdom."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
When they give to others, their own **virtue/power grows**,
when they **impart virtue/power and dharma-transformations** to others,
their own **virtue/power and dharma-transformations** grow ever more abundant—
thus they **possess ever more virtue/power**.»

The **Dao** thus declares:
*"When one gives to others, one’s own abundance grows ever greater—
when one distributes wealth and treasures in alms,
one’s own wealth grows ever more abundant,
like the light of sun and moon,
endless without cessation."*

**Master Yan** said:
*"The principle of *wuwei* [non-action] is this:
The more one gives to others, the brighter one’s own virtue/power becomes,
the more one gives to others, the longer one’s own life endures."*

**Master Cheng’s commentary** said:
*"When one gives to others, one’s own virtue/power grows ever greater—
*ji*, meaning ‘exhaustively.’
*Wei*, meaning ‘to transform and bestow.’
It speaks of one’s inherent virtue/power and moral cultivation,
exhaustively imparted to teach others,
without miserliness or pettiness,
thus one’s virtue becomes ever more profound and vast—
this is *virtue-giving*.
When one gives to others, one’s own abundance grows ever greater—
all one’s wealth and treasures,
exhaustively dispersed in alms,
the fruit of one’s merit becomes ever broader—
this is *wealth-giving*."*

**A summary of the highest virtue:**
*"Benefiting others while forgetting one’s own deeds.*
The **Dao of Heaven** benefits without harming."*

**The Imperial Commentary** said:
*"The **Dao of Heaven** nourishes and sustains all things—
this is benefiting.
It takes nothing in return—
this is without harming.
This analogy illustrates how the **Sage’s Way** is vast and beneficial."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
*"Heaven nurtures and cherishes all things,
letting them grow great without injury."*

**Master Rong** said:
*"The **Dao of Heaven** benefits by giving life—
it constantly aids others without harm.
Strife arises from the mind,
and from actions born of desire.
The Sage has no mind,
thus naturally no affairs.
When affairs are without affairs,
action is *wuwei*."*

**Master Cheng’s commentary** said:
*"The natural **Dao** generates and nurtures all things,
its benefits vast and boundless—
what harm could there be?
The **Sage’s Way** acts without contention."*

**The Imperial Commentary** said:
*"The **Sage’s Way**—
whatever is done,
does not contend with others.
The Sage holds nothing back,
gives ever more to others—
thus, no contention."*

**Master Gong of the He River** said:
*"The Sage follows Heaven’s **Dao**,
takes no action of his own.
Transformation complete, deeds accomplished,
he does not contend for fame or merit—
thus his sagehood remains whole."*

**Master Cheng’s commentary** said:
*"The Sage’s highest virtue
follows the **Dao**, open and unobstructed,
his actions reaching even the lowest,
his transformation encompassing all ranks.
He guards himself with humility,
achieves success without claiming it,
attributing merit to others—
thus it is said, ‘without contention.’"*

*Thus concludes the twenty-second scroll of the* **Mysterious Virtue Commentary on the* Dao De Jing*.*
